title: Pitch Bend via Midi Controller
post_content: Hi Everyone,When controlling Nord Drum 3P with an external midi keyboard controller, is it possible to use pitch ben on the controller? Right now the Nord Drum doesn't respond to pitch bend. Is there a setting I need to adjust? or is it not possible?Thank you!

title: RE: Pitch Bend via Midi Controller
post_content: Hi Skram, welcome to the forum!No, you can't do pitch bend.You can control the pitch of the tone with MIDI CCs, but that's stepped and goes through the entire note range, not a small and smooth increase or decrease relative to the note you're playing.Cheers,Albert

title: 3P - is it possible to change banks via midi program change?
post_content: Hi all,After years of wanting one I have finally bought a Nord Drum P3, and love it to bits.For many years I have been using Roland TD modules to play drums live, currently a TD-50 and other Roland devices such as Octapad and SPD-SX.By connecting MIDI In and Out on the Roland devices each kit change will make the other Roland devices change kits also (and vice-versa) which is very useful playing live.The Nord Drum P3 also works linked like this via MIDI cables to the Roland TD-50.However the banks only go up to 50 kits each whereas the Roland devices go up to 100. (I don't have 100 songs per gig but I do play with a number of bands with different sets and I like to have one kit per song in the set lists stored in the Roland TD-50).I have done some reading up on MIDI and while it looks as though it should be possible to switch banks on the P3 via midi I don't see a way to do it with these particular devices.I wondered if anyone could shed light on this please - all thoughts and comments welcome.cheers,

title: RE: 3P - is it possible to change banks via midi program change?
post_content: not 100% sure that I understand the question here...you are trying to:1) use the Nord to send bank change messages to some other device, or2) use some other device to send bank change messages to the Nord?Hopefully not #1 because that is not possible.  #2 is not documented and I don't have an ND3P on hand to test this with at the moment, but...I wouldn't be surprised if it responded to bank select messages sent from other devices.  Check out the format Nord uses on Stage 3 and try sending it to your ND3P and see what happens.  I'll wager (a small amount) that it will work.  Please let us all know what you are able to find.Bless, Pablo

title: RE: 3P - is it possible to change banks via midi program change?
post_content: Hi willsud,There is bank select and program change, although related functionally, they are two different things when it comes to controlling them via MIDI;Program change are quite universal MIDI messages that in case of the 3p will change theprogram within a bank. There is a setting in the MIDI menu that controls if these program changes are sent/received by the 3p, the manual says : Program Change can be set to off (of), send only (s), receive only (r) and to both send and receive (sr). set this to receive if you want to change the programs on the Nord drum 3P from a mIdI controller or a sequencer.Range: PC.Of, PC.S, PC.r, PC.SrFor Bank Select the 3p uses a combination of 2 CC messages (CC0 MSB and CC32 LSB). There is a general setting in the MIDI menu for what the 3p does with CC messages: Control Change can be set to Off, Send only, Receive only and both Send and Receive. Set this to receive if you want to change parameters on the Nord Drum 3p from a MIDI controller or a sequencer. Range: CC.Of, CC.S, CC.r, CC.Sr. Bank Select requires a pair of LSB and MSB values (Least Significant - and Most Significant Byte). Transmit the LSB value first, then the MSB value. Which values will select which bank is probably easiest to find out by monitoring what MIDI messages the 3p sends when selecting banks.Of the two, program change is the more universal in MIDI, although the reach is limited; within one bank of the 3p. Bank change requires some CC messages specific for the 3p (or Nord*), and will possibly/probably not be compatible with Bank selection in instruments of other brands, *(Nord Stage for example uses the same CC's).Cheers,Albert

title: RE: 3P - is it possible to change banks via midi program change?
post_content: I'm controlling my Nord Drum 3P with mySquarp Hapaxsequencer that can send a MSB, LSB and PC MIDI signals whenever changing a pattern. What I did was1. In the Nord Drum MIDI settings: set program change and control change to "receive" (PC r / CC r)2. On my sequencer: LSB controls the Bank: 0=A, 1=B, 2=C and so on. The MSB doesn't seem to matter, neither empty "––" or some value "03" does anything. The PC changes the Drum Kit 1=1, 11=11 and so on.So to change my Drum Kit to C11, I would send LSB=2, PC=11. Change it back to A1: LSB=0, PC=1.Hope this helpsEdit: I got aFaderfox EC4now too, bank change is a bit different there: I set knob 1 to CCAh, Disp 9999, Numb 000, Lower 0, Upper 7. And knob 2 to PrgC, Lower 0, Upper 49.Knob 1 sends MSB 0 (Numb) and LSB 0-7, BUT … this only gets executed when you send a PC. So to change the preset from A1 to C32, I must first turn knob 1 to 002 (nothing happens), then turn knob 2 to 031 (Nord jumps to C32). To change it back to A1, first turn knob 1 to 000, then knob 2 to 000. Just changing presets within 1 bank only requires knob 2 with the program change.

title: RE: Nord 3P CC10 Pan
post_content: Well, yes, perhaps firmware, or a faulty unit, maybe someone with a 3p can chime in..Perhaps there is still something to be found in your setup, or MIDI settings-Could there be a MIDI loop going on? Is the 3p's MIDI output connected to the MIDI input of your digitakt?-Make sure the digitakt is only sending the CCs to the individual MIDI channels. If CC messages are also sent to the global MIDI channel, they might clash/conflict with messages sent to the individual channels, CCs on the global MIDI channel are directed to the drum channel that is in focus/selected.

title: RE: Nord 3P CC10 Pan
post_content: Frustrating. Do you have a MIDI monitor app to check what the digitakt is outputting?If you send CC messages per note with p-locks, perhaps the order and timing of the messages are important for the 3p to respond properly. According to the thread "Parameter locking not working with external instrument" on Elektronauts, the digitakt sends the note first. I'd say that CCs to control sound parameters ideally should come before the note on. That is also how I control the ND2 from my DAW or other gear. On the other hand, one would expect that if a CC comes too late to have an effect on one note, it should affect the next, unless the digitakt resets CC 10 to a default value between notes for some reason.I think monitoring the MIDI output of the Digitakt is the best way to find out what is going on..

Nothing about the interface is recognized in the drum manager. Open to any and all suggestions. Thanks for any answers.

title: RE: Windows 10 not recognizing m-audio uno sport midi interface
post_content: Are the other MIDI messages from the ND3P recognized by your computer (for instance in a DAW or in another midi console)?The ND3P midi manager can be picky, especially if the MIDI interface is low quality (which could be your case). I remember that using a crappy USB MIDI interface the sysex messages from the ND3P would get cut out and the manager would crash entirely. Using the midi interface of my Focusrite card would show no problems though.Those USB midi interface more often than not just can't deal with the way some machines send sysex messages. I found the Midisport manual online and it says that it should manage long sysex messages, granted the right drivers are installed. I have founds also some reports of people online saying that sometimes the interface correctly sends/receives sysex and sometimes not. It is an old interface but according to M-Audio's website itsdriversshould be supported by Win11.You can try downloading a MIDI monitor app like MIdi-OX or MIDIview and see what you computer receives from the midi dump. It should start with the byte F0 and end with byte F7 and it should be 295 bytes long if I remember correctly. Anything else means that the message is being corrupted. It should look something like this (this is a sysex dump from my Nord Lead 3).midioc.png (138.87 KiB) Viewed 1812 timesAnyway, if you happen to put your hands on a more solid interface (like an audio interface with midi connection or like the 2x2 midisport) your problem should go away.

title: RE: Windows 10 not recognizing m-audio uno sport midi interface
post_content: Thanks for the detailed response. Im not going to pretend that I fully understand all the things you were saying above like how to send sysex messages through the midisport. But I ended up finding the usb devices section in windows and it was saying that there was a driver error. Tried rolling back, updating and reinstalling the driver from the manufacturers website, but none of that ended up working. I searched a little more about m-audio and from what I gather, they're not very good about keeping their drivers up to date. I didn't realize it at the time, but as you said, it's an old ass interface. So I ended up grabbing another midi interface(Lekato LUM-01) that was recommended by another user in the nord keyboards side to use with nord sound manager and it ended up working right away for drum manager. Apparently, this one is fully class compliant. No driver issues whatsoever. Just plug and play. But again, thanks for the detailed response and I'll go ahead and download that test program incase of any future issues.

title: How to increase output signal?
post_content: I use multiple instruments for live looping and just bought a nord drum 3p. I am routing all the instruments into a Motu M6 interface. The first 4 inputs are boosted (not sure if that is the correct term?), but inputs 5/6 are not. The issue I'm running into is that the only 2 inputs left for the Nord are 5 and 6, and the resulting sound is VERY quiet even with the master volume maxed.Any ideas on how to fix this? Should I pull the trigger on a stereo preamp to use in between the Nord and the interface, something like this?https://www.musiciansfriend.com/pro-aud ... /120621118

title: RE: How to increase output signal?
post_content: Hi sonotx, welcome to the forum!If one of your other instruments has higher output levels than the 3p, connect that one to inputs 5/6, and connect the 3p to inputs with gain control. If such a swap is not an option, you could try to increase the channel levels of the 3p. These are set per drum channel and stored per program/kit.If you're playing a drum sequence via MIDI, send higher velocity notes. If you're playing the pads, try different velocity curves or sensitivity settings so that it becomes easier to reach higher velocity levels. Increasing velocity will also change the sound characteristics though.Cheers,Albert

title: Nord Drum 3P pad problems solved! - Everyone needs to read and be aware!
post_content: Sup,So Ive had a faulty ND3P and its needed service many times due to faulty pad connections.Dealing with Clavia has been................frustrating.... yet smooth....to put it that way.    Swedes arent good at customer service and it comes off lazy and appears work ethics lacks. Ill just say that.However its confirmed now buy them that this issue is recurring in many units and it is in fact a design flaw.The pads float and are subject to move when packed or while playing (if you see some units the pads are too far apart or close together or one pad is smashed all the way to one direction).This shorts the wires out from the pads to brain!  They are confirmed to be too short and tight!  Make note of this!   Ive suspected this to be the case for years but has now been confirmed.No wires have been lengthened in the whole unit so to e will tell if this solved the issues and I suspect it will.Only took more than 4 times of broken pad wires for this to be a solution......Ive been so fed up with this unit but unfortunately seems to be the only thing like it in existence.   Was looking at perkons hd1 and vermona drum but it lacks clear info if input trigger pads can be used and only 4 voices.  Im craving a unit with editable physical knob controls and trigger inputs.  Its 2024 and I have no clue why not one has made this stuff......Good luck everyone.  Lets pray for a 4P soon thats got external inputs and a plethora of other features!

title: RE: Nord Drum 3P pad problems solved! - Everyone needs to read and be aware!
post_content: Hi Naughty Nord 4P,So, the pads can move over time (which indeed has been reported on this forum before) and you're saying the wires underneath the pads are too short and/or fragile, and they will short(?)How would you describe the problems that you were having as a result of all this? Did some pads suddenly stop working so that they couldn't be triggered anymore, or did you also experience other changes, like (an increase in) crosstalk between the pads? What were the first signs?I checked my Nord Pad (of the ND2), luckily the pads are still aligned properly. I can see that the wires of the bottom row of pads (piezos) go straight up, underneath the first row, to the board in the top bezel. So, together with the wires of the top row, there are 6 neatly spaced pairs that connect to the board. I can imagine that if the pads would move/slide, the wires could break. If pads physically touch, it may cause crosstalk, perhaps also if the wires of 2 different pads are in close proximity.Cheers,Albert

Did some pads suddenly stop working so that they couldn't be triggered anymore, or did you also experience other changes, like (an increase in) crosstalk between the pads? I can see that the wires of the bottom row of pads (piezos) go straight up, underneath the first row, to the board in the top bezel. So, together with the wires of the top row, there are 6 neatly spaced pairs that connect to the board. I can imagine that if the pads would move/slide, the wires could break. If pads physically touch, it may cause crosstalk, perhaps also if the wires of 2 different pads are in close proximity.Cheers,AlbertHey albert.The pads just stopped working, or triggered other pads around the pads that was failing and generally not triggering and over 4 times it was the same issues, wiring to the pads and brain.Sure we can see the wires to the pads and Theres no give in them. This creates a problem if you play the unit primarily with sticks or hands.  Eventually it seems the wires pull and the soldiers get weak.Thankfully my unit has been fixed and adjusted to accommodate these oversights in the construction of the production of the nord drum 3p.  We will see how long it lasts.The wires are too tight and short and over time with playing or moving around they will get weak at the solder joints. Thus creating false triggers and pads that dont work properly.

title: How do I connect 3P to MacBook Pro via Arturia Studio?
post_content: Title says it all. Using MacBook Pro from 2019. Arturia Studio interface with 1/8” midi inout. Which cables? How? Made by who? title: RE: How do I connect 3P to MacBook Pro via Arturia Studio?
post_content: Hi damnedcat777,I presume your question is about MIDI, not about audio. (Audio is quite simple; if you want to record the audio, you just need 2 jack-to-jack audio cables to connect the audio outputs of the 3p to some inputs of the Audiofuse, set up a stereo audio track in your DAW using the 2 inputs and hit record.)MIDI: The Audiofuse studio comes with 2 MIDI adapter cables, these have a TRS mini jack on one end and a female DIN on the other end. Use the ones that came with the Audiofuse, I think they are 'type B' adapters. You also need 5 pin DIN MIDI cables* - get 2 of them:-Connect one of the Arturia MIDI adapters to the MIDI OUT jack port of the Audiofuse, connect a MIDI cable between the adapter and the MIDI IN port of the 3p.-To record MIDI from the 3p, connect a MIDI cable from the MIDI OUT of the 3p, to the Arturia adapter connected to the MIDI IN jack port of the Audiofuse.-For firmware updates of the 3p you need to connect both IN and OUT, so you really want 2 MIDI cables.*MIDI cable:https://www.guitarcenter.com/Roland/Gol ... 0044677.gcCheers, Albert

title: Separate channels on nord 3p
post_content: Hi.I have been trying to set each page to a different channel so I can track separately, but I cant get the nord to split the pads. Global off Chanel 1-6 and created tracks in Reaper, recording midi ch 1-6 and it doesn't trigger the nord pads.Any clue whats going on??

title: RE: Separate channels on nord 3p
post_content: Hi Naughty Nord 4p,The individual MIDI channels can only receive MIDI, not send, so MIDI can only be recorded from the global MIDI channel. Perhaps you can transform each note coming from the global MIDI channel to a new note with the same velocity, note number 60 on the desired channel (depending on the original note number).Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Separate channels on nord 3p
post_content: wartalerwrote:↑16 Jan 2025, 23:33Hi Naughty Nord 4p,The individual MIDI channels can only receive MIDI, not send, so MIDI can only be recorded from the global MIDI channel. Perhaps you can transform each note coming from the global MIDI channel to a new note with the same velocity, note number 60 on the desired channel (depending on the original note number).Cheers,AlbertCan you explain a bit more about what you mean?

title: RE: Separate channels on nord 3p
post_content: Because the 3p doesn't send MIDI from individual MIDI channels, you can't record the 6 drum channels onto different MIDI tracks directly. The workaround is to somehow transform the MIDI data coming from the global MIDI channel of the 3p. Perhaps your DAW can do this, or hardware like the Blokas Midihub, or the Bomebox. You'll have to split the notes coming from the global MIDI channel of the 3p into separate MIDI channels depending on the note number, and then change the note number to 60 of all notes on all 6 tracks, the exact method depends on the DAW, MIDI plugin, or hardware.Not sure but reading back your original post, I may have misinterpreted your initial question, if so, let me know!

title: RE: Midi control from Roland spdsx pro
post_content: Hi Naughty Nord 4p,USB-MIDI interfaces that look like a cable have a USB A connector on one end and 2 MIDI DIN connectors on the other. Their purpose is to connect MIDI devices to a computer (/tablet/phone), you can't use it to connect the 3p to your Roland.They vary in quality, I'd only buy them from a proper musical instruments store, avoid the very cheap ones, check compatibility with your OS, read reviews before you buy.The ESI and iConnectivity ones work fine I believe. The ESI MidiMate Ex automatically detects how you connected it, so it can be used as 2 outputs, 2 inputs, or 1 input and 1 output.Cheers,Albert

Message: "No reply from drum. Please check midi setup."- Tried using USB midi cable (I've seen these can be cheap and not work), but also have tried running it through midi on my focusrite interface, Elektron gear, Cirklon sequencer, and Arturia keystep 37. Happy to provide any other details and if anyone has any tips or suggestions to try, anything is welcome. Thank you!

title: RE: Problems connecting 3P
post_content: Hi furiousmother, welcome to the forum!That's frustrating indeed,A couple of tips/suggestions, you possibly knew already, but just to be sure:-Press SHIFT and DRUM KIT SELECT while powering the 3p up to start it in Update Ready Mode,-try to avoid USB hubs in between your audio/MIDI interface and your PC, preferably USB ports on the motherboard (rear of the PC)-because the update utility wants to do a handshake with the 3p both MIDI IN and OUT should be connected, that's connecting OUT of your interface to the IN of the 3p, and the OUT of the 3p to IN of the interface,-In the update utility make sure to select the correct MIDI interface and ports for both connections-being able to send and receive MIDI notes does not guarantee that the interface can also be used for firmware updates, it is indeed a good idea to try a couple as you did.Good luck!Cheers,Albert

title: Nord Drum 2 checksum
post_content: Hi, I've been developing a patch editor/generator for the ND2, but am hung up on a system exclusive issue. Does anyone here know how the checksums are calculated for the Nord Drum 2? There's a 7-bit (1 byte) checksum for requests and a 21-bit (3 byte) checksum for voice data. I've tried a variety of CRC algorithms without hitting on the right one, maybe someone here knows the secret sauce.Thanks, Jeremy

title: RE: Nord Drum 2 checksum
post_content: Wanted to do the same and asked Nord for this 2-3 years ago for the D2 and D1 to save patches more easily. Spend days on trying to figure it out but had to give up. Nord's answer then was that  sysex/checksum  "was not a secret but they just did not have it  and CC could do the job". It is a kind if interesting as for older products (NL1/2/3) the Sysex was made available but then suddenly not anymore for any products. Around the same time Roland started to stop disclosing Sysex as well. Really like the D1 & D2, except for this. It is the main reason why I did not buy an NL4, A1 and an Electro and went for Dave Smith / Sequential products.

title: RE: ND3P Channel 6 responds to CC's sent on other channels
post_content: Hi Elektron84,Strange, but it's not only CC messages on the individual MIDI channels that can change parameters, CC messages on the global MIDI channel can affect parameters of the selected drum channel (Ch select buttons / pad follow), not sure if that continues/stops when you return to drum kit selection mode. After restarting the unit, no channel has been selected yet, so I suspect it won't respond to CCs on the global MIDI channel until you select a channel to edit.Cheers,Albert

title: RE: How to recover Nord Drum 3P after failed OS update?
post_content: Hi Oggi2,That is quite unfortunate, a similar problem was mentioned in a topic in 2013, but it is not clear to me how it was solved then:nord-drum-forum-f27/nord-drum-freezing- ... t4967.htmlPerhaps the connection with your 3p was not that great to begin with, it shouldn't take 10 minutes to update the OS. Some Mac users seem to have problems connecting to the 3p, and some MIDI interfaces are not suitable for doing OS updates. If you have a good quality MIDI interface, perhaps try it on a Windows PC.The manual states the following at the bottom of the update section: "Press SHIFT and DRUM KIT SELECT while powering the unit up to start the Nord Drum 3P in Update Ready Mode, without booting from the currently installed Operating System." not sure when this is applicable, but the message in your screen suggests yours is already in this mode when you boot it up. It can't hurt to try it.If all fails, perhaps you should contact the distributor, the contact form on the Nord website is forwarded to the distributor and Clavia (Nord). title: Nord Drum 3P with DSI TEMPEST

title: RE: Nord Drum 3P with DSI TEMPEST
post_content: I have a Tempest and use an external Electronic Drumkit(Yamaha DTXpress)to trigger sounds on the Tempest,this is the same process as you wish to do with the ND/TempestYou'll need to connect a Midi cable from Nord Drum-Midi Out to Tempest Midi InThen you will need to assign the Nord Drum to the same Global Midi channel as the Tempest and then assign the Pad Midi note numbers on the Nord drum to match the Tempest pad note numbers.I have no experience with the Nord Drum directly so not sure if you can change the Midi note number assignments of the Pads directly or if they are fixed to set note numbers,if they are fixed on the ND then you can change the Note numbers of the Pads on the Tempest in the system menus pages,change them to match the Nords Note assignments you should then be able to trigger the sounds on the tempest from the ND pads

title: RE: Nord Drum 3P with DSI TEMPEST
post_content: Hi Naughty Nord,As you can see AdamStage2 left this forum, so he probably won't answer your question, unless he re-joined under another name.The key settings are the Global MIDI channel on the 3p (which is the MIDI channel the 3p transmits MIDI on) and the MIDI note, which is set per drum channel (/pad).Note 60 on the 3p corresponds with 'middle' C, that's C3 or C4 depending on which standard the Tempest uses (Yamaha resp. Roland) for octave numbering.Check the Tempest manual how to trigger drum sounds using MIDI notes on page 70 and 71..Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Nord Pad suddenly stopped working with Nord Drum 2
post_content: Hi Handed,The category is usually printed on the sheath of the cable, my original cable is a CAT 6 UTP, the number tells you which generation of cable it is, each new category has better isolation between the wires, reducing crosstalk within the cable. UTP means it is unshielded. Maybe the category doesn’t really matter for this use, it perhaps tells you something about the age of the cable indirectly.Because you tested a couple of cables, I agree it seems to point to a problem with the port. Cleaning and checking it for physical damage makes sense, although it may be difficult to really tell, the contacts are very small to start with. There are some small structures to keep the connector in the right position, perhaps these can wear too. If I were you I would try to get it checked/serviced.Albert

title: RE: Nord Pad suddenly stopped working with Nord Drum 2

title: RE: using Nord Drum 3P as a 6 voice synth
post_content: Naughty Nord 4P wrote:As the title says. I want to plug my nord Drum into my midi keyboard and use it as a synth as well.  I have been successful but its only on 1 channel.  I can choose channel 1-6.   Can I play it as a 6 voice synth or is it only Mono???Should be possible to get this thing to be able to play some chords as midi no? Such a setup would use theindividual MIDI Channels. Make sure that each Nord Drum 3P Channel isset to an exclusive MIDI Channel.-dj

title: RE: using Nord Drum 3P as a 6 voice synth
post_content: I've used anRK-002to do a simple voice assignment for the ND2. It works with the 3P as well. Basically i have my kick, snare and hihat as normal, and then the last three voices are copies of each other and then the midi keyboard input cycles the channels 4, 5, and 6. This way i have a three voice polyphonic synth on those channels.Any way to do a midi channel multiplexer will work and you can build synths from 1-6 voices of polyphony. Of course, with six voices you no longer have any other drum sounds available.

title: RE: using Nord Drum 3P as a 6 voice synth
post_content: Exactly right, I did something similar with the Blokas midihub, made the nd2 into a very compact 6 voice polyphonic synth for melodies or chords. You can even let the note length depend on how long you press a key by increasing the decay time to the highest value (longest) at note on, and decrease again to the minimum at note off.

title: RE: using Nord Drum 3P as a 6 voice synth
post_content: wartaler wrote:Exactly right, I did something similar with the Blokas midihub, made the nd2 into a very compact 6 voice polyphonic synth for melodies or chords. You can even let the note length depend on how long you press a key by increasing the decay time to the highest value (longest) at note on, and decrease again to the minimum at note off.Amazing! I've been using a midi round robin script in Reaper. But I've always longed for note length control. Can you please describe how you set that up (I thought the ND2 didnt have note on/off?). Many thanks mate.

title: RE: using Nord Drum 3P as a 6 voice synth
post_content: Hi Stoat,Step 1The first step is indeed the easiest; dispatch simultaneous notes (chords) from a keyboard or MIDI track into the 6 MIDI channels of the ND2 (or 3p). These notes will have note on, and (some form of) note off messages.Step 2Now the notes are all in separate MIDI channels (step 1), have all note-on messages trigger a CC50 value 127 (longest tone decay), and CC21 value 127 (longest noise decay). Also, have note-off messages trigger CC50 value 0 and CC21 value 0. The Midihub transforms the note-on and off messages to CCs, so I have to make sure to keep the original note on messages when sending it all to the ND2/3p, luckily this is simply done by selecting 'insert' in stead of 'replace' in the editor. In my DAW I had to merge the newly generated CC messages back with the notes from step 1.-and that's it!Instead of the decay parameter, I also tried channel level, but that caused some clicking artifacts. You can of course experiment with the max and min decay values, it doesn't have to be 127 and 0.In the midihub I am using a transformer 'pipe', I bet there are MIDI plugins that can do this conversion if your DAW can't do this natively..Cheers,Albert

title: RE: using Nord Drum 3P as a 6 voice synth
post_content: Wonderful - thank youEdit: just to add for others, I'm using this for the round robin (https://stash.reaper.fm/v/415/MIDI%20Ch ... Router.txt), and I'm going to try this (http://www.bewaryprods.com/software/pro ... index.html) for the midi note to CC transform. TBH the Blokas midihub looks the best way, on the Santa list

title: RE: using Nord Drum 3P as a 6 voice synth
post_content: Here is how I set it up in Cubase:nord-drum-forum-f27/synth-sounds-with-n ... tml#p45072I used some of these plugins:http://thepiz.org/plugins/?p=pizmidi(midiPolyphony and midiConverter3). I like the Blokas Midihub for its ease of use, the BomeBox by Bome should also be able to do this with the 'MIDI translator Pro' software

title: RE: using Nord Drum 3P as a 6 voice synth
post_content: I forgot how easy it is with the Midihub; in the dispatcher 'pipe' (block) you just tick the desired output MIDI channels. I also needed 2 transformation pipes: one to set a long tone decay at note on, one to set a short note decay at note off. I didn't include control over noise decay, but that would only require 2 additional pipes. The transformation pipes can process all MIDI channels at the same time, and you can decide if you want to replace the original note-on/off messages with the newly generated CC, or simply add the new CC messages, keeping the original note-on messages.1D66BE2E-2A65-4F80-AF04-4CDF33894488.png (5.94 KiB) Viewed 13479 times

title: RE: Anyone use the Bastl Midi Looper?
post_content: So you are on the same midichannel on both devices. Do you see midi incoming on the Bastl? A small led wil be blinking when recieving midi.If that is the case the Bastl will record.The use-case that you want, should be possible with the Bastl.Have you tried sequencing the 3P with another device?Another suggestion: you haven't muted the selected voice on the Bastl?

title: RE: Anyone use the Bastl Midi Looper?
post_content: Hi BobbyT,Sounds frustrating, I don't own the Bastl looper either, but here are a couple of ideas based on their manual:-On the Bastl make sure that static octave offset is off. On the 3p's global MIDI channel you have to return exactly the same MIDI notes, otherwise no drum sounds will be triggered.-On the 3p, keep the individual MIDI channels off (or at least make sure they're not using the same MIDI channel as the global) - each drum channel is monophonic, if one drum channel receives two triggers at once via MIDI it may result in notes cutting off, or other weird stuff-Although I don't think your problem is caused by feedback, it never hurts to try this (from the Bastl looper manual): "you can activate the MIDI feedback filter on the Midilooper. While selecting the MIDI channel on the voice that is feedbacking, press the CLEAR button. This will turn on the MIDI FEEDBACK FILTER or in other words: disable the live playback on that particular channel"-I don't think that the Bastl looper requires a MIDI clock from the MIDI input. Using either the tap tempo or free running option on the Bastl will allow you to go back to a basic MIDI setup without the MIDI merger.-In the Bastl manual they're using a separate keyboard to input notes for the loop, perhaps you should try that too to diagnose the problem: connect your keyboard to MIDI IN of the looper, the 3p to the MIDI OUT of the looper, set the looper 'voice' to MIDI channel 10. Perhaps even try to directly trigger drum sounds with the keyboard without the looper, to check if the 3p receives any MIDI notes. Remember that on the keyboard you have to play the exact notes as set in the MIDI menu of the 3p to trigger the drum sounds.-check/swap MIDI cablesGood luck!Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Anyone use the Bastl Midi Looper?
post_content: Hi BobbyT,I wouldn't give up yet. I think it is a nice and easy looper to pair with your 3p once you got this problem sorted. Check if there is a Bastl MIDI looper section on Elektronauts, or Mod Wiggler, see if other people are having similar difficulties with their looper. If you hadn't already, check this video by Bastl:On the 3p the MIDI note is set per drum channel. In the MIDI menu use the drum channel selection buttons (CH SELECT) to see the note [nt.XX] for each drum channel. Only these 6 MIDI notes will trigger the drum sounds via the global MIDI channel, any other notes will be ignored. So if the looper for example transposes all recorded notes with an octave, you won't hear any drum sounds.Also using the channel selection buttons, make sure that the individual MIDI channel is off on all 6 drum channels [Ch.OF]. The global MIDI channel [GL.10] applies to all 6 drum channels, and should correspond with the voice MIDI output channel on the looper. As advised in the Bastl video, switch local off on the 3p when it's connected to the looper [Lo.OF]. This is a global setting that will be reset (!) when you switch off the 3p. (the 'feedback filter' setting on the Bastl basically does the same.) If you happen to have a USB MIDI interface, you could check what MIDI is coming out of the looper in a DAW, or MIDI monitoring app, it may help to further diagnose the problem.Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Multiple pads being triggered on nord drum 3p
post_content: Hi David, welcome to the forum!Usually raising the threshold should help with that. Adjust the sensitivity & curve so that you don't have to play it that hard to reach maximum volume. Not sure if placing it on a stand will reduce vibrations within the unit but it probably helps with ergonomics, and perhaps that will help you to hit the pads less hard.Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Multiple pads being triggered on nord drum 3p
post_content: Thank you for your reply!Just to ensure, because as I said earlier I'm very new to drum pads. It is completely normal for the pads to be triggered silently, right?

title: RE: Multiple pads being triggered on nord drum 3p
post_content: I think the answer is: 'it depends'. The threshold setting is there for that reason, so it's something that occurs under certain circumstances. If you find it impossible to get rid of it, you're possibly hitting it too hard, or there is indeed something wrong with the unit. It's a bit difficult to assess from here. When mine is on the floor it's worse than when it's on a stand. Here on the forum some people reported that the rubber pads were physically touching each other, which clearly is a defect that should be looked at.Good luck,Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Can't connect Nord Drum 3p with Nord Drum 3 Manager (MAC)
post_content: Hi all,I just bought a Nord Drum 3 and also have problems using the Nord Drum 3 Manager.The MIDI adapter is recognized by the Drum Manager and I can send and receive MIDI data to/from Nord Drums 3 (I verified it using a MIDI monitor and DAW).Thus, it's obviously not related to the hardware or operating system...Interestingly, it does not work for both, Mac OS 14 and Windows 10.I hope bug fix will be released soon!UpdateI tried using a MOTU interface and it works now for Mac OS 14 and Windows 10 for me (before I used a cheap, old LogiLink USB-MIDI adapter)!This is quite interesting as for basic MIDI messages (e.g. Notes, CC, ...) the LogiLink adapter "worked".Maybe the problem is related to the generic USB-MIDI driver of Mac OS / Windows as LogiLink does not offer dedicated drivers.Or the cheap, internal hardware of the LogiLink adapter introduced some race conditions or similar resulting in this issue (I guess this has higher probability).Anyways, I would recommend to try a proper, more recent MIDI interface:)

title: Nord Drum 3P iOS editor
post_content: Hi,Since I do not like to do sound design on the 3P itself, I have created an iPad editor template for it, using the TB Midi Stuff app.It's a snapshot of 7 editor pages:When you start it up you will get the start up screen and after tapping on "Start" you will be directed to the editor page for channel 1. In the upper half you'll see the distortion, eq, FXs and channel level/panning parameters, plus a small trigger pad for that channel. In the lower half you will find the three "sound" components with their respective parameters: Noise, Wave and Click.At the bottom of the screen you can navigate between the six channel pages and one editor page that mirrors the 6 pads of the 3P module where I also added a channel level slider for eacht channel.You can use the editor wireless when connected to the same wifi network as your computer (assuming the 3P is connected with a MIDI interface to that computer), or directly wired from the iPad to your 3P module.I will post a youtube vid asap to show some of the functionallity.The template is purely aimed at easier sound design (and boy, one can create very cool drum/percussion and other sounds with the 3P!). I made it for personal use, but why not share it with others.Send me an email to receive the template plus an extensive readme file atbjgerkes@gmail.comYou'll need to buy the TB MIDI stuff app to be able to use the template. Last time I checked it was 4,99 euro's.Regards, Boele

Is there any way to fix this?

title: RE: Drum 3P driving me crazy! Major latency and other issues.
post_content: Hi Christ2000, welcome to the forum!Strange and frustrating indeed! This is not normal for the 3p or Nord synths in general, I can't remember anyone else mentioning noticeable latency like that.Apart from a bad MIDI cable, or a broken 3p, issues can occur if for some reason multiple MIDI notes trigger a single drum channel at the same time. This is because each drum channel is monophonic. Notes may cut each other off, the 3p will sound erratic.This may occur if, for example, the general MIDI channel is the same as one or more of the individual MIDI channels.Hope you get it sorted!Albert

title: RE: Drum 3P driving me crazy! Major latency and other issues.
post_content: Could it be some sort of command overload? Did you check the MIDI command stream of your Cirkon? You might send it to a computer with a MIDI monitor software running.

title: RE: Drum 3P driving me crazy! Major latency and other issues.
post_content: Well, a sequencer can output a lot of MIDI data of course, but the OP also encountered this problem when playing a single note on a keyboard. It nevertheless is a good idea to monitor whatever MIDI is sent, it will probably also show if something's wrong with the cable.I think these are the most common MIDI related problems with the Nord drum 2 and 3p I've read here on the forum:-triggering a drum channel with more than one MIDI note at once, (usually due to Individual & Global MIDI channel setup)-bad MIDI cables, bad MIDI interfaces,-MIDI thru not working as expected when daisy chaining multiple devices,-MIDI loops-hardware itself malfunctioning (can't fully exclude it)-I don't think there is (or ever was) a MIDI related problem with the 3p firmware

title: RE: Drum 3P driving me crazy! Major latency and other issues.
post_content: Sounds like a midi loop somewhere for sure. I've had this sometimes, and making a linear midi setup to debug makes a lot of things easier

title: RE: Can't send banks to P3?
post_content: UPDATE / RESOLVEDI was able to resolve my issue; I'm not entirely sure what was happening, but I'm guessing it was the cables I was using (I never switched, and they eventually worked, but I just have this feeling). I kept resetting my Mac, and each time I booted up Nord Drum 3 Manager, the progress bar would advance a little further when sending the bank files to my 3P (this is why I believe the issue was ultimately because of my cables).For those who are curious what settings I used: under SYSTEM, I have Pr.OF and PL.1; under MIDI, I have Lo.On, GL.10, Ch.1, nt.60, PC.Sr, CC.Sr, SE.nd (*this setting in particular I left flashing in all of the successful attempts, by hitting the "drum kit select' key; the manual mentions this for backing up Banks to a PC, but not for restoring Banks to the P3, but I tried anyway with success)I kept trying, because I was able to update my 3P (which requires MIDI in), so I was sure it had to be something else. title: Nord drum 3p pad issues, faulty service and WE NEED A 4P!
post_content: For the most part this whole forum for nord drums is dead but I'll make a post anyways.A few days ago I've had my Nord drum 3p pad crap put on me for a 3RD TIME.  Yes 3 times.  I'll be sending it to clavia for service soon and I have read a few posts tht have the same issues. One pad craps out or triggers other pads.  This is faulty by design I think.  If you open the unit, you can see just how short the wires are from the first pads up to the circuit board.  To me this is an issue because the floating pads tug and pull on these wires and eventually shorting the connection.It's annoying as hell to have constant issues with this thing.  When I have the bass drum pedal plugged in it triggers crazy notes when recording.  I've turned the sensitivity to one and messed with the threshold to no avail....I've opted to go without the bass pad pedal entirely.I wish they would have added a hi hat trigger and a SEPARATE bass drum channel!I wish they would have released the nord drum 3 unit with 6 inputs for pads instead of the built in ones as well.  I have seen some mods with this and reached out to a guy whom did this and claims Nord has left components inside to connect jacks for each pad on the circuit board.   IF my pads go out again after the 3rd time servicing the unit, I will commission a  local metalworker and electrical synth repair man to install 1/3 jacks for each pad and have a custom metal backing to complete the unit. I'll use nice pads to replace the built in ones.  Plus the Nord pads are noisy as all hell and too clicky and loud.I have come to the conclusion this unit will be with me forever because there is no other drum synth on the market like this and I don't see anyone having balls to make one anytime soon.  And for me the ability to drum out synth stuff is invaluable, so I'm willing to modify this thing for my use only.  To hell with it.IMHO Nord has really dropped the ball here.  I would LOVE for a unit to have the ability for external pads, hi hat and bass triggers, and ALL KNOB PER FUNCTION!!!  I could live with a unit that is double thick as the current one, I don't care, as long as it has these things this unit would be the beast of synths on the market, no aceptions.   Hell if they did that you can still use MIDI keyboard with it and it's a full fledged key synth, drum synth and all around monster.Nord drum 4p or anything after this IS NOT COMING.  It's been 7 years or so and counting since the 3P release?...I'm not holding my breath for anything more.Anyone else have issues with their unit or did similar modifications to their units? Any tips and success stories??Thanks!

title: RE: Nord drum 3p pad issues, faulty service and WE NEED A 4P!

title: RE: drum3p midi
post_content: Hi sofrito95, welcome to the forum!The way to address the 6 drum sounds of the 3p using 6 different notes on one MIDI track is to set the track output MIDI channel to  the same as the General MIDI channel on the 3p. The default MIDI channel for this is 10, you can check and adjust this in the MIDI menu [G.10]. The notes to be used are also set in the MIDI menu ([nt.60] etc.) for each drum sound (drum channel).Make sure none of the Individual MIDI channels [Ch.X] is the same as the General MIDI channel [G.Y].Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Nord 3P random ghost notes on midi playback
post_content: Hi oliverbetts, welcome to the forum!Interesting..I agree with Mr G to check what MIDI messages are coming from the MIDI interface. Perhaps some MIDI effect is applied in the DAW, perhaps your MIDI interface or cabling is the culprit. What MIDI interface are you using?Do these 'ghost' notes occur completely randomly, or is there a pattern in these notes?Perhaps try to switch Local off (Lo:Of), to prevent any 'spontaneous' triggering from the pads, which can occur when pad threshold settings are too low / sensitivity settings are too high..If the 3p's MIDI Out is connected to the MIDI interface, check if the problem still occurs when you disconnect that cable.Does it occur with one drum channel on the 3p or with more?Cheers,Albert

title: Improving the Drum 3P?
post_content: I'm not a drummer, as such, so take these opinions with a pinch of salt. They just occurred to me, and not that I'm going to upgrade my Drum3P, but if they added a couple of new voices I might consider it.I'm not thinking of major hardware changes, but the addition of 2 new green LEDs and 2 new red LEDs for my two new voices and the addition of a 2nd Kick connector. Obviously there's the internals of two new voices as well. Is this an Analog or Digital synth? Never even looked into that...My thinking is that I've a kick drum pedal connected in to the Drum3P So I've two ways of playing the Kick drum. I can use my foot or I can use the drum pad on the Drum3P. That seems like a waste to me. Once the Kick Pedal is connected to the Drum3P I'm never hitting that drum pad for the kick. That pad is never used. So by adding the Kick pedal I'm now reduced to 5 drum pads. If another voice was added to the synth, which could only be activated by the Kick you'd have 7 voices, if you have a kick pedal, but only 6 if you're using the integrated drum pads only. And sure when we've got that far adding an extra 'kick' voice, 7 is a bit of an odd number so why not 8? So out of the box the Drum 3P be 6 voices but add extra kick pedals for two additional voices. All this functionality for the price of 4 LEDs and a Jack.Just a thought.

post_content: Hello everybody,I'm looking for how I can send a midi program change to my Nord Drum 3P.Actually, I've a got a Apple Macbook and Logic Pro.I manage to record notes from the Nord Drum 3P in Logic Pro with a midi interface.I manage to send notes from Logic Pro in the Nord Drum 3PI manage to send midi CC from Logic Pro to the Nord Drum 3P to change filter frequency, Filter resonance, etc...But, I would like that when I open a Logic Pro's project, it will send a midi message to ND3P in order to command it to select the good drum kit for this project.I have read the user Manuel, search in forum, etc... I have read that it be about CC 0 (Bank select MSB) and CC 32 (Bank select LSB).But any message form this CC seem to go to the nord drum 3P. It doesn't change the Drum Kit.My nord drum 3P midi setting :Lo : OnGL : 10PC : rCC : SrSE ndthank a lot for helpKarl

title: RE: Nord Drum 3P and program change with a DAW
post_content: Hi Karl,There's bank select and program change, two different things. You can select a bank using the 2 CC's, with program change you select a program within a bank. Program change messages are different from CC messages and notes. Maybe you can record a program change to see what it looks like in your DAW; on the Nord set PC (Program Change) to send and receive, that's 'Sr' I believe, then record MIDI on your DAW while going from one program to the next, then check what you see on your DAW..To select the right program at the beginning of a track, you'll need the 2 CC's to select the desired bank, then a program change.Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Nord Drum 3P and program change with a DAW
post_content: Hello,Here's what I did for those who might be interested and it worksThe procedure for ordering a change of sound bank of hardware synths when opening the project in the DAW:• Logic Pro• Nord Drum 3P• Hydrasynth Deluxe1 - For each midi track, create an event (by clicking on + "change prog.")2 - MSB/LSB value: from 0 to 127 (Sound bank number)3 - Program value from 0 to 127 (Sound number)ThanksKGCapture d’écran 2022-10-31 à 16.01.02.png (232.67 KiB) Viewed 7638 times

title: RE: Nord Drum is annoying to work with & have many questions
post_content: Hi Naughty Nord 4P, welcome to the forum!Naughty Nord 4P wrote:1.  I plug my Nord drum 3P midi in (Nord 3p) to midi out (Scarlet 18i20) and midi out (Nord 3p) to midi in (Scarlet 18i20).What is the proper routing for this to record audio AND MIDI!?????You connected it properly to record and play back MIDI. MIDI is digital information of the notes that are played; which notes, velocity, etc., no audio. If you want to record the audio, use audio cables to connect the L and R outputs of the 3p to audio inputs on your scarlet.Naughty Nord 4P wrote:2. When im able to get the Nord to record MIDI the piano roll hits are really far apart (vertically) that I have to scroll to find them all, its annoying.Check the MIDI notes for each drum channel in the MIDI menu, make sure that they are near each other; 60, 62, 64, 65, 67, 69. Or perhaps even 60, 61, 62, etc.Naughty Nord 4P wrote:3. I recently bought the Momo muller nord VST controller but I can not get this thing to literally control my entire Nord Drum 3P unit, im at my wits end. What settings do I need this on!?Check the MIDI menu, make sure CCs can be controlled by setting: CC.Sr or CC.r (r=receive)Naughty Nord 4P wrote:I wish they would have opted for knobs instead of buttons and menus!!I wouldn't call this a typical 'menu diving' synth though, I've seen worse, I also prefer one knob per function, but there are quite a lot of sound parameters per drum channel on the 3p. It's quite efficiently laid out, I bet you'll get the hang of it soonCheers,Albert

title: Trigger options for the Nord Drum 3P?
post_content: Still learning the 3P and excited at the prospects of using it both for recording and live.  I've decided that I won't likely want to hit the pads when playing live and would prefer to use a trigger on the Kick and one trigger for my snare and have the 3P sounds available for specific songs/sections.I've been trying to figure out the following:1. Which trigger devices (Roland, DDrum, etc) are compatible for what I'm trying to do?2. As there is only one 1/4" input (kick) - can that port be used to trigger any pad/channel?3. Do I need to use the MIDI input instead?4.  Given I'd like to have at least 2 triggers (one on kick drum and one on snare), how can that possibly be done?Any info and/or recommendations is appreciated.Thanks,Rob

title: RE: Trigger options for the Nord Drum 3P?
post_content: Hi Rob, welcome to the forum!Yes, you can only connect 1 pad/trigger to the 3p, it's hard wired to drum channel 1. I think they had an electronic bass drum pedal in mind, to play a bass drum sound. However, drum channel 1 can be programmed to any sound you like, and you can also use any brand of pad, drum trigger, or electronic bass drum pedal you prefer, just be aware that with multi zone pads it will only use the main one, and hihat pad setups won't work as intended.If the 3p itself doesn't fit in your setup, and you want to play more than 1 drum sound on the 3p, then indeed MIDI may be a solution, in theory... You'd have to find a device with a pad, or a drum 'brain' to which you can connect several pads, that has a MIDI out port, from which the (digital) MIDI messages can be sent to the 3p. Alesis makes some small units with 4 pads, the Roland SPD-One models have one pad and MIDI out. A drum brain may also be an option, they often also have a MIDI out port.Why don't you want to play on the 3p directly live?Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Stand Holder for 3p (& other models)
RE: Stand Holder for 3p (& other models)
post_content: The dimension you need for the stand holder are that the plate of the stand holder should have a distance between the holes (centre of hole to center of hole) should be80mmin the horizontal direction and50mmin the vertical direction.The part number indicated on the stand mount/holder/plate that I am using isA015G.Thi information should be documented in the manual. But it isnt. The manual has on page 16 a diagram of the stand holder with no indication of the dimensions of the thing, and no indication of the size of the screws that should be used in the hole. Apparently Nord thinks that proper and complete product documentation is something exotic.

title: RE: Stand Holder for 3p (& other models)
post_content: I think if the replacement part was easy to come by, you wouldn't need the dimensions in the manual. Perhaps it would have been easier if they'd chosen for the more common Roland's mounting plate design. Apparently some specialized spare parts stores sell them, you can also contact the Nord distributor in your country to check if they can provide you with a spare one.To summarize:- The Nord drum 3p, 2, 1, and Nord Pad all use the same 'stand holder',- The distance between the (centres of the) holes is:50mmand80mm,- The bolts have anM4thread, length is8mm,- The Roland/Alesis/Millenium mounting platecannotbe used to mount the Nord drum series units!- Nord website: Contact your Nord distributor for spare parts*The stand holder of the Nord Pad has some additional ribs/buttresses underneath (see belowj, not sure if they contibute much to the strength, the stand holder of the slightly heavier and larger 3p does not seem to have them.Cheers,Albert.

title: RE: Drum Kit list for 3P
post_content: Hi Oggi2,Not sure if it's common practice, not sure if it's even feasible to make such lists in case of the Nord drum(sj t.b.h. Listening to the sound demo's on the Nord website, I find it difficult to describe the kits, other than; 'synth drum kit', or sometimes perhaps: 'tuned synth percussion'. Some of the individual sounds within the kits may sound somewhat similar to vintage electronic drums, drumcomputers, acoustic drums, or percussion sounds, but it's a flexible synth, not a sampler. You can sculpt the sounds in infinite ways, and then combine a diversity of sounds into a kit. I'd therefore take any naming or labeling with a grain of salt, if they were to do the effort.I'd just go through the presets, pick anything you like, perhaps recombine some sounds into new kits, tweak the sounds to your likings, or just create completely new sounds and kits from scratch.Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Fix or replace ddrum4 SE tom pad transducer/trigger?
post_content: Hi @RhythmMachineSeems like two possibilities; 1) Wire connection to jack has failed. 2) Transducer has a detached wire. By removing the head you can clearly see the jack to check for a broken wire there, however the wire connections to the transducer cannot be seen as they are inside the foam and it looks as if it would require destroying the transducer to expose them.Although not a direct replacement, it looks like this replacementtransducerfrom the ddrum Elite series would work. You might need to adjust the rubber pad that the transducer is glued to in order to maintain the proper height.UPDATE: Also foundthiswhich appears to be a direct replacement or at least very close in form.Hope that helps a bit.Cheers!Ken

title: RE: PLAYING NORD 3P VIA OTHER E-DRUM
post_content: Hi Davidevil,Welcome to the forum!I think you may have switched on the Individual MIDI channels, and they are set to the MIDI channel that the TD9 sending on. If so, switch these off [Ch.Of] use the Global MIDI channel instead, adjust the MIDI notes to match the notes that the TD9 is sending..Hope this helps,Cheers,Albert

title: RE: PLAYING NORD 3P VIA OTHER E-DRUM
post_content: Hi Albert,Thanks for your reply. I have switched the Channels off and Global On on the Nord and the result is no sound come out from it. I think I need to change some settings on the TD-6, but its menu is not straightforward at all (at least for me).V

title: RE: PLAYING NORD 3P VIA OTHER E-DRUM
post_content: Hi,I checked the Roland website; by factory default, the Drum kit part of the TD-6 is on MIDI channel 10, so that's the same as the default Global MIDI channel of the 3p, (it doesn't have to be 10, but make sure they are both on the same channel..)Now match the notes:The default MIDI notes of the 3p are:60 for drum channel 1,62 for drum channel 2,64 for drum channel 3,65 for drum channel 4,67 for drum channel 5,69 for drum channel 6.I found this list for the Roland:https://www.vdrums.com/forum/general/pr ... -note-listMake sure to adjust the note numbers of the 3p to match the notes of the TD-6, or the other way around..So, either follow the manual of the 3p, or this one for the TD~6:https://rolandus.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/a ... o-the-PadsCheers,Albert

title: How to Rename/Convert Samples for Upload to Nord Drum 3p
post_content: Hey All,I'm trying to get my head around how to load my own samples on to the Nord Drum 3p using the Drum Manager. I've sussed out the basic part and have been able to upload kitbanks which was fairly straight forward. Howeverthis maybe the dumbest question but how do you go about converting WAV files to .nd3_kitbank for use on the Nord Drum? I'd really appreciate some help. Thanks

title: RE: How to Rename/Convert Samples for Upload to Nord Drum 3p
post_content: Nord Drum 3P does not support using samples in general (neither factory or user), as far as I know and I can read from its specs and manual, it is a Modeling Percussion Synthesizer with multiple synthesis engines (seehttps://www.nordkeyboards.com/products/nord-drum-3pSound Creation and Tone Section description) but no sample playback capability.

title: RE: How to Rename/Convert Samples for Upload to Nord Drum 3p
post_content: The Nord Drum 3P is a fully virtual-analogue digital synthesizer. You can create your own sounds, but need to put them together with the given waveforms & filters or resonant or FM synthesis. There's nothing to upload except what you created on the Drum 3P itself and downloaded before - or someone else.

title: RE: How to Rename/Convert Samples for Upload to Nord Drum 3p
post_content: Thanks for putting that to rest for me. I can now concentrate on synthesis

title: Auditioning Samples
post_content: Hey Guys,I'm new to the forum and recently acquired the Nord Drum 3p.I am playing in an electronic live band and we are about to start gigging. At times I would like to be able to modify sounds on the fly.Is there a way or are there any suggestions to be able to audition sounds through the headphones with out sound coming out of the mixing desk to the audience? Cheers

title: RE: Auditioning Samples
post_content: Hi Jimmi,Welcome to the forum!The headphones output is directly coupled to the main output, same routing and volume control, so it's not possible to audition something on headphones only. However, with a small mixer on stage you should be able to. I know that on Mackie mixers muted tracks are routed to the monitoring section, and when you're happy with the sound, you simply unmute the 3p on the mixer.Another simple solution: interrupt the audio path from the 3p to the main mixer/amp using a stereo line selector pedal, A/B switcher, or perhaps a stereo volume pedal.If you don't want to carry extra gear; in theory you could also use the 3p's channel panning. First, connect the L output to the main mixing desk/amp, and R to your personal monitor/headphones amp. Then, by hard panning a drum sound on the 3p, you can route it to either your headphones, or the main mixer.  However, in this way you'll in fact be using the 3p in mono. I don't think it's a very practical solution either; the panning is confusing, easily forgotten, and a bit slow. Perhaps a MIDI (foot) controller might be helpful here, but the idea was to not use any extra gear.. The only advantage of this method is perhaps that you could (potentially) audition each drum sound individually before adding it to the mix.I think a small mixer or a switching pedal are the simplest solutions in case you really need to audition kits during a gig. Personally I would only do some final tweaks during sound check and focus on playing during the gig. For jamming and experimenting perhaps consider a small MIDI controller with some knobs to control a couple of basic parameters such as channel level, (but be careful of MIDI parameter jumps)..Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Auditioning Samples
post_content: Thanks Albert,Extremely helpful information and clarification. I may invest in a Makie big knob or an A/B foot switch as you’ve suggested. Extra gear but not untypical for a drummer to be carting a heap of stuff around. The main thing I wanted to rule out was if I was missing anything on the Nord 3p. Hopefully an update might be able to add a shift function to turn down the output to the mains. We can but dream. Cheers

title: Nord Drum 3P output levels
post_content: I recently bought a Nord Drum 3P and using a dual 1/4 inch TS to dual RCA cable I plugged it into the AUX of my 120 watt home stereo. With everything turned up full the sound output was minimal. Is this a fault or a feature? Any ideas?

title: RE: Nord Drum 3P output levels
post_content: Hi furtwangler, welcome to the forum!I'd think one of the following:-the cable is bad-the main volume of the 3p, or the amp is turned down-the outputs of the 3p, or the inputs of the amp are broken (try a different sound source or amp)-the channel levels of the kit are low (try different kits)-the sensitivity settings of the pads are such that the 3p barely makes a sound when playing them (try the trigger button)-you've accidentally connected the outputs of the 3p tooutputsof your amp (yes, I've done this once by accident, and I did a hear faint sound coming from the speakers)And just to be sure: I think you shouldn't expect levels to match that of acoustic instruments, or instrument amps, it shouldn't be louder than playing a CD for example. You don't want to damage your home stereo amp, speakers, or ears!Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Nord Drum 3P output levels
post_content: Thanks for that. I metered the cable and it's fine,  Master level on 3P highest and volume on my stereo highest. Amp tested fine with another source. Tested with pad channel levels at 50. I no longer have the unit so cannot play around with pad sensitivity but that seems unlikely as all pads and kits delivered the same soft output. Definitely didn't connect to amp outputs. The only conclusions I can reach is that either the product was defective or there is an incompatibility with my home stereo amplifier and the 3P. Thanks again.

title: RE: Nord Drum 3P output levels
post_content: Hi,Good to know..Perhaps not very relevant now that you returned or sold it, but just in case anyone else has similar problems; I think it still could have been pad sensitivity because that is set for all 6 pads at the same time and applies to all programs/kits. The velocity of the trigger button is constant and high (100), and you can even raise that to the maximum (127), so it would have been an option to test the audio using the trigger button.I agree, it also could have been a defective unit.Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Nord Drum 3P output levels

title: RE: Nord Drum 2 Vs Nord Drum 3P Pads
post_content: ^Thank you, Albert. Yes, I tried to optimize all possible settings, a whole bunch of different sticks, etc. I loved the sounds, but I couldn't get any pleasure out of actually striking that surface. It's been years, but I remember it being a bit laborious setting up (copying, etc.) the ideal set of sounds that I liked across the 6 pads too.So I got into alternative controllers, like the Linnstrument, Roli Seaboard, etc., to add a bit of fun to my guitar playing. Yeah, I took out the ND2, after years and years (!) and the action is not quite as hard as I'd imagined. I think that the unfamiliarity of my arms striking something in that drumming motion has a lot to do with it. I'd imagine that drummers have tremendous control and nuance along that axis. For a guitar player, the picking arm action is peculiar and very different. Also, the left arm is totally unaccustomed to that kind of striking motion. So I just have to learn how to do that better. I remember taking a set of drumsticks when I was out walking, but the left arm was really uncoordinated and I gave up and got a(nother) saxophone. The body itches to move... no matter what!

title: RE: Controlling Midi CC globally
post_content: Hi Matlamar,As you say; when sending CCs on the Global MIDI channel, you have to choose which drum channel you want to control with the channel selection buttons. If I'm not mistaken CC 70 actually controls the channel selection, so perhaps you could use that to switch the focus in the course of the track. I agree that would be quite limiting still..So, if your DAW doesn't allow to set the output MIDI channel per CC controller within the same track (I doubt if there is any DAW that is that flexible) then indeed you'll have to create a separate MIDI track for each drum sound you want to control. That makes 7 tracks in total, I agree, not ideal..However, perhaps you can use a MIDI processing tool/plugin to transform CC messages coming from your main drum track and distribute them to different drum channels. You'd start by picking your own CC numbers to use in the drum track, and with the tool/plugin transform them to the desired CC numbers and send them to the desired Individual MIDI channels of the 3p. For example: convert CC1 messages from MIDI channel 10 (drum track) to CC7 (controls channel level) on MIDI channel 1, convert CC2 on MIDI channel 10 to CC7 on MIDI channel 2, etc. etc.In this way CC1 in your drum track will control channel level of drum channel 1 of your 3p, CC2 will control channel level of drum channel 2, etc. You'll have to make a selection of parameters that you want to control, because there are only 128 CCs available in MIDI, and in this setup you're potentially using 6 CCs for each parameter that you want to control... Possibly quite a bit of work to map and configure everything, but I think it is possible..Hope this helps,Albert

title: RE: Controlling Midi CC globally
post_content: Great Thank you for your answer, that’s helpful:)

title: RE: Sequencing Issues with Nord Drum 3p
post_content: Hi Matlamar, welcome to the forum!A couple of thoughts/ideas:1) make sure there is no mute group active in the program of the 3p that you're using, but if you are indeed able to trigger the drum sounds at the same time on the unit itself, then this isn't the problem2) I'd suggest to switch off the individual MIDI channel option for all 6 drum sounds on the 3p, this functionality may complicate things when trying to 'debug' the problem. So go through all 6 drum channels with the channel selection buttons, and make sure 'Ch OF' is selected in the MIDI menu for all 6 drum channels.3) Make sure you program the drum pattern on a single MIDI track (one that uses the Global MIDI channel of the 3p as output MIDI channel) using the MIDI notes that are set in the MIDI menu of the 3p. Tip: You can record some notes on the MIDI track by playing the pads of the 3p, to see if you're using the correct MIDI notes to program the pattern with..4) It might also be your USB-MIDI interface that is causing the problem, what MIDI interface are you using to connect your 3p to your computer?Hope this helps,Cheers,Albert

The same behavior was happening with the north drum so I am thinking the issue is the usb-midi interface. It is just a cable with usb one side and midi in-out on the other. I own a MIDI interface that looks like a cable but of a reputable brand, it costed me 20 or 30 euros at the time, and still works just fine, so the size itself doesn't matter.. Ask a music store for a small good quality USB-MIDI interface that they know work, or check the forum here as well for some suggestions.I found old threads where people mention successfully using smaller E-MU, ESI, Roland, iRig interfaces, not sure about current availability, and perhaps check recent user reviews using the same platform (mac/Windows OS version).ESI midimate eX,E-Mu Xmidi 1x1,IK multimedia iRig MIDI 2,Roland UM One mk2Cheers,Albert

It generated, all on channel 10:ON D1 Velocity 126ON C-2 Velocity 4ON E3 Velocity 16ON E-3 Velocity 38OFF E-2 Velocity 64Given that the pad (and nt) were both set to 38, I have no idea how it generated those notes, and no idea why, within an absolute fraction of a second, it generated 4 ONs before an OFF.Hitting it again generated 3 note off signals, one of E-1, one F#8, one E-2. title: RE: Having some MIDI issues, unreliable output
post_content: Hi Zevulpn45, welcome to the forum!That sounds confusing indeed!- It seems that multiple pads are triggered when you're hitting a single pad, to overcome this, raise the threshold setting for the pads. Hitting the pads right in the center also helps to prevent this, maybe tilt the unit a bit more if that makes it easier.EDIT:- I had another look at your post, in your description I count 7 different MIDI notes after 2 consecutive strokes on your 3p, unless you changed MIDI settings in the mean time, I'd expect only 6 different MIDI notes from your 3p at max, and I don't understand the Off message(s). Therefore I was wondering if your MIDI interface could be the culprit, what MIDI interface are you using?And just some general MIDI related explanation & suggestions:- The note number in the MIDI menu (nt) determines the MIDI note that the pad will output via MIDI, the pitch sound parameter only determines the pitch of the drum sound on the 3p audio output, it's important to choose a different MIDI note in the MIDI menu for each of the 6 pads..- You don't need the 'individual' MIDI channels (Ch) in this setup, you only use this functionality when you want to control the 3p's sound parameters, I think it's good practice to switch this OFF when not in use - so: set parameter Ch to value 'OF' for all 6 drum channels (pads) one by one. You could also disconnect the cable from your interface to the MIDI in of the 3p if you hadn't already. It's just to keep things as simple and tidy as possible, but I don't think it should make a difference in your current setup.Hope it helps,Cheers,Albert

post_content: OK, that led shows that the interface is "ON", fine but then the green and yellow leds should blink when data is being transmitted either way; consider that some of those cheap MIDI USB cables have trouble handling Sysex or in general Hi-speed (dense) MIDI data, this could be another factor.To understand if that's the case, have you tried to see (using a MIDI Monitor utility such as Snoize's MidiMonitor) if you can at least send Notes from the 3P to the Mac (btw: what Global MIDI channel you have set in the 3P MIDI menu?) when you play the N3P pads?PS: have you already tried to select the second OUT port instead, just in case...?In any case, getting a better/branded MIDI USB interface is something I would definitely recommend.

title: RE: What MIDI interface (Nord 3P to iMac)
post_content: Hi,Yes, I meant the indicator in the Manager application itself,In your screenshot it's red, 'Disconnected', which indeed means the Manager doesn't see the 3P,You checked if the MIDI interface was connected the wrong way around by swapping the cables, perhaps a port is misconfigured (2 outs in stead of an in and an out), selecting the same port for in and out as in your screenshot doesn't seem right. title: Nord 3P creating random ghost notes during performance ???
post_content: Hello all,First time poster here.Writing with a weird issue I've been having.We are rehearsing for an upcoming gig, and our drummer is using a Nord 3P.*RANDOMLY,* during rehearsal of a song, the 3P will go completely wild and start rapid fire triggering hits from the pad, which ceases when we all stop playing.After some theorizing & experimentation, Ithinkwhat may be happening is that loud bass frequencies are making the practice space floor vibrate, which is then vibrating the 3P's stand, which is then triggering notes as if they were hit by the drummer.I had the idea to reduce the touch sensitivity, but even when we had that at 0 we were still getting this issue.Anyone else have this issue? Any suggestions??? One (ridiculous) thing we tried was putting the stand on top of some foam, to cut down on possible vibration, but I personally feel like...we shouldn't have to do this?Our drummer also told us that she had this issue at a venue before, so we are trying to avoid having this happen at the upcoming show.Thanks so much in advance for your time!

title: RE: Nord 3P creating random ghost notes during performance ???
post_content: Hi ambymoho, welcome to the forum!I had something similar in a hybrid drum setup, and I once also experienced unexpected triggering from electromagnetic interference. Given your story, it's most likely triggered by sound, vibrations in the room or floor. What happens if you tap against the stand, or stamp on the floor?There are a couple of setting on the 3p that have to do with the response: pad mode, dynamic response curve, threshold, and sensitivity (see page 12 and 13 of the manual). You want toraise the thresholdto reduce unintended triggering of the pads. If it becomes unplayable, try other solutions...It could very well be the bass amp, but also acoustic drums or cymbals, which are perhaps closer to the 3p. Make sure the stand does not touch other stands or drums. You can also try changing relative positions/distances of gear on stage. If it is the bass amp, try raising it if it's standing directly on the floor. Reduce low frequencies, reduce amp volumes, play less loud.If the foam did reduce the unwanted triggering, perhaps check if there are other stands with thicker/softer rubber feet, a drum carpet/mat or riser maybe. Be careful with diy solutions, you don't want the stand to topple over!Best of luck!Cheers,Albert

title: Nord Drum 3P quieter via midi then via pads
post_content: I have my Nord Drum 3P set up to play into my Daw.I record a kick via midi. I can see that velocity data is being recorded, so there are dynamics, but triggering the 3p via midi is always quieter then when I play it directly.For example, if I record a kick into a midi channel, and I want to do some overdubbing into audio with midi and me both triggering the 3P.Then record audio, with me adding more kicks on top of what the midi track is also triggering, there is a huge difference in volume between kicks triggered via pads and kicks triggered via midi.I don't think I have ever owned a piece of gear with this issue.Usually whatever midi you play into your daw, recreates exactly what you played.Any ideas?

title: RE: Nord Drum 3P quieter via midi then via pads
post_content: I confirmed that my Daw is capturing pressure, pitch bend and all those CC's which 'maybe' the Nord Drum uses?But still a midi triggered sound at 127 velocity is 4db quieter then hitting the pad full on - I can see this by recording the output into Logic.I assume the note length has no effect on the volume.What could be causing this - it is quite annoying!

title: RE: Nord Drum 3P quieter via midi then via pads
post_content: I don't have a digital Drum, so no experience from that side. But I see two different issues:a) If you play the Drum 3P directly or through another sound generator via MIDI, of course the two sound generators (built-in Nord, external) may have different volumes. So if you play a velocity of 127 on both, that may be different in volume;b) if you play a middle velocity value, that may differ even if full velocity is the same on both sound generators, as the velocity curve may not be the same. That's what we always encounter on Nord keyboards - even if Nord approached the velocity curve to a standard curve recently. If you have to deal with that, you may connect a MIDI velocity converter in between. Or have a look into your DAW if you can convert velocity values inside.

title: RE: Nord Drum 3P quieter via midi then via pads
post_content: I figured out the issue through some good old fashioned trial and error.I set the Nord to Local Off, and made sure my Daw looped back that data, so now all hits are from external midi, because my live playing is just looped back midi. This made it so that my live playing was of equal volume to my recorded midi tracks (kick etc.). It was all 4db quieter, but at least consistent.I hate having Local Off because now the entire front panel only responds to midi. You can't even change drum kits!From here you could set the ND to send Program change, and make sure your Daw loops that back, but I never have my hardware send program changes because depending on what you have focussed in Logic, changing a patch on your hardware synth can swap out a plug-in or cause other mayhem. It's just not good for my workflow.So I set Local back on, and made sure my Daw wasn't looping back midi data, which is when I realizedit had been doing that previously. The Nord doesn't have a 'through' capability. So if you have your Daw looping back midi data you won't get the usual midi-loop madness other gear exhibits. But with Local ON, what you do get is double triggered sounds! With most gear this would be a noticeable flam, but the latency on the ND must be phenomenal, because it wasn't flams, it was just louder. This explains how full velocity from live vs recorded midi could be different in volume, the live playing always had double triggered notes, doubled by a hair.So now I have Local ON and can switch kits to audition different sounds quicker, and I have my Daw never looping back incoming midi, so only the recorded tracks come back to the ND. This works. This is fine.I will leave this post here for when in five years I forget all this and my google search turns up my own solution

title: 3P App and Sync Problems

title: RE: 3P App and Sync Problems
post_content: Hi Judy,Not sure how you connected everything.The Thru port on your iRig outputs (copies) whatever MIDI signal is connected to the IN port. If the Beat app is generating the MIDI clock, and you connected the iRig as a MIDI interface to your iPad, the clock will only be coming from the Out port of the iRig.In order to distribute the clock signal to multiple instruments, you will need a second output on your iRig, or a MIDI thru box..Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Need to replace POWER SUPPLY (European) for Nord Drum 3P
post_content: According to the text on the front panel (checked an image from Thomann), it operates on 12V DC, and consumes 500mA max, centre pin positive. Any power supply with the right size connector, correct voltage, correct pin polarity, and at least 500mA output should work.EDIT: I'm not a Nord technician, all the basic precautions apply. But I have a decent understanding of electronics and a power supply that fills these requirements has always resulted in a working device for me.

title: RE: Need to replace POWER SUPPLY (European) for Nord Drum 3P
