title: Nord drum 3 with Volca Kick
post_content: So I am trying to trigger a volca kick to layer with the nord drum. The only way i can get it to trigger is if the nord is on global 1 with the volca on the same number. But I only want it to trigger with pad 1 and its triggering with every pad instead. I tried just putting pad one on midi channel 1 and every other pad off and global off but then it wont trigger. Is it possible to trigger the volca kick with just the kick pad 1 on the nord pad 3?

title: RE: Nord drum 3 with Volca Kick
post_content: Hi Junglsmor,The 3p only sends MIDI notes on the Global MIDI channel, not on the Individual MIDI channels, which can only be used to control the 3p sound parameters. The notes that are sent can be set per drum channel in the MIDI settings. The trick would be to only use notes on drum channel 2-5 that will not trigger a sound on the Volca. If the Volca responds to all incoming note numbers, it's not going to work without additional MIDI filtering.Albert

title: RE: Nord drum 3 with Volca Kick
post_content: Wow. I don’t understand why they wouldn’t allow different pads to send to different midi channles. It sounds really good when layered with other stuff. Could there be a software update to allow that? Do you know of any other solutions? You mentioned midi filtering. How would I achieve that?

title: RE: Nord drum 3 with Volca Kick
post_content: Hi,The best companions for layering with the 3p are probably samplers and other sound modules where you can map single samples or sounds to individual MIDI notes. There is a work-around for your setup though. Any app, DAW plugin or hardware MIDI processor that can filter out notes or create a 'keyboard split' can be used to pass only the MIDI note from one drum channel to your Volca Kick.I was able to set up a filter with iOS app 'Midiflow', so that it only let through note C3, all other notes were ignored. If you happen to have an iOS device and a USB-MIDI interface, ..The Digital Music Corp MX-8 that Pablo mentioned in another thread here on the forum, is able to setup 'keyboard splits'; ranges of notes can be routed to different MIDI channels. The MX-8 is no longer produced, perhaps to be found on e-bay.The 'MIDI Platform' by Future Artists will be able to do it, but it may take a while before they will start selling them..The MIDI Solutions Event Processor (/Plus) is perhaps able to do it but it's not compatible with Nord keyboards and probably not with drums either.Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Midi connecting problem
post_content: An often made mistake is MIDI OUT (cable) to MIDI OUT on Drum.The MIDI IN cable goes in the MIDI OUT of the Nord Drum and the MIDI OUT cable goes to the MIDI IN of the Nord drum.Check that first. Otherwise: I don't have a clue (since I don't own one).GrBart

title: RE: Midi connecting problem
post_content: Berretje wrote:The MIDI IN cable goes in the MIDI OUT of the Nord Drum and the MIDI OUT cable goes to the MIDI IN of the Nord drum.That, and indeed make sure to connect both IN and OUT. The software expects an answer from the 3p.Cheers,Albert

title: how to change midi note for pads 3p ?
post_content: i want to  use ableton drum rack with my nord 3p.how to setting each pad for what midi note i want?thanks!

title: RE: how to change midi note for pads 3p ?
post_content: Hi p3p3p3,Go to the MIDI settings: press shift + MIDI repeatedly until you see 'nt' in the display, you'll find the MIDI note number of the selected channel right of it. Use the channel selection buttons to check the note numbers for each of the 6 drum channels, and, if required, edit the note number with the knob.see manual page 12: "nt - MIDI Note: each of the six Channels can be assigned to respond to an incoming* MIDI note. When the Nord drum 3P is shipped from the factory, Channels 1 to 6 are assigned to MIDI note numbers: 60, 62, 64, 65, 67 and 69.Range: n.0 - 127"-note 60 corresponds with C3 or C4 depending if your software uses the Yamaha or Roland standard..-the note numbers are set globally, so not per program*and sentAlbert

title: RE: help! connecting nord drum 3p midi to computer

I don't have a Mac, no experience with Ableton, so I cannot help you.Just some general tips/remarks:-Your USB-MIDI interface ('cable') is a MIDI device, I think in Ableton you should be able to select it and use the same MIDI channel as in the app, so that's probably MIDI channel 10 if you didn't change anything on the 3p.-The 3p (only) outputs the 6 notes as set in the MIDI settings, so if you want to control sounds or trigger other stuff by playing the pads, check the note numbers that Ableton receives, couple them to whatever you want to trigger.-If you want to use the 3p as sound module, send the mentioned notenumbers on MIDI channel 10Hope this helps,Albert

title: RE: Trigger Nord Drum 3P via MIDI with additional pads?
post_content: Hi,Yes it is possible to control the 6 drum sounds ('channels') on the Nord Drum 3p with MIDIThe 6 channels are completely independent from each other, but each channel is monophonic.you can trigger the 6 drum sounds with both MIDI and the pads , but if you hit the pad exactly at the same time as a MIDI note is received for the same drum sound, you won't hear the sound twiceAlbert

They can be "additional" sounds to the ones I am alreadyusing on the 6 pads, right? ( I hope.)2 additional "crash cymbal" sounds that can be hit in sync with the kickdrum sound, for example.And will an incoming trigger signal cut off a long reverb or delay "tail" that has been playing on theidentical channel? Or would it just replace the actual sound but not the effect tail.Just trying to max out the possibilities when using the ND3P live as a super minimalistic stand alonedrum kit.Cheers,Falko

title: RE: Trigger Nord Drum 3P via MIDI with additional pads?
post_content: Hi,Falkom wrote:Can those notes that are coming in triggered by MIDI differ from thoseassigned to the 6 pads. They can be "additional" sounds to the ones I am alreadyusing on the 6 pads, right? ( I hope.)No, if you are using a drum set with for example: bassdrum, snare, hi-hat, and 3 toms, you can't play other sounds with MIDI than these (eg add crash sounds). However, with the right MIDI settings you can play the same sounds with a different pitch, which in this example might be interesting for the tom sounds. With a kit composed of: bassdrum, snare, hi-hat, one tom, and 2 crashes, you would still be able to play multiple tom pitches.If you program a simple snare + bassdrum loop with the Nord Beat app, you can still play the kit yourself, even add extra snare or bassdrum notes in between the notes that are triggered with the app.Falkom wrote:And will an incoming trigger signal cut off a long reverb or delay "tail" that has been playing on theidentical channel? Or would it just replace the actual sound but not the effect tail.Not sure, I think the reverb is an effect that behaves just like an external reverb (but dry/wet can be set per channel) so I don't think the reverb tail is cut by new notes. The delay might be different, I only know that the delay on the Nord drum2 was similar to a MIDI delay, not sure how it works on the Nord drum3p.Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Trigger Nord Drum 3P via MIDI with additional pads?
post_content: Hi,The first step is to setup an individual MIDI channel for the drum channel with the tom sound (if the Global MIDI channel = 10, pick any except MIDI channel 10), any note sent on that MIDI channel will then trigger the tom sound and the note number will determine the pitch.Albert

title: RE: Trigger Nord Drum 3P via MIDI with additional pads?
post_content: wartaler wrote:Hi,The first step is to setup an individual MIDI channel for the drum channel with the tom sound (if the Global MIDI channel = 10, pick any except MIDI channel 10), any note sent on that MIDI channel will then trigger the tom sound and the note number will determine the pitch.AlbertThanks Albert!That's great! It is actually explained in the manual, but for some reason I just skipped over the MIDI chapter without paying attention...The way I see this, it opens up a lot of possibilities, not just the extra toms. Some additional ideas:1) Have a simple step sequencer, e.g. Beatstep or SQ-1 play a melodic sequence using a tuned percussion sound on one channel of the 3P. Play on top of the sequence on the remaining five pads.2) With a more capable sequencer, e.g. Beatstep Pro, play two different melodic sequences simultaneously or alternately, using two different tuned percussion sounds on two different channels of the 3P. The sequencer can then simultaneously play a drum track on the remaining four channels of the 3P.3) Set up the 3P together with a controller keyboard, five channels for playing drums, and the last channel for playing a tuned percussion sound chromatically with the keyboard. Many cheap controller keyboards even have a simple arpeggiator built in, so that could be used to lay down a simple melodic sequence or drum track, depending on the setup....etc.!

title: RE: Looping Nord drum 3p
post_content: Hi sepetov,The Nord Beat app is a step sequencer, so you can program a drum pattern and loop it. With the app you can't record MIDI notes that you play on your 3p live, but a pattern is setup in no time, and adapted quickly.. The disadvantage of a MIDI solution may be that it triggers notes on the Nord Drum, leaving perhaps a little less room (polyphony) for live playing the Nord Drum yourself on top of the loop, depending how many notes and channels you use for the loop/pattern. There is no sound degradation though as each note is produced by the Nord Drum itself. The other advantage is that the loop will be very accurate, no timing errors.With a looping pedal you can record audio from your 3p, and then loop it, you can start and stop recording, and in this way determine the length of the loop, all with your foot. The disadvantage is that it may require some skill to make a good and working loop without timing errors. The advantage is that you can layer and go beyond the polyphony /the 6 voices of the Nord Drum, and you are fully free to play any notes on top of the loop. I don't know the audio quality of these pedals though.Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Stompbox Nord Drum trigger
post_content: Hi sadczaaa,The honest answer is that I don't know. A piezo can produce high voltages for a very brief time, I don't know the voltages a drum pad normally outputs. It is possible to trigger the ND with a Beatstep Pro (BSP) which 'only' outputs 3V. The shape and duration of the signal also matters; a long pulse or 'gate trigger' from the BSP triggers the ND twice: at the start and again at the end of the pulse. To prevent this double triggering they use the shortest pulse possible on the BSP (not sure how short this is) or envelope generators to create a spike like signal.Some links to threads in MuffWiggler that may help:https://www.muffwiggler.com/forum/viewt ... highlight=https://www.muffwiggler.com/forum/viewt ... sc&start=0Hope this helps,Albert

title: Nord pad (ND2) setup
post_content: HiChecked the manual about setting up Nord Pad for ND2. I don't get how to get the pad setting right.I use it as a "hand trigger" setting, but I don't get any sound or midi when hitting the pads. The Cat cable is connected. I get sound and midi when using the "Trig/Tap" button on ND2.According to the menu I should change the setting with Shift + Inp Thres and Inp Sens are the trick.Any recommended settings here?Thanks!

title: RE: Nord pad (ND2) setup
post_content: Hi Eric, welcome to the forum!Lowering the threshold and raising the sensitivity normally helps. If the threshold is too high, it won't respond to your hands tapping the pads. Therefore I would just start by lowering the threshold quite a bit and raising the sensitivity.Then check the cable: it should be easier to trigger the Nord drum with a stick than with your hands, do the channel lights light up when you hit the pads with a stick? If not, perhaps the cable is bad or unsuitable, or one of the ports is dirty or broken (which I doubt), inspect the ports, try another Cat6 cable..If you do see the lights blinking I would expect the ND2 to output MIDI notes, did you check this with MIDI monitor software? If you don't hear anything when you do see the lights blinking, it could be that Local is off in the MIDI settings, turn Local On.Optimizing the sensitivity, threshold and dynamics response curve setting to your playing style may take some time, I find the manual quite helpful on pages 25 and 26. Just one remark: you may experience spontaneous triggering with too low threshold settings, and cross talk between pads with too high sensitivity settings. It's also worthwhile to experiment with the various dynamic response curves, some will make it easier to reach higher velocities, others quite the opposite.Hope this helps,Albert

title: RE: Any way to get the Nord Drum 3p to....
post_content: Digital Music Corp MX-8 can do this.In the "heyday" of midi there were many creative people making many useful devices, and the MX-8 was one of the best.  Among many other things, it has an available  midi "compander" feature via which velocity ranges can be manipulated; it includes a level setting.  Just set it to 127 and you're good.Everybody and anybody doing stuff with midi should want at least one MX-8 in their rig.  They are AMAZING and solid as a tank coming up on 30 years old.  For a time they could be had all day on ebay for $50, but people in the know apparently have started grabbing them judging by current ebay pricingbless, pablo

post_content: Hi Jungismor,That depends upon the pedal. title: need help deciding on nd2 or nd3
post_content: Hi,I noticed the differences in adjustable paramaters (or at least in name-giving) by looking at images of the ND2 and ND3p module. I really want to buy one of them and actually found a nice ND2. But after doing about 2 hours of research im not satisfied with the information collected. I'm looking for the Nord Drum with the broader synthesis engine.This ease of editing is further enhanced by the ‘Pad Follow’ option, which is enabled by pressing both of the Ch Select buttons together. With this option, whichever pad you hit becomes the pad you are currently editing. A feature like this becomes a lot more relevant now that the pads are integrated. With the Nord Drum 2, you had to make sure you had manually selected the correct channel before editing.The Nord Drum 3P adds two T-Bridge oscillators and two ring mod oscillators to the previously available palette....we lose the Attack Rate and Attack Mode parameters,...The Click element previously offered 36 different click options. This is now reduced to 12, [for the ND3p]The Nord Drum 2 introduced effects in the form of distortion, EQ and a basic Echo/Repeat feature. The 3P expands upon these with the addition of reverb and an enhanced delay effect, which is now a true audio-based delay rather than the ‘MIDI repeat’ function of the Nord Drum 2.But:https://www.gearslutz.com/board/electro ... esign.htmlPlease feel free to school me on the differences between the two machines!ND2:ND3:

title: RE: need help deciding on nd2 or nd3
post_content: Hi Hello, welcome to the forum!I personally prefer the ND2, because I don't care that much for the reverb per channel they added, I think I'd miss some other parameters they removed. They may have added a couple of waveforms to the 3p. Check the comparison chart on the website :https://www.nordkeyboards.com/products/ ... ison-chartThey are both very nice sounding drum synths!The image of the ND3 desktop version that you posted was of a prototype that was never taken into production, only the 'Nord drum 3p', which has the pads built in, but is quite a bit bigger. You can connect the Nord Pad to the ND2 or 6 drum pads of any brand you choose.This is what the 3p looks like:https://www.nordkeyboards.com/products/nord-drum-3pCheers,Albert

title: RE: need help deciding on nd2 or nd3
post_content: ThanksI used the nd3 as a visual reference because you have a clearer image of the parameters.Also I read that the nd3p has 2 more synthesizer types, correct me if im wrong.

title: RE: need help deciding on nd2 or nd3
post_content: Hi,You're right, the word 'waveforms' is inaccurate, the ND2 and 3p have a couple of synthesis models to choose from:3p:    6 Analog style, 2 T-Bridge, 4 FM, 6 Harmonic, 7 drum head, 4 tuned percussion, 3 cymbal type, 2 ring modND2: 6 Analog style, 1 T-Bridge, 6 FM, 7 Harmonic, 9 drum head, 4 tuned percussion, 3 cymbal type, 2 ring modI'm quite surprised to see that the ND2 actually has more synthesis models, only one less 'T-Bridge' model. I'm not sure if these numbers actually say anything about the potential of the synths.The ND2 has moreClick, Tone and Noise parameters, so slightly more options to sculpt the sound with. The Attack of the Noise section of the ND2 for example allows you to create a clap sound similar to that of famous roland drum machines of the past. You could download both manuals from the Nord website to compare the sound parameters in detail, I think both are great sounding drum synths.About the noise issue with the 3p; there was an OS update to fix a noise issue, according to some the reverb still causes some form of unwanted noise, check this thread:nord-drum-forum-f27/nord-drum-3p-is-ver ... 12780.htmlAlbert

title: RE: nord drum 3p as sound module
post_content: There is a free Nord Drum sequencer app for Apple Ipad that does just that, but any sequencer will work. Just use a midi cable and "midi out" from your preferred DAW/sequencer/computer to the "midi in" of the Nord Drum then use the piano roll to draw in your steps (set up your midi channel in the Daw first). I personally use it with an Akai MPC and it works perfectly. Yes, there are six midi channels each corresponding to a pad or you can use channel 10 which is a global channel and allows you to program all six pads on one channel. Hope that helps.

title: RE: nord drum 3p as sound module
post_content: Hi drongoloid,You can use the global MIDI channel to trigger sounds on your 3p by sending the MIDI notes as set in the MIDI settings on the 3p. The default factory settings are:  Global MIDI channel = 10, MIDI note 60 (central C) is coupled to channel1 (I do not mean MIDI channel1, but the sound or pad on the 3p), note 62 is coupled to channel2, note 64 to 3, note 65 to 4, note 67 to 5, note 69 to 6. That’s 6 white keys of a keyboard, C3 and up (or C4 depending on if you’re on the Roland or Yamaha standard). On the 3p these notes can be set in the MIDI settings, looks something like this: [n.60]. So if there is a bass drum sound on channel1, and you send a central C on MIDI channel 10, you will hear a bass drum. Make a drum pattern using these 6 notes. If you send any other notes to the 3p, nothing will happen, no sound. The pitch of the sounds will exactly be as you programmed them, and as can be heard when playing the pads themselves.The individual MIDI channels can be used to control all sound parameters with MIDI CC messages, if you send MIDI notes on an individual MIDI channel, the MIDI note number will here control the pitch of the Tone section. In that way you can play melodies using one channel, handy for tuned percussion sounds eg marimba, only with one channel! Sending note 60 will result in the original pitch (of the Tone sectionj, notes above or below will result in a higher or lower pitch. Remember that each channel of the 3p is monophonic. To avoid problems, never use the MIDI channel that is already used as global MIDI channel. For example if the global MIDI channel = 10 [GL.10] use MIDI channel1 through 6 for the individual MIDI channels: [Ch. 1], [Ch. 2] etcHope this helps..Albert

title: RE: nord drum 3p as sound module
post_content: thank you very much for this comprehensive answer.  It works!

title: RE: nord drum 3p as sound module
post_content: Hello Folks,Just received my new 3P today and I'm really enjoying it.I have found a strange behaviour though and I wonder if anyone might be able to help out.I'm using the ND3P as a tone module and have it connected to my hardware sequencer, my Global channel is set to 10 as is my sequencer so I can play all 6 parts (internal ch) from my Sequencer also set to channel 10 on note numbers. All the individual parts MIDI channels are set to off so I'm exclusively using the drums on channel 10. I have a mapping in my hardware sequencer (I'm using an SL MKIII from Novation) for the Nord drum again this is set to MIDI channel 10 so I can automate and control the sound engine with the mapping and change sounds to edit them with ch select switches this is all working fine. However......I'm finding that all CC messages regardless of MIDI channel are controlling the ND3P's first part (maybe I should call it drum 1 from now on.... basically the one that is usually a kick in the kits). Again this is even after making sure that drum 1 has it's own MIDI channel set to off.It's basically like there is a bleed through of MIDI CC data onto drum 1 regardless of the MIDI channel I'm using.Eg i set global MIDI channel to 10 and individual MIDI channels for all 6 drums to off, then move a CC on say MIDI channel 1 or 2.... or indeed any channel and it affects the 1st drum part.I would have expected that CC sent only on MIDI channlel 10 would affect drum 1 when set up this way.Is this usual behaviour? it certainly seems a bit strange. The other drums behave as I would expect, ie they only react when selected and CC's are sent on MID Channel 10 so this problem seems only to be on the first drum part.I hope my description makes sense and thanks in advance of any help that might be around.-CALC-

title: RE: nord drum 3p as sound module
post_content: Hi CALC!Sending CC messages on the Global MIDI channel will control sound parameters of the channel (drum sound) which is in focus, you can change the focus with the channel select buttons.If a MIDI channel is not used as Individual or Global MIDI channel, the 3p should not respond to these CC messages, very strange! If it happens again, perhaps you can feed the MIDI that is sent from the sequencer to a computer or tablet with MIDI monitoring software to see what is actually sent to the 3p.Albert

title: RE: Kick Trigger for Nord Drum 3P
post_content: hi benstavanger,That must be Yamaha or Roland kick pedals, I never tested the difference between these settings on my ND2 (which has 6 trigger inputs and similar options), I guess Roland and Yamaha pads differ in dynamics/response curve and these settings help you to get better results with pads (or in this case kick pedals) of these 2 big e-drum brands.This is what the ND2 manual says about Trig Type: "The different Trig Types that allows you to match the response of the Nord Drum 2 to the output from a pad or a drum trigger. The trigger output from different types of pads and manufacturers varies a lot. The setting of the Trig Type parameter should be matched to suit the output from the pads or triggers you use. If you have Roland pads, try the Ro setting, if you have Yamaha pads, try the Ya setting."cheers,Albert

title: RE: Kick Trigger for Nord Drum 3P
post_content: Hi!Frustrating indeed!-Did you also try lowering the threshold?-Linear dynamics (dy) settings 01 or 02 compress trigger signals, further boost lower velocity triggers on the inputI've read the beatstep pro has 10 Volts on the drum gate outputs and that is enough to trigger the Nord Drum2 trigger inputs. The duration of this signal should be very short, otherwise it will cause double triggering.Cheers,Albert

title: RE: nord 3p midi/daw
post_content: Hi VincentAnthony,I'm afraid I can't help you with Garageband for Mac, I have the iOS version (and that user interface really drives me nuts, but that is just personal). You have to create a MIDI track, not an audiotrack, but how to do that and how it's called in Garageband I don't know. However, I looked on the internet if it is possible to send MIDI from Garageband back to external instruments (in your case the 3p), apparently it isnot. So you can record MIDI from an external keyboard or drum pad onto a MIDI track, but only to play sounds from Garageband itself..So the best advice I can give you is to search for Garageband forums or tutorials on the internet to double check, because perhaps I'm wrong.. Or look for another MIDI sequencer / DAW for your Mac. Perhaps someone else here can help you with that, I'd suggest Logic, but that might be a bit expensive...I can help you with the MIDI settings of the 3p.. for most common uses you shouldnotturn the Global MIDI channel off, so [GL.10] is ok, leave it like that. Use MIDI channel 10 as your MIDI track output channel. In most cases you won't need the Individual MIDI channels, best to switch them off [Ch.OF].. (or at least pick different MIDI channels than the Global, and also choose unique MIDI channels, so all different from each other, but I would leave them off for now).Cheers,Albert

title: RE: nord 3p midi/daw
post_content: VincentAnthony wrote:if you could answer on the video that I saw, the person created the midi track and then just went under the preferences under the track and changed it to channel 10 and was able to get the sounds to come though the nord.This is how it is usually done in the DAWs that I know:-Connect the MIDI interface to your computer and both the MIDI in and out to the MIDI out and in of the 3p.-Create a MIDI track, select the MIDI interface for it and set the output MIDI channel. Usually the input MIDI channel does not have to be set, it will record any MIDI channel on the input.-Click on the record button and hit some pads of the 3p, the recorded notes will appear in the MIDI track, you will notice that the recorded drum pattern only consists of the notes that are set in the MIDI settings of the 3p.-If you like you can now edit individual notes, eg 'quantise' the recording so that the timing is correct, add or delete notes, increase the velocity of some notes, etc.-If you then play the track back, the notes will be transmitted to the 3p which will then produce the drum sounds. On the 3p you can select other drum sounds if you like, the same drum pattern will then sound differently.If you only want to sequence the 3p, and do not want to record any audio, then check MIDI sequencers or step sequencers.  If you also want to record audio check DAWs like Logic, Cubase, Pro-Tools, Tracktion, Ableton etcAlbert

title: A little midi help, please.
post_content: Hi All -I am relatively new to midi and can't figure out what's happening with my drum set up. I using a Cirklon (midi output 4) to sequence a TR909, Nord Drum 2 and a Bolsa Bass and I am using a midi thru box. Each drum machine is set to receive a different channel. Bolsa Bass is set to channel 1, 909 on channel 2 and Nord Drum on global channel 3. The settings in my Cirklon match. For some reason the Nord Drum is receiving the midi assigned to the Bolsa Bass and I can't figure out why! Any suggestions?Do I need to assign different note assignments for the Nord?? Or something else?Any help is much appreciated!

title: RE: A little midi help, please.
post_content: Hi mayyammay!Make sure that the Individual MIDI channels of all 6 channels of the ND2 are switched off [Ch.OF],-If that was already the case, the ND2 should only respond to notes sent on MIDI channel 3 (/the global MIDI channel), and I would check the Cirklon MIDI settings, maybe some setting allows MIDI notes from the bass track ending up on MIDI channel 3. If you can't find anything in the Cirklon settings, check with a MIDI monitor app or software* what MIDI messages are coming out of the Cirklon and the thru box.Albert*You'll need a MIDI interface for this, there are free apps available for iOS and Windows, and I think Mac as well.

title: RE: A little midi help, please.
post_content: Thank you, Ch.OF was it!In hindsight I should have known, but thought the GC would cancel out the channel settings.Thanks so much for your help.

title: Nord 3P only plays back kick on midi
post_content: Hey everyone,I just recently purchased the nord 3p. I am able to record midi with the different pads. When I play it back, the only sound that plays is the kick drum (first pad) for every single not on the midi. Even if the note in midi is the 3rd pad it will still trigger the kick drum.Right now I only have 1 midi cable. I alternate between In & Out to record and then to play back. I didn't realize I needed both during the time of purchase. I'm going to get the other midi cable asap so I can get this working but I'm assuming this is not the reason for the midi triggering only the kick.Does anyone know how to fix this problem or does anyone have this problem?

title: RE: Nord 3P only plays back kick on midi
post_content: Hi masbee, welcome to the forum!Perhaps there are more explanations, but maybe your MIDI track does not send the recorded notes on the ‘Global’ MIDI channel, but on the ‘Individual’ MIDI channel that you perhaps set on the channel of the 3p with the kick sound-The Nord Drum 3p only sends MIDI notes on the global MIDI channel, you want to send the notes back to the 3p on this MIDI channel, check the global channel in the MIDI settings, the factory Global MIDI channel is 10 [GL.10], you can pick a different one if you want. Match the output MIDI channel of your MIDI track with the Global MIDI channel on the 3p.-I’m assuming you’re recording MIDI on a sequencer app /DAW, the track on your sequencer probably accepts all MIDI channels from the input, the output MIDI channel of your MIDI track is probably not the same as the Global MIDI channel as set on the 3p, but corresponds with the Individual MIDI channel of the channel (pad) with the kick sound on the 3pUnless you want to control the sound parameters of the 3p with MIDI, it’s best to switch the Individual MIDI channels off - check this setting on all 6 channels of the 3p, it looks like this: [Ch.OF]Check the manual or perhaps some other posts here if you want more info on the difference between Global and Individual MIDI channels, eg this one:nord-drum-forum-f27/nord-drum-3p-as-sou ... ml#p105915Hope this helps,Albert

title: RE: Nord 3P only plays back kick on midi
post_content: Thanks for the response Albert. I am using Logic as a DAW. I was reading the manual and it mentioned Global Midi. There are no details about it though..Where do I go select Global Midi on the Nord ?

title: RE: Nord 3P only plays back kick on midi
post_content: Hi,Press Shift + MIDI repeatedly to go through the different MIDI settings,-you found the Global MIDI channel when you see [GL.xx] (where xx is the currently set Global MIDI channel, or OF =off)  factory setting is [GL.10].-match this one with the MIDI output channel of your track in Logic,The Individual MIDI channel can be set for each of the 6 channels of the 3p,-press Shift + MIDI a couple of times until you see [Ch.xx] (where xx is the set channel or OF =off),-with the channel select buttons check the Individual MIDI channel for each of the 6 channels..-never use the same MIDI channel as the Global MIDI channel...-perhaps best to switch it off on all channels if you’re not going to control parameters with CCThe note numbers are also in the MIDI menu and set per channel, [nt.xx] where xx is the MIDI note number that is sent on the Global MIDI channel when you hit the corresponding padCheck page 14 and 12 of the manual for more info..Albert

title: RE: Nord 3P only plays back kick on midi
post_content: So I did what you suggested and it did work. I need to alternate the Global Midi though because it still plays two channels at a time. Depending what pads I'm recording I change the Global Midi - which doesn't really make sense. I'm going to keep trying things and hopefully get it because having to change the Global midi each time makes the process very slow.Thank you so much for your help

title: RE: Nord 3P only plays back kick on midi
post_content: Strange!The 3p sends and receives on the Global MIDI channel, one track in Logic is enough to record a drum pattern using all 6 channels (sounds). The recorded drum pattern will consist of the 6 notes as set in the MIDI settings on the 3p.Do you mean that 2 channels of the 3p are triggered when only 1 MIDI note is sent to the 3p?-If all Individual MIDI channels are off [Ch.OF], the 3p should only ‘listen’ to the Global MIDI channel,-which of the 6 channels is triggered depends on the MIDI note that is sent to it on the Global MIDI channelThe other thing you should perhaps check is if all MIDI notes, as set on the 3p, are different from each other, eg note 60 for channel 1 [nt.60], note 62 for channel 2 [nt.62] etc.If the problem still persists I think either Logic is sending more MIDI notes than there are recorded on the track (perhaps check the metronome settings, or MIDI plugins or effects) or your MIDI interface does some weird things,Albert

title: RE: NORD DRUM 3P MIDI Chanel Configuration
post_content: Hey, since you figured that out. Did you have the problem of Channel 1 being triggered with the other Channels? I can't seem to figure this out. I am sending midi to my interface and receiving via my interface but on the receiving end I am getting Channel 1 triggered along with the other Channels. Any suggestions? - Thanks

title: RE: NORD DRUM 3P MIDI Chanel Configuration
post_content: Hi Tiand,What do you want to do, and what is your current (MIDI) setup?The Nord Drum sends MIDI on the Global MIDI channel only, the individual MIDI channels cannot be used to send MIDI from the Nord Drum (2 or 3P). So if you hit a pad, the 3P will send the corresponding note on the global MIDI channel, the note numbers are also set in the MIDI menu. The individual MIDI channels that can be set per Channel of the ND2 or 3P, can be used to contol sound parameters of the individual Channels, or to play melodies with an individual drum sound of a Channel. Unless you want to do one of these things, it's best to switch the individual MIDI channel off for all 6 Channels, only use the Global MIDI channel. If you do want to use the individual MIDI channels, make sure you set a different MIDI channel for each, and yet a different MIDI channel for the general MIDI channel, unless you're absolutely sure what you're doing.Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Nord drum 3p albin kit problem...
post_content: Hi soon81,Maybe it’s not the 3p, but the cables, amplifier, speakers or headphones that you are using?Try other cables, or if you’re using headphones, try different headphones, I would start with that. title: RE: PDS 10 or 2 stand
post_content: Hi!The PDS-10 is quite expensive indeed.The PDS-10 in the picture has a mount holding a base plate that is only compatible with Roland devices,you can't use that plate for the Nord Drum2/Pad, in stead you will have to use the 'stand holder' that comes with the Nord Drum2 and Pad,So when you buy a PDS-10 you can trash the Roland base plate, the mount is the essential bit, and the PDS-2 doesn't seem to have such a mount to hold the Nord Pad or Nord Drum2 'stand holder',You can replicate the PDS-10 with Pearl stuff: have a look at the solution suggested by Pablo here:http://www.norduserforum.com/nord-drum- ... t5717.htmlHowever, that particular Pearl stand is no longer available,perhaps the Pearl C-830 is also suitable[<Edit : No, it is not, see below posts of 20 July 2018] - however, when I add it all up, the replica becomes more expensive than the PDS-10...I once took a straight cymbal stand, removed the upper section, to put the ND2 with its mount right on top, (disadvantage = can't adjust the angle) and I used the AX25-L to attach the Nord PadPerhaps you should visit your local music store, ask the drums/hardware department for a creative but not too expensive solution,the diameter of the Nord stand holder is 23mm according to the manualCheers,Albert

title: Copying and pasting individual sounds to User Kit?
post_content: Sorry if this is a stupid question... I like some of the individual sounds from the Factory Kits and would like to be able to copy and paste these sounds to my own User Kit. Is this possible at all?

title: RE: Copying and pasting individual sounds to User Kit?
post_content: Hi whitecat,I presume this is a question about the 3p,Option 1:Use Copy and Paste functions, see page 11 of the manual, you can copy the sound of one channel from one kit to another kit, first go to the channel (sound) that you want to copy, press Copy, then simply navigate to the other kit and destination channel and press Paste.Option 2:according to the manual you can store a drum sound in a user Drum bank (in case the drum sound is not in one of the factory Drum banks) after that you can select it from the Drum bank when you are assembling a kit, have a look at the ‘store drum’ and ‘drum select’ sections on page 6..Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Copying and pasting individual sounds to User Kit?

title: Nord Beat tutorial
post_content: hi - can anyone give a simple step-by-step tutorial for setting up nord drum 2 and nord beat for ipad via midi interface?!

title: RE: Nord Beat tutorial
post_content: Hi Hans,Welcome to the forum!I assume you know how to connect your MIDI interface to your iPad, directly, or through the camera connection kits USB port, then connect the MIDI OUT of your interface to the MIDI IN of your ND2Then make sure the NB2 app sends its MIDI signals on the same channel the ND2 is set to receive on, just follow these steps:1) On the ND2 match the global MIDI channel [GL.XX] with the MIDI channel in the app:- Nord Beat app: go to Menu > MIDI setup, check the MIDI channel- ND2: press [SHIFT] + [MIDI] - a couple of times, until you see [GL.XX], then use the knob to set the value XX until it's the same as in the app2) In the MIDI setup menu of the app: check the note numbers listed (e.g. #1: 60, #2: 62, #3: 64, etc...) -- then on the ND2: press [SHIFT] + [MIDI] - until you see [n .XX]  and match the MIDI note numbers with the ones in the app:In this example: go to channel 1 and if required, use the knob so that you’ll see [n. 60] in the display, then go to channel 2 make sure it says : [n. 62], etc...3) Because you won't need this functionality in combination with the app, switch the individual MIDI channels off in the MIDI menu of your Nord drum2: [Ch.OF]  :- press [SHIFT] + [MIDI] - until you see [Ch .XX] select OF (off) on each of the 6 channels - ...Cheers,Albert*

title: RE: Nord Beat tutorial
post_content: Hi Lftomashek!Carefully check the settings in the third step I mentioned above, only use the Global MIDI channel, not the individual MIDI channels..If that doesn’t help, it could also be your USB-MIDI interface, what brand and type is it?Some very cheap ones are missing a small but apparently important component, you wouldn’t be the first I’m afraid.Albert

title: Drum 3p and Beat Step Pro

title: RE: Drum 3p and Beat Step Pro
post_content: Well, I finally figured it out with the help of a friend. I hope this can help other Nord Drum 3p users as its a really awesome piece of hardware. I had to go into the settings on the beat step pro software and set the individual settings to the midi notes that correspond to the nord drum 3 midi note default settings in the manual, they are something like: 60, 62,64 etc...its important to note the pads were backwards for some odd reason so don't get discouraged. I then had to turn all of the global and individual channels off on each pad of the nord drum on its midi settings.Overall now that it works its really tight, velocity control is amazing!

title: Can I connect an old Roland TMC 6 to the Nord Drum 3P?
post_content: I know that I can connect the TMC 6 to the Nord Drum 3P since the 3P has MIDI IN, my question is, can the 3P play 12 different sounds at a single instance (6 sounds from the 3P, 6 more sounds from the 3p triggered by the TMC 6)?

title: RE: Can I connect an old Roland TMC 6 to the Nord Drum 3P?
post_content: Hi whitecat,No it can’t, the 3p has 6 channels, that can be triggered either via MIDI, or by playing the pads, so 6 sounds is the maximum.Cheers,Albert

title: Help with setting up ND3 in Cubase
post_content: Hi guys,First post here, since i just purchased my first Nord instrument. Happy with the sound, but still figuring out how to connect it the way i want.Here goes:What i want to do, is basically to programm all 6 sounds within one midi clip. So far i have only been able to control one sound per midi clip. It seems like every sound channel has it's own midi midi channel, which is preventing me from addressing them all at the same time. I read in the manual something about CC and how each channel has it's own setting, but i am unsure how to use this in my situation. If i record myself playing the nd3, it does record different notes in the clip; they just all play back the same sound.My ideal end result would be that i play the ND3, record the midi notes in a midi clip within Cubase, and then do some further editing of notes and automation in the clip.Thank you  in advance for your help!Boy

title: RE: Help with setting up ND3 in Cubase
post_content: Hi Boy, welcome to the forum!You probably already knew this about the basic setup..The ND3p sends MIDI notes on the Global MIDI channel, each of the 6 sounds (channels/pads, whatever you want to call them) is coupled to a MIDI note, as set in the MIDI menu of the 3p, eg [n.60]. The pattern you recorded consists of these 6 different notes only. Example, let’s say note 60 (C4) is coupled to channel1, if you send note 60 to the 3p on the Global MIDI channel, you will hear whatever is programmed on channel1, eg. a bass drum, note 62 a snare etc..Explanation of what goes wrong..The individual MIDI channels can indeed be used to control sound parameters, but it is important to know that if you send a MIDI note to an individual MIDI channel, a sound will be triggered on the channel(s) of the 3p that you coupled to that MIDI channel. The MIDI note number will here control the pitch of the Tone section. If you’re using the same MIDI channel as the Global MIDI channel for one or more Individual channels, sending one of the notes as set in the MIDI menu [n.XX] will cause a problem; each channel of the 3p is monophonic, and you’re sending two notes to one channel at the same time.. Therefore, if you want to use Individual MIDI channels, avoid using the same MIDI channel as the global MIDI channel.. so if the global MIDI channel is 10 [GL.10], never use MIDI channel 10 for one of the individual MIDI channels [Ch.XX].Setting up the Nord Drum Individual MIDI channels [Ch.XX] for CC controlIf you want to control the same parameter(s) of all drum sounds at the same time, select the same MIDI channel as Individual MIDI channel for each of the 6 channels, but don’t use the same MIDI channel as the Global MIDI channel, and don’t use it to send MIDI notes to the 3p, unless you want all channels to be triggered at the same time. If you want to control sound parameters of individual drum sounds, choose a different MIDI channel for each, eg. MIDI channel 1 for channel1, MIDI channel 2 for 2, etc, but again, avoid the MIDI channel that is used as Global MIDI channel. Also, do not forget to allow the 3p to receive CC in the MIDI menu..Setting up CubaseIn Cubase you will need to create at least one extra MIDI track for automation, because you’re going to send the CC’s on a different MIDI channel than the Global MIDI channel. And depending how many sounds you want to control individually, you’ll need to add more tracks, so up to 6 additional MIDI tracks for automation. Make sure the MIDI out channel for each track corresponds to the Individual MIDI channel as set on the Nord drum. If you want to have the recorded notes in the MIDI track that you’re using to control parameters of a sound, move (not copy) the notes that correspond to that drum sound (eg all D4 notes) from the recorded track to the new track. In the new track you can now also change/vary the pitch of the drum sound by moving the notes up/down, if you want to keep the original pitch of the drum sound, place the notes on C4.I hope this helps,Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Help with setting up ND3 in Cubase
post_content: Hi Albert,Cheers for taking the time.When i saw your post i'd already figured it out somehow. Still not sure what i've done exactly, but it works.Honestly though, i find it a bit confusing. I've worked with MIDI for about 10 years but still some aspects make my head spin.Anyways, thanks again!

title: RE: Help with setting up ND3 in Cubase
post_content: Hi boybianchi,Great you got it working!Yes the Nord drum 2 and 3p are very flexible when it comes to MIDI,A huge whish after the first model Nord Drum was to get control over sound parameters with MIDI CCs, the ‘Individual MIDI channels’ are the result of that, and as you can assign any channel for each, it is possible to make configurations that in combination with the Global MIDI channel, will get you unwanted behavior..Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Modulation?
post_content: There is no morph but on the ND2 manual tou can see the list of MIDI Controllers and associated parameters, so if your ModWheel can be reassigned to one of them (on the master keyboard the MW belongs to) you may still be able to use it in a somehwat similar fashion, for example CC14 is Noise Filter Frequency.

title: RE: Modulation?
post_content: Hi Drumunkey,That’s page 30 of the manual for more details on how to do that, and page 32 for the list of the CC numbers and corresponding parameters...One tip if you’re going to use the Individual MIDI channels: never use the same MIDI channel as the general MIDI channel,if you have any questions about the correct MIDI setup, feel free to ask..Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Modulation?
post_content: I have the pleasure of beta-testing Patterning 2, imo by far the best iOS drum machine/MIDI controller. The best to work with the ND2, that is. I've used and fancied Patterning from day one but the new version will expand the possibilites with the ND2 big time. There'll be full MIDI CC mapping (this is limited in Patterning 1) where all externally controllable parameters on the ND2 will be easily accesible, all this on a very intuitive and imo easy to use UI. And there's many more new features. Like I said to Patterning's dev, now it feels like I have a new drum machine at hand.Also, I started experimenting with driving the ND2 with Patterning AND sending trigger inputs to one or more of channels from my euroracks or banana modulars. The results are highly interesting and experimental, something I happen to like. I may post a track at some point to show what this sounds like.

title: RE: Modification to allow individual outs...

title: RE: Modification to allow individual outs...

title: Kicks on the Nord Drum 3p
post_content: Hi! Any tips on creating kicks for electronic music?

title: RE: Kicks on the Nord Drum 3p
post_content: Hi JotaTiyus,I’m not sure if I can help you, my ND2 sounds are not compatible with the 3p, and I bet you are after completely different sounds than I am.. But I do find the ND2 is easy to edit, and I bet the 3p is too.If you have a clear idea of what you want, or a recording, try to dissect the sound; how low is the frequecy, do you hear any overtones, how does the sound decay, etc. If you keep that in mind, start with an ‘empty’ (default) sound and work towards the sound you want. Usually you will stumble upon some interesting other sounds in the process, you can always keep those as well, and before you know it, you have a complete bank full of sounds that you created yourself! Another good way to start is scanning through the factory banks, to see if anything comes close, start tweaking from there. Unfortunately there aren’t that many 3p banks here nor on the Nord website, apart from the factory banks there is theAlbin Westerlind bankthat you may want to check out, if you hadn’t already..Have fun experimenting, creating and playing!Albert

post_content: Hello,I'm blocking on one things from several days...I use Ableton Live Lite, with a Nord Drum 3P, the link is done with the Roland UM-ONE (DIN midi / USB) cable.When I want to record a loop of drum with Ableton (so Armed), 2 notes are played.Always the snare (the 2nd PAD initialized on the superior line ) and the sound I'm playing.E.g. if I'm playing the Kick, I have 2 sounds, the Kick and the Snareif I'm playing the HiHat, I have 2 sounds, the HiHat and the SnareWhen I stop record (not Armed)  I have correct sound. title: RE: Nord Drum 3P + Ableton (double notes)
post_content: Hi Phillius, welcome to the forum!!The problem is probably (if I read your setup correctly) that you are using the same MIDI channel for the individual MIDI channels as your Global MIDI channel on your Nord drum.You can use the individual MIDI channels to control sound parameters or play melodies, but you should always choose a different MIDI channel than the Global MIDI channel. If you’re not going to control sound parameters, it’s best to switch them off.. You’re setting the should look like this:[GL.10] (global MIDI channel = 10[Ch.OF] (individual channel off, for each of the 6 channels of your 3P)In your sequencer program a drum pattern using the notes set per channel (  [n.60] etc) and send it on MIDI channel 10...Hope this helps,Albert

title: RE: Nord Drum 3P + Ableton (double notes)
post_content: Hi Albert,Thanks for your hospitality.and yes your explaination help me!!!Thank you very much for your response, I understand now that each PAD have a channel (like if on a keyboard we have one channel per note)So I understood that in MIDI setting, I have to change of channel of PAD with the 'CH SELECT' buttons (CH is not the global...)Now, It's OK with Ableton!!!I changed all channel (CH) on OFF for each PAD, and I let GL = 10Phil.

title: RE: Nord Drum 3P + Ableton (double notes)

title: RE: How to Connect Drum 3P to Computer via MIDI
post_content: Hi Ash,I presume you downloaded the latest version of the Nord Drum 3 manager from the website. Was your MIDI interface properly installed on your computer, or is it a class compliant interface that doesn’t require driver installation? Did you select your interface in the settings in the manager software? /Does the Nord Drum 3 manager recognize the interface?You have to connect both MIDI In and Out, connect the MIDI Out to the MIDI In port on the Nord drum, and MIDI In to MIDI Out, if it’s not clear which is which, try if swapping them helps..Albert

title: RE: How to Connect Drum 3P to Computer via MIDI
post_content: Hi AllProblem solved - it turns out that the MIDI to USB cable that I bought is rubbish!  On the advice of Andertons, Guildford UK, I purchased a Roland UM lead, which worked perfectly first time.  They did advise me that most cheap cables won't work or, if they do, are unreliable.I thought I'd post this, just in case other members have a similar problem in future.Ash

title: RE: How to Connect Drum 3P to Computer via MIDI
post_content: Hi Ash,Glad you got it sorted!I’m afraid you’re not the first, some cheap interfaces will work ok with simple MIDI data such as a couple of notes, but fail when you want to transfer larger amounts of data, like when transferring banks or an OS update.A couple of other examples:http://www.norduserforum.com/nord-drum- ... 13599.htmlhttp://www.norduserforum.com/nord-drum- ... 11675.htmlHave fun playing your 3P.Cheers,Albert

title: HEADPHONE GAIN
post_content: Hi,I was wondering if it's possible to up the gain of headphones output. I hear more the drumsticks hitting the pads, than the actual sound (specially on hi hats). This decreases a lot my playing experience.Hope someone could help.Cheers,ANtoni.

title: RE: HEADPHONE GAIN
post_content: Hi Podenco,Which Nord drum model do you have and what headphones are you using? When it was introduced it was said that the Nord drum 3p has improved headphones level over the Nord drum2. Then still it depends on the headphones you are using, and there are some settings that may help to increase the level,Some thoughts /ideas:-needless to say, open headphones will not help, some closed models reject sounds from the outside world better than others,-low impedance (lower than 50 ohms or so) headphones do not seem to work well with the Nord drum2, at least that was my impression after reading some of the postshere, not sure about the 3p. Very high impedance headphones will (in general) also get you a lower sound output. My 250 ohms DT-770 headphones work great with my Nord drum2, the combination could destroy my ears if I crank up the output to max. At reasonable levels I still hear the sticks hitting the pads, depending a bit on the drum sound and my playing style, I can live with it.-did you try different sticks, tip shapes and other types of wood?Settings that might help:-You can set the level of each channel (drum sound) - perhaps they are low, / you can increase them-Try to experiment with sensitivity settings & dynamic curves of the pad(s) - maybe you want the Nord drum to be slightly more responsiveBe careful with your ears, enjoy playing!Cheers,Albert

title: How to Copy a Drum Kit in Nord Drum 3p
post_content: Hi,is it not possible to copy a drumkit to another destination, for example from A1 to C2?

title: RE: How to Copy a Drum Kit in Nord Drum 3p
post_content: To copy a kit to another location press SHIFT+STORE (program number will start blinking) then dial in the desired program number, then press STORE again, the program is then copied to that location.

title: RE: Nord Drum Bracket Screws
post_content: Hi nord lord,For the ND1, ND2 and the Nord Pad the bolts are 8mm long, outer diameter is 4mm, and given the 'pitch' of the thread, I think it's 'M4', (coarse M4, M stands for metric,http://www.metrication.com/engineering/threads.html). Maybe you can measure the diameter of the holes in the plastic plate and 3p itself, if that’s also 4mm, I bet it’s M4Albert

title: Removing reverb from whole kit in Nord Drum 3P
post_content: Just a quick'n'dirty hack for cleaning the kit from unwanted amount of reverb. BE AWARE that this will alter the overall sound of the kit.But thats exactly why you are here.Select all channels for editing by holding SHIFT and clicking EDIT ALL CHSelect reverb parameter for editing by clicking REVERBReduce the amount of reverb by turning the DIAL to zeroYou can try out the sounds nowSave the kit by holding SHIFT and clicking STORE KITNow you can choose the slot. If you want to save to the same slot just click STORE KITDoneIf you miss the reverb on some of the drum sounds, you can edit these one by one by exiting all channels, selecting a channel you want to edit and adding the amount of reverb. Don't forget to save.For more information please read the manual and this thread:http://www.norduserforum.com/nord-drum- ... 12780.html

title: Separated Channels Recording with Nord Drum.

title: RE: Separated Channels Recording with Nord Drum.
post_content: Hi Podenco!No, the Nord drum2 and 3p models have 2 outputs: Left and Right, each drum sound can be panned. So by panning to the extreme left or right, you could record the bass drum on one track and the rest on the other, for example. So there’s less to do in post, requires a little bit more preparation to get the sound and dynamics you want.Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Separated Channels Recording with Nord Drum.
post_content: Hi Albert,thank you very much for your quick response!I've done a little research, and found a template that can transfer each sound pad into different MIDI channels... What do you think about that?Cheers,Antoni.

title: RE: Separated Channels Recording with Nord Drum.
post_content: Hi Antoni,Ah, ok I thought you wanted to edit and tweak recorded audio per channel, you can of course do that if you record the audio tracks one by one, (which I forgot to mention in my previous post).This is how I would do it:-You can start by recording or programming a drum pattern on a MIDI track in Logic using the ‘Global MIDI’ channel as set on the Nord drum. If you prefer playing the pads to create this pattern, connect MIDI out of the Nord drum to a MIDI input on an interface. The drum pattern will be recorded on the MIDI track in Logic.-Connect MIDI out of the interface to the MIDI in of the Nord Drum, if you play back the MIDI recording, the beat will be played by the Nord Drum. If you want, you can still quantize notes and change velocity values in Logic, or pick a different kit on the Nord drum, that is one of the advantages of recording MIDI.-You can indeed control the sound parameters with MIDI (Nord Drum2 and 3p only), by setting up an ‘individual’ MIDI channel for each sound. Then setup a MIDI track for each to program/record the ‘control changes’ you want to send to the Nord Drum.-if you’re satisfied with the result, you can record the audio from the Nord drum onto an audio track in Logic.Hope this answered some of your questions,Albert

I want to be able to have it in different channels (snare, bassdrum, hi hat, etc), so I can play with volume, pan and other things when mixing. I now I can record each sound separately, but I would loose the organic experience of the performance.wartaler wrote:-Connect MIDI out of the interface to the MIDI in of the Nord Drum, if you play back the MIDI recording, the beat will be played by the Nord Drum. If you want, you can still quantize notes and change velocity values in Logic, or pick a different kit on the Nord drum, that is one of the advantagse of recording MIDI.When you say that, I'm assuming I'll be able to have each sound in a different MIDI channel, right? Nord would be capable to assign the sound from the pad to the MIDI channel, then I could export the 6 MIDI channels to audio.Thanks again for your time.Cheers,Antoni.

title: RE: Separated Channels Recording with Nord Drum.
post_content: Hi Antoni,When you’re playing the pads of the Nord Drum 3p, it will (only) output MIDI notes on the ‘Global’ MIDI channel, this Global MIDI channel is set in the MIDI menu of the Nord Drum. You can record these notes on a (one) MIDI track in Logic. Each pad (sound) is coupled to one MIDI note number, so the MIDI recording will consist of these notes only.If you want to record the Nord Drum in one take, and then want to edit the audio for each drum sound seperately you will have to be a bit creative, because unfortunately the Nord Drum 2 and 3p only have 2 audio outputs (left and right). Therefore I think you should start by recording your session on a MIDI track. One way to then get the audio of the different drum sounds onto different audio tracks, is to split the MIDI recording you made into 6 MIDI tracks. One track with the bassdrum notes, one with the snare notes, etc. If you then play back these tracks one by one, (each time muting the other 5) you can record the audio for each drum sound seperately, track by track.The MIDI channel that you can set for each drum sound can (only) be used to control sound parameters. You could use this to your advantage, because you can control level, pan, in fact all sound parameters of each drum sound. I agree having separate audio tracks has it’s advantages but it is a little bit of a hassle, therefore I suggested using this functionality first..Hope this helpedCheers,Albert

title: RE: Separated Channels Recording with Nord Drum.
post_content: Hi Albert,thank you very much. I think I get it now, you've been super clear!Finally, bought one.wartaler wrote:If you want to record the Nord Drum in one take, and then want to edit the audio for each drum sound seperately you will have to be a bit creative, because unfortunately the Nord Drum 2 and 3p only have 2 audio outputs (left and right). Therefore I think you should start by recording your session on a MIDI track. One way to then get the audio of the different drum sounds onto different audio tracks, is to split the MIDI recording you made into 6 MIDI tracks. One track with the bassdrum notes, one with the snare notes, etc. If you then play back these tracks one by one, (each time muting the other 5) you can record the audio for each drum sound seperately, track by track.I'll try this method for my recordings, but as you pointed, this is an instrument and has to be played with all the intention and sensitivity, meaning that you even could not need to tweak anything in mixing.I'll keep you posted.Thanks again for being so nice!Enjoy your Thursday.Cheers,Antoni.

title: RE: Nord Drum3P as Midi Controller ?
post_content: Hi Torobello!This is how it works on the ND2, as far as I can tell from the manual it works the same way for the 3p,Hold Shift and press the button above the label ‘MIDI’ a couple of times until you see ‘GL’ in the display, here you can set the global MIDI channel, make sure the global MIDI channel matches the MIDI channel of your sampler. Hold Shift and press MIDI again until you see ‘n’, here you can set the note numbers for each of the 6 Channels of the Nord drum,Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Triggering Sample with a Pad or with The Snare
post_content: Triggers usually require a trigger-to-MIDI converter. I haven't yet seen "all in one" solutions.What about something like an Alesis PercPad (discontinued but still available online)?You can use its internal sounds but also trigger external ones, thanks to its MIDI OUT; you can modify the MIDI Notes associated to each of the 4 pads, to map them to your samples.Another simple solution could be the use of a Roland SPD ONE WAV pad, you may load your samples in it and let the drummer play them directly from the pad, with no need for any MIDI connection

title: RE: Triggering Sample with a Pad or with The Snare

title: RE: Triggering Sample with a Pad or with The Snare
post_content: Hi Quai!The Percpad is probably a good idea, cheap, it has MIDI out, and a trigger input in case your drummer wants to use a drum trigger or small pad. On the Samplepad models, you can import your own samples, still much cheaper than a Roland SPD-SX or Yamaha DTX Multi 12.The Roland SPD::ONE WAV has one pad, you can import your own samples onto it, no MIDI out though..The other models in this series have a fixed set of sounds, but you can import 1 sample of your own, the ELECTRO model has some retro handclap sounds, might be interesting,.The Roland TM-2 drum module is very small, not extremely expensive, has MIDI out, can import user samples, but you will need a drum pad like the BT-1 you mentioned, or a trigger like the ones from roland or ddrum.And of course the Nord Drum (the first model) is quite a compact drum module too, the synth can produce some cool sounds of it’s own, has MIDI out. With a ND2 you can possibly even replicate those clap sounds. The ND2 is probably harder to find second hand, and more expensive.Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Triggering Sample with a Pad or with The Snare
post_content: Hey Quai!I agree they are interesting looking units! I didn’t know they have MIDI over USBLike most MIDI over USB devices, it can’t serve as ‘host’, so you can’t connect a regular USB-MIDI interface to the USB port. You either need a computer or tablet, or something like the Kenton MIDI USB Host mkII, that basically provides DIN MIDI ports to an instrument that only has MIDI over USB. The SPD::ONE manual doesn’t say much about MIDI, if you can send/receive program changes, or which MIDI channel has to be used etc. Perhaps check a Roland forum, I did find thisreview, near the end the guy says you need to switch it into MIDI mode, which turns ‘local off’ (if you hit the pad, the unit won’t produce sound, unless you route it back through MIDI). I think it’s easier to let the drummer himself switch between the sounds with the knob.Albert

But What I want to do is sen CCs from Ableton to my nord drum (and the rack 2x aswell) to change the sound banks from song to song/ scene to scene in my live set.Lets say I go from scene 1 to scene 2 in my ableton set. title: RE: Sending program change from ableton to nord drum 3p
post_content: Hi!There are a few things to be aware of:!) this is an Ableton question, not an ND question2) you want to send PC's not CC'sWHY?Ableton is the thing sending the change data, ND is just receiving. PC = Program Change, CC = Continuous Controller or Control ChangeHOW?make a MIDI track in Ableton sending to the port and channel that your ND is connected to. Empty MIDI clips in the track will transmit appropriate PC's to the ND, which will change as instructed, assuming you have connected everything correctly.Changing ND patches from Ableton Live.pdf(123.48 KiB) Downloaded 394 timesI have done this and depended upon it live, so I know it works.Ed

title: RE: Sending program change from ableton to nord drum 3p
post_content: Program changes has always worked with Nord Drum 2 (& 3 it seems). I still haven't found a way to send Bank changes though. ND 2 doesn't respond to Ableton's way of sending Bank changes. Only being able to send Program changes and no Bank changes isn't very useful for a live performance. Same problem using Modstep on an iPad. There is no way to send cc for MSB and LSB in Ableton nor in Modstep. It seems that those software are preconfigured to send MSB first then LSB (which is the normal order that most synths and drum machines use) when Nord Drum 2 has an inversed order for bank change as mentioned in the manual (LSB first then LSB).

title: Add hihat-pedal to ND3P rig
post_content: I want to add a hihat pedal to my 3p rig. It is just for practice, so I don't need to have stellar sound from it.My choices are either to get some pedal that can transmit midi trigs and just trig one of the pads that way, or to get some kind of stand alone electric hihat pedal that generates sound on it's own and then just add that signal with a small mixing desk.I don't really like any of the options but I need to be able to practice drums in my appartment and my nord drum is doing electric drumkit-duties part time.Have any of you guys thought about this?

title: RE: Add hihat-pedal to ND3P rig
post_content: Hi Simpa!With a hihat pedal you usually want the position of the foot pedal to influence the sound, to mimic open/closed position of real hats. These pedals are not compatible with the Nord Drum models as you may already know, in the sense that the open/closed position will not have any effect on the sound.It would require some complex MIDI trickery to let the position of a foot pedal determine the note length parameters on the Nord Drum, not impossible but not really practical. So, I think if you want open/close sound and feel, find yourself a second hand drum brain and hihat pedal, use that unit generate the sound. Exactly as you suggested. Check the specifications if the drum unit reacts to half open positions of the pedal, if you want a more natural response. Perhaps someone else here can give you better suggestions what to look for..There are two options on the Nord drum itself that might help you to get a hihat like sound:Using 2 pads: create one pad with the sound of a closed hihat, and one pad with a sound of an open hihat. Then define a mute group so that these 2 pads exclude each other, after you’ve hit the pad with the open hihat sound, you can stop the sound by hitting the other pad.Using 1 pad: create a sound where the length of the hihat sound is dynamically controlled, so that if you hit it harder it will sound longer. I found this working quite ok, and got used to the playing style quickly..Good luck!Cheers,Albert

title: RE: ND2/Nordbeat and other devices [MIDI]
post_content: Hi!You have to enable sending MIDI clock from the Nord Beat app: go to the menu > MIDI devices > Clock syncset it to send,Perhaps first check if your effects and synths can actually sync to MIDI clock, the Moogerfooger can,(I had a peek in the manual, cool device btw, switch the MIDI clock sync function of your MF on by sending a value of >63 to CC108 (edit: and CC89. title: RE: ND2/Nordbeat and other devices [MIDI]
post_content: Hey all, first post here.. after a fruitful cooperation with the Nord Drum 1, as of yesterday, I'm a happy user of the Nord Drum 2. I'm thrilled as I expected to be and thought this may be the right time to ask around whether anyone else using the Nord Beat 2 app have the same experiences as I do. In a nutshell: the bpm values set in the app, in reality,  are prone to shift up a little, by a few decimals. In a little more detail:  when, say, the tempo is set to 126, the app actually sends 126.1 or 126.2.. some bpms, like the good old 120 seem to be intact and remain 120 at the end, but usually there's this little, but annoying difference.  I tested this with and without a MIDI interface (i.e.:when  Nord Beat sends clock directly to other apps like SamplR or Loopy AND when Nord Beat sends clock via the iConnectMIDI interface to the Nord Drum) and the results are always the same. So it is not the interface causing the shift, the bug, if this is a bug at all, comes from Nord Beat. I'd like to have a steady bpm all around so that I can play my other gear in sync with the Nord Drum, SamplR, etc. Shall I forget the app and get a hardware sequencer? If so, I thought maybe the Arturia Beatstep would come handy. If you have experience / info on this bpm-shift issue and/or the Nord Drum-Beatstep integration, please share.  Thanks a million!Cheers, Gabor

title: RE: ND2/Nordbeat and other devices [MIDI]
post_content: Hi Gabor!not sure, but I managed to replicate what you're seeing within the iPad:(Nord Beat + Loopy), after changing the bpm value in NB from any value to 126 bpm, the Loopy app reads 126.1 bpm...However when I then shortly stop NB, and then press start again, the BPM in Loopy reads 126,0When I connect the NB app thru my MIDI interface to my Midibro device (small unit by Audiothingies = Midipal by Mutable instruments) the Midibro measures a slightly higher bpm value than expected. When the Loopy app is the clock source the Midibro measures a slightly lower bpm than expected. When I connect my ERM Midiclock+ device to the Midibro, it also reads some slightly lower bpm. When I connect the Midiclock+ to the Loopy app, all bpm values are exactly as expected.[btw.: The bpm measurement of the Midibro shows some fluctuations, regardless of the clock source. This either means that all the sources, including the 'rock solid' Midiclock+ have some MIDI clock jitter. And/or the Midibro's internal reference clock isn't 100% stable. When I connect the Midiclock+ to the Loopy app, the reading is very stable, the app clearly does some smooth and slow averaging as it is also slow to adapt to abrupt intentional large changes in tempo..]Funny stuff, ... but to come back to your question..I think, in general, that two (even seemingly identical) devices will not run exactly at the same tempo, even when both are set on exactly the same tempo. Therefore I think it is a good idea to use one MIDI clock source for all your apps/devices, sync everything to that one clock source. As long as everything is in sync with each other, and there isn't too much fluctuation from the clock source, all should be fine. And then it doesn't really matter what the exact bpm value is, or reads, right? The different bpm readings in the 2 synced apps, I think, doesn't mean that they are actually running on different tempos, or do you hear them drifting apart?Cheers,Albert

title: RE: ND2/Nordbeat and other devices [MIDI]
post_content: Hey Albert,Thanks for your detailed reply. Indeed,  tempo fluctuation is kinda rooted in the nature of MIDI and "rock solid clock" may be just a myth after all. I guess I can live with this or find a workaround and use a single device as the master clock. I'm not sure though if I can get it work it right as, like I said in my first post, my synths tend to translate the incoming clock data as per their own protocol and this results in behaviours not really fitting the song structures I'm working on. The Mopho x4 is a good example; it reads external MIDI all right but it also becomes a total slave and its sequencer plays only when the Nord Beat is running. Plus it translates the notes on the drum channels into voices so it plays notes, too.  So far I've been unable to get rid of this issue, maybe it's not even possible, can't tell right now. Muting the drum channels when they're not needed in the composition may be a solution, but a very awkward one. I could sync the whole lot to my DAW (Reason 8.3...guess I gotta love Swedish stuff...I also have a Teenage Engineering OP-1... and I drive a Saab) but don't want to take my notebook and audio interface to gigs ...(.. reading back all this raises the possibility of me having far too many problems...) I'd prefer to do this in a more straightforward manner without complex syncing-routes. The iPad is such a sleek and versatile tool/instrument, I use it exclusively to play backing tracks if that is the case, play SamplR and Loopy live, synced to another app...possibly Nord Beat. SamplR, for instance, does exactly what I need: reads the external tempo but has its own transport controls alive, no forced start/stop. And to answer your ultimate question, yes, the tiny tempo drifts are enough to move the track out of sync over time,usually in the matter of a mniute or two; Nord Beat runs at bpm 126 (let's stick to the example) which in SamplR becomes 126.1, then at some point I start the Mopho's sequencer set to bpm 126 dead on beat and pretty soon I notice that it's running a tad behind the Nord Drum. Retriggering the sequence of course helps, temporarily. Anyway, I guess I'll have to accept that this is all down to MIDI and gotta live with it. Will and can.I emailed Nord Beat's developer, Kymatica earlier today, asking Jonathan to consider rolling out an update which should offer bpm decimals - with that the actual tempo could be tricked into whole numbers. We'll see what he's got to say.Thanks again, talk to you guys later.Cheers, Gabor

title: RE: ND2/Nordbeat and other devices [MIDI]
post_content: Hi!Quite some cool stuff you have there!Just some quick replies/ideas:jooga1972 wrote:The Mopho x4 is a good example; it reads external MIDI all right but it also becomes a total slave and its sequencer plays only when the Nord Beat is running. title: RE: ND2/Nordbeat and other devices [MIDI]
post_content: This just in: Jonathan from Kymatica wrote back and said that he and Loopy's developer had run a few tests right after he received my "bug report" and concluded that any Nord Beat bpm value set lower or higher than 120 produces a slight drift. So now the issue is kinda official. They used Nord Beat as master and a special app ( developed by Michael of Loopy...) as slave during the tests. Nord Beat is owned by Clavia Nord so Jonathan contacted them asking if they want him to look into this. Let's hope they say yes. A little twisted, but simple enough solution.
