title: Soundbank management .... having some issues
post_content: Hey fellow Nord Drummers,Today I installed the Nord Drum Manager app on my Macbook because,for the very first time, I wanted to back up my custom kits and also load same some artist soundpacks into my ND2. It more or less worked with the following issues:1. Was unable to send factory bank 1 into the laptop as the process stopped halfway thru and got the "read error" message. Had no trouble with sending all the other banks over to the mac. Note: I have modifed/customized kits in each factory bank so tampering with stock sounds should not cause any import/export bugs, I presume.2. I downloaded all the artist kits and managed to load them into the ND2 with the exception of the Boska-pack. The transfer always goes without any problems and the destination bank IS overwritten ... all with INIT sounds...i doubt that's how Boska's  custom work sounds like.I tried with different banks with the same result. Other artist packs transferred all right.I use a mid-2010 Macbook Pro with OSX 10.9.1 and my main interface is a Focusrite Saffire Pro 40. Any hints or thoughts on these issues will be much appreciated.Thanks,Gabor

title: RE: Soundbank management .... having some issues
post_content: Hi Gabor,@problem 1: Strange, I will try some things here to replicate later, I agree it shouldn't matter whether it's a modified factory bank or not@problem 2: on what OS is your ND2 running? Did you manage to work with the Tilliander bank?The reason I ask is because the Boska and Tilliander banks are made with OS3.00,I remember that loading a bank made with a newer OS than the OS installed on your ND2 results in 'init' sounds.So if your ND2 is still at 2.x you need to update it first to OS 3.0 in order to use those 2 banks..

title: RE: Soundbank management .... having some issues
post_content: wartaler wrote:Hi Gabor,@problem 1: Strange, I will try some things here to replicate later, I agree it shouldn't matter whether it's a modified factory bank or not@problem 2: on what OS is your ND2 running? Did you manage to work with the Tilliander bank?The reason I ask is because the Boska and Tilliander banks are made with OS3.00,I remember that loading a bank made with a newer OS than the OS installed on your ND2 results in 'init' sounds.So if your ND2 is still at 2.x you need to update it first to OS 3.0 in order to use those 2 banks..Hey Albert,Thanks for your reply, it helped a lot!With regard to problem nr.2., it just occurred to me that until now I'd been on OS 2.24! I bought the ND2 new last summer and for some reason I was convinced that it came with the latest OS. This explains why the Boska and Tilliander banks (you were right again, that one didn't load properly either..) couldn't be saved on the unit. title: RE: ND2 broke down... during 2 hours
post_content: Happy to hear - but strange, it more seems like a temporary malfunctioning of your interface that coincided with/just after your update to OS3I surfed the net and there's quite some things that -in general- can go wrong with USB MIDI interfaces:- Microsoft very recently updated Win8.1 for a problem with certain USB MIDI interfaces when connected to USB3 ports- Here's an example of an 'alternative' (probably cheaper) interface design, "this crap does not follow [MIDI] standards. Yet these MIDI USB cable work with eg Yamaha equipment, but apparently not with MIDI outs buffered with a 74HCT04"I can imagine that the fact that they still work with some MIDI devices, not with others, complicates things quite a bit trying to figure out what's going on...http://www.arvydas.co.uk/2013/07/cheap- ... -required/- Here's some discussion about SysEx, data speed, software, drivers, and interface design:http://www.soundonsound.com/forum/showf ... er=1025890Based on the SOS thread in the link, I'm not sure what the conclusion on this should be. It's clear that SysEx (i.e. bank transfer and OS updates) contains a lot more data than just notes, rate of transfer can be an issue.To me it hasn't become clear what the influence of software (i.e. the ND Manager), the operating system (Win/Mac version), computer hardware, and MIDI interface are on this...I guess I was lucky with my choice of interface, and I have no clashes with my other hardware, software and Windows, it connects well with the ND2..Personally I don't think there is anything wrong with ND2, OS3, nor the Manager software per se..Albert

title: RE: ND2 broke down... during 2 hours
post_content: Well today after more testing I managed to figure out the problem. Hopefully this will solve issues for those also getting one midi note etc. Essentially, it depends on the midi cables themselves. I have two sets - one is a very short but from a music store, the others very long and from ebay. Needless to say, the ebay ones are the issue. Now they look the same, they still send midi, but they fail to consistently receive midi from the ND2. I believe that is due to the pin configuration not being correct or they are not using a proper cable (bandwidth).So answer to any midi issues is to first ensure that your cables are reputable. If in doubt, try other cables. Crazy I know, but it will save you getting different interfaces etc. Its especially confusing as the cheap cables will still work, but just not all of the time (in my experience it was actually everything but ND2 software and midi slave mode).Hope that helps - I spent a couple months trying to sort this out, I know there are others in the same situation, this is what solved it for me.

title: RE: ND2 broke down... during 2 hours

title: RE: ND2 broke down... during 2 hours

FrustratingAnyway in conclusion, apparently a lot of crap is sold, so people looking for new MIDI gear should take care choosing their interface (read reviews), and go to a proper music store to get your MIDI cables.  When things don't work use a systematic approach to test each component in the chain; usb port, usb cable, MIDI cables, interface - by swapping with components preferably of different make..Great you finally found the problem, and good to know it has nothing to do with your ND2 or OS3.0Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Sample rate
post_content: Hi!The Nord Drum 2 can't record audio, it doesn't have AD converters, only DA.It is a digital synthesizer, not a sampler; you can't import, or play back recorded samples.Like many synthesizers, technical details like the DA converters used, bitrate and depth, and output circuitry are not specified, but in my opinion the Nord Drum 2 is a very nice sounding synth!When I'm playing with it, I am not aware of the fact it's a digital instrument..Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Headphone impendance/once and for all
post_content: Hi,My Senn. HD 595 (120ohm) are louder than my BD 770 pro (250ohm), I tested it with 'snare' sounds..The frequency response is quite different, so it depends a bit on the drum sound.I still think that, as a rule of thumb, lower impedance cans have higher output than higher impedance ones (with the same audio device).  "the 'professional' designs (..) typically range from 150(omega) to 600(omega). Within this group it is often the case that the lower the impedance the higher the volume. (..) people tend to use high-quality 'professional'-impedance headphones with portable equipment, and this is rarely a problem, except that the maximum volume will be reduced compared to a lower-impedance design" SOShttps://www.soundonsound.com/sos/jan03/ ... rkshop.aspI can imagine frequency response of the headphones, and design (open/close/in ear) may also influence perception of loudness. I am a bit surprised by your finding, could the ND2 output be designed to lower the level when low impedance (say <100ohm) headphones are connected?Cheers,Albert

title: RE: RECORDING ND2 USING CUBASE 5
post_content: I seem to be having the same issue. I am new to MIDI and am struggling to record the ND2 sounds using MIDI. Is this actually possible?I can record audio no problem but how, using MIDI, can I get the cool sounds I've created on the ND2 to record on my DAW (Cubase)?Please, oh sages, enlighten me...

title: RE: RECORDING ND2 USING CUBASE 5
post_content: If you want to record the "sounds" you need to hook up your ND2 to your audio card and create a track to record Audio, not MIDI.If you want to record also the MIDI data (then playback them to record the audio) you need to create another track that points to the ND2 MIDI IN/OUT ports.

title: RE: RECORDING ND2 USING CUBASE 5
post_content: Hi!MIDI is perfomance data, like notes, velocity, control changes etc - that can be communicated between Cubase, and the ND2. You can record/program/edit MIDI data on a MIDI track in Cubase. MIDI data does not include audio.The audio that comes out of the Nord Drum 2 can be recorded on an audio track in Cubase.MIDI:Nord Pad > Nord Drum 2 <> MIDI interface <> Cubase MIDI track       (data: notes, velocity etc)Audio:Nord Drum 2  > audio interface A/D > Cubase audio track.Let's say you have the Nord Pad (or other pads) connected to your ND2. You can record a performance on a MIDI track in Cubase. You can easily edit the recorded notes, eg quantise, edit the velocity, delete/add some notes. When you then play back the track, the MIDI data goes to the ND2 which will produce sound. If you replace the ND2 with a different synth, the same notes are played, but with different sounds. MIDI is just data: which note is played at which velocity, etcIf you have a problem with setting up MIDI correctly, feel free to ask...Cheers,Albert

title: Left handed drummer ...
post_content: HelloI received my Nord Pad today.All the kits have hihat assigned to channel 3, snare is 2, kick is 1.I unpack the Nord Pad and realize that channel 3 is on the right and channel 2 on its left.Is there a way to assign channel 3 to the upper right pad, channel 2 to the upper middle and channel 1 to upper right ?.

title: RE: Left handed drummer ...
post_content: Hi,Refer to page 23 in the ND2 manual. Pad layout allows you to configure 4 different layout options under system menu button. Your layout is at 2, change it to 1.Another wayis copy an individual channel, paste it to a preferred channel - then save the program. It's a good idea to make a copy of the untampered program first, paste it to a new location - then do your edits. The reason is that let's say you copy your hi-hat sound then paste it where your floor tom was, you'd be replacing floor tom with hi-hat. By keeping a copy of the program you can recall the original floor tom, copy the channel - then paste it to your new location.Cheers lefty!

post_content: Hi,so, you are experiencing low audio levels on your headphones, when you play your ND2 with either mesh drum pads, or the Nord PadDid you try using the [trig/tap] button? First make sure the level of the trigger button is set at 20, try several sounds, a couple of programs. For this test avoid sounds where channel levels are set to lower levels, etc..The [trig/tap] button (when set at 20) triggers sounds at maximum velocity. When I do this, I can't turn the volume knob all the way up, it will simply blow up my headphones and ears. My headphones (BD 770), are 250 Ohms, yours might be louder in theory, they are 38 Ohms (I quickly googled your headphones, not sure though). So be careful!If you do get good levels using the trigger button, your problem is probably on the input side, too weak trigger signals, possibly wrong sensitivity / dynamic curve (!) / trig type settings. Some pads also have a little knob to adjust sensitivity, yours too? You say you get irratic/varying results from your mesh pads, try different cables..If you don't get decent levels with the triggering button, it's either the (headphones-) output, your headphones, or your ears (just kidding)... Since you tried 2 different ND2 units and with both you get the same results, I doubt that they were both defective in the same way, not impossible, just unlikely.. It's a good idea to try different headphones too if possible..Hope this helps!Albert

title: My Ableton setup for the Nord Drum 2
post_content: So I've seen a few posts recently about getting the Nord Drum 2 working with a DAW. I've attached an Ableton Live Pack that I made. I made it with Live 9.1. I'm not sure what the backwards compatibility issues are so if you try it with a different version please reply on this thread and let us all know if it works okay.NOTE: This Ableton Live Pack will most likely NOT work out of the box. You'll need to do some reconfiguring. You will be expected to know how to hook your Nord Drum 2 up to your MIDI interface and how to configure Ableton Live's MIDI settings.Installation1) Download the ZIP file attached to this post and extract it to your local disk.2) Start Ableton Live.3) Double click on the ALP file or select "Install Pack" from the File menu in Ableton Live and find it on your disk.4) In each of the 7 MIDI tracks there are External Instruments, reconfigure each of these for your particular MIDI interface device and ports. I kept the MIDI channels standard so unless you changed them on your Nord Drum 2 there should be nothing to do here.5) Read the notes on the Drum Rack I created below, you may need to reconfigure the Drum Rack to match your Nord Drum 2's settings.6) Make some music.I'm going to explain a couple things just so you're aware of how it works and what the issues are.Here's what the session view looks like:I'll just go from left to right:NordDrum: This is just a grouping of all the tracksND-M-Global: MIDI track with my own Drum Rack made for the Nord Drum 2, sends to the global MIDI channel 10.ND-M-1: MIDI track that sends to Channel 1 on the Nord Drum 2 (MIDI channel 1)ND-M-2: MIDI track that sends to Channel 2 on the Nord Drum 2 (MIDI channel 2)ND-M-3: MIDI track that sends to Channel 3 on the Nord Drum 2 (MIDI channel 3)ND-M-4: MIDI track that sends to Channel 4 on the Nord Drum 2 (MIDI channel 4)ND-M-5: MIDI track that sends to Channel 5 on the Nord Drum 2 (MIDI channel 5)ND-M-6: MIDI track that sends to Channel 6 on the Nord Drum 2 (MIDI channel 6)ND-A: Audio track for receiving a stereo signal from the Nord Drum 2ND-A-Left: Audio track for receiving a mono signal from the left channel of the Nord Drum 2ND-A-Right: Audio track for receiving a mono signal from the right channel of the Nord Drum 2You can use as many or as few of these as you want, I went for the "kitchen sink" approach. For most purposes, only ND-M-Global and ND-A are required for sending MIDI to and recording from the Nord Drum 2.ND-M-1 through 6 are for sending MIDI note or CC data to individual channels on the Nord Drum 2. You can use this to play a channel melodically (though monophonic). You can also use it to change the sound over time using MIDI CC. Refer to the Nord Drum 2 manual to find the table of CC# to parameters, it's all in there.ND-A-Left and ND-A-Right are handy if you want to treat the outputs on the Nord Drum 2 as two mono outputs. That way you can have different effects chains for both. Then on the Nord Drum 2 you change the Pan setting on each Channel to be either 20.0 or 0.20. Don't think of this as "stereo", think of it as two mono outputs. You could for example make a nice bass sound on Channel 6, pan it to the right, pan the other Channels left, then in Ableton put a reverb or an amp or anything else on the right channel to give the bass sound some extra presence or to EQ it, whatever you want to do.Below is the Drum Rack I created:Have a look at the Chain list on the Drum Rack. I set the Play parameters for each drum in the rack to correspond to the MIDI notes I set up on the Nord Drum 2.NOTE: I changed the MIDI notes on my Nord Drum 2 to more closely align with the General MIDI spec for drum machines. If I remember correctly, the default setup for the Nord Drum 2 had the notes an octave higher.Here's what I set all the notes to on my Nord Drum 2 and in Ableton Live:1: 36/C12: 38/D13: 40/E14: 41/F15: 43/G16: 45/A1Please refer to your Nord Drum 2 manual on how to view and change which MIDI notes are assigned to which Channel.Hopefully this is useful to you all. LMK if you have any questions about this pack. However, if you're unfamiliar with Ableton Live I strongly suggest you read the User Manual or make use of the thousands of Ableton Live videos on YouTube to get yourself up to speed.Share and Enjoy.

title: RE: Questions/Problems with my ND2.
post_content: Hi, Lamouette, welcome to the forum!lamouette wrote:When i trig the channel needed (let's say the channel 1) manually with the trigger button on the ND2, i got a certain sound, but when i trig the same channel by my DAW, the sound is thinner, sounding like it don't have release, on fat in it. Any thought on that ?This may have to do with velocity.. By default the trigger button is set to trigger at maximum velocity, make sure your DAW sends notes with velocity 127 if you want to match that.lamouette wrote:i put the global channel off, and only use individual channel 1-1 / 2-2 /3-3 / ....I set the pitch at 60, but i can only play one note, whatever which midi note i set up on the ND2. i have to change the pitch to modify the pitch note, which is quite strange, as no one preset sound like it should sound.....Did i miss something ? or did something wrong ?Hmmm.. Seems like you set it up correctly! It puzzles me why it doesn't work..Let's go through it step by step:-In ND2 MIDI settings switch the global channel off [GL.OF] as you did, just to keep things simple for now,-On channel 1 of the ND2 you select MIDI channel 1 [Ch.1],-For the sake of this test, maybe turn the others off, so for channels 2-6 of the ND2 : select [Ch.OF]-Create a sound on channel 1 with the Tone section alone (/mainly)-(Feel free to add noise, but this is just to keep things clear and simple - and the filter frequency of the noise section can't be controlled with MIDI notes anyway),-On the ND2, set Tone pitch at 60 (which ensures that when you send MIDI note 60 you'll hear 'central' C)..-Make sure your DAW track sends to MIDI channel 1 (only)-You should be able to play a melody now (it's monophonic, so you can't play chords)Apart from the very first OS version (0.92) where it wasn't implemented yet, this should work properly with OS2.x  and the latest OS3.00..Hope this helps..Cheers,Albert

post_content: One remark, If you activate monitoring on the track and keep local control on, then it sounds like "muted" / double trigger.This with Wartaler's help and you should be fine I hope)Enjoy the NS2.( BwS is nice too )

title: RE: Questions/Problems with my ND2.
post_content: Hi,Lamouette, I just read your post again,lamouette wrote:whatever which midi note i set up on the ND2. i have to change the pitch to modify the pitch note, which is quite strangeI think I misunderstood/misread your post when I posted my answer above...The MIDI notes you set in the ND2 only determine which MIDI notes you have to use to trigger the different channels of the ND2 in case you're using the global MIDI channel. In this mode, the pitches you'll hear are the same as with the trigger button. Use velocity 127 to match the level of the trigger button..In case you're using individual MIDI channels, you have to select the appropriate MIDI channel to address the correct channel of the ND2. Any MIDI note can be used. The pitch you'll hear in this mode, now depends on the MIDI note you send to the ND2, so you can even play melodies. If you send MIDI note 60 (!) you will get the same pitch as set with the Pitch parameter on the ND2 (= same as with the trigger button).Use velocity 127 to match the level of the trigger button..So..- If you only want to program beats; use the global MIDI channel + the MIDI notes set in the ND2- If you want to make melodies, control the pitch, or have control over parameters of individual channels; use the individual MIDI channels.. Use MIDI note 60 to get the same pitch as you get with the trigger buttonCheers,Albert

post_content: Hi,In Nord Beat midi setup, channel 6 has its distinct note number ?

title: RE: ND2 hits always channel 6
post_content: HelloYes, the MIDI notes are;#6 69#5 67#4 65#3 64#2 62#1 60The MIDI channel is 10I can also change the #6, but this has no effect...

title: RE: ND2 hits always channel 6
post_content: Hello,Maybe Ch.6 is matched to global channel. Did you try turning off the midi channel for Ch.6?Cheers

title: RE: ND2 hits always channel 6
post_content: Yes, maybe you accidentally set the individual MIDI channel of Channel #6 to MIDI channel 10Channel#6 of your ND2 will then respond to any note sent on MIDI channel 10, so everything from all 6 tracks of the app is sent to Channel#6...Make sure that the individual MIDI channel of Channel#6 is set to off: [Ch.OF](or at least different from MIDI channel 10)Cheers,Albert

title: RE: ND2 hits always channel 6
post_content: No, the MIDI channel for Channel#6 ia 69 like in the nordbeat app. And the global channel is 10, So everything is the same like in the nordbeat sequencer app.Or is there another channel I missed?THX and Heavenicetrip!  Fe/2

title: RE: ND2 hits always channel 6
post_content: Hi!There is global MIDI channel [GL 10], (factory setting is 10), and MIDI note 60, 62, 64, 65, 67, 69 (factory settings)that's properly set up in your Nord Beat app and ND2, as you mentionBUT you can also set an individual MIDI channel [Ch xx] for each of the 6 channels of the ND2, this is a different MIDI setting, just repeat pressing [shift] + [MIDI] until you see [Ch.xx] (where xx is a value between 1-16 or OF).Example of use: when you set MIDI channel 5 [Ch. 5] on channel #1 of your ND2, and connect a MIDI keyboard to your ND2, you can actually play melodies on your ND2! (the output MIDI channel of your keyboard also has to be 5).Another example: when you have a beat set up in your sequencer (eg cubase, not the Nord Beat app), and you want to create a slow filter sweep on the snare drum sound only (!). Noise filter frequency can be controlled with MIDI CC 14. You can use the individual MIDI channel function to control the filter on just the snare drum sound ..But there is no need to set individual MIDI channel(s) when you're only using the Nord Beat app... best to switch it off..What I mean is that you maybe accidentally set MIDI channel 10 as individual MIDI channel on channel#6 of your ND2,To check this: press [shift] + [MIDI] on your ND2 until you see [Ch.xx], (xx is a value/OF), then go to channel#6 on your ND2, the value for xx should be OF (off)- (or any value EXCEPT 10)

title: RE: ND2 hits always channel 6
post_content: Wow, thanks for this deep explanation, I see there is still more possible with the ND2 than I knowAnd you're right, the Channel#6 was on Ch.10, so I set it to Ch.OF. And now everything runs fineTHX and Heavenicetrip!  Fe/2

title: RE: Ableton exporting midi file Nord drum 2
post_content: MIDI isperformancedata, not audio. You can only hear the noise the synth makes if you record the audio stream (an audio track), or in real time if you set the MIDI channel in the sequence to control (play) the synth.

title: RE: Ableton exporting midi file Nord drum 2
post_content: Hi!You have to connect the audio outputs of the ND2 to an audio interface/ soundcard on your computerIn ableton you'll have to set up a stereo audio track with the audio interface /soundcard as source/input, then record the sound of the ND2 onto that audio track.. I'm not familiar with ableton to help you in detail, but that is roughly what you should do..Cheers,Albert

title: RE: play a sequence and recording live over it
post_content: Hello,In that video he is not recording live. He starts by playing the pads then starts a pre-programmed sequence on the Nordbeat 2 app. It is possible to record the midi from the pads to a daw like logic, ableton etc by routing the midi out from the ND2 to usb on a computer. Nordbeat isn't capable of recording midi pad performance. Note also that the "infinite repeat" feature he uses at the beginning of the pad jam is from an older ND2 operating system that is unfortunately no longer available (although you can still set repeat amount for long increments, just not infinite).Cheers,Nate

title: Is it possible to import ddrum sound sample to Nord2??
post_content: Is it possible to import ddrum sound sample to Nord2?? I`d like to create a simple drum kit in one module. Ddrum and Nord drum are both Clavia products. So does anybody know if it is possible to import ddrum sound samples into Nord drum 2 modul?Asked many users but found no answer yet. I appreciate your help

title: RE: Is it possible to import ddrum sound sample to Nord2??
post_content: Hi Macwino,ddrum WAS a Clavia product, but that was many years ago and they are no longer affiliated with one another.ddrum samples are...samples.  The Nord Drum and Nord Drum 2 are synths and are not sample-capable.In other words, no.Bless,Pablo

title: RE: Is it possible to import ddrum sound sample to Nord2??
post_content: What Pablo said. But there is also the option of using the nord pad as a midi controller for triggering the samples. Essentially you will need to put the ND 2 into midi local off (in shift midi options lo.off) and then have the midi ports connected to the sample module (ddrum). Set-up the midi channel to 10 and away you go. I can give more details if you like but normally the issues are on the sample module end as they are all different. I use this set-up on occasion when I have the need to play samples and it works great - you can use any sample source you like such as a laptop/DAW, mpc, drum modules etc. Keep in mind that the ND 2 is a synth so when in midi slave mode you can't have some pads allocated to the synth and the others to samples as the midi option is a global instead of per channel option.

title: RE: Is it possible to import ddrum sound sample to Nord2??
post_content: Can we please call this a Nord Drum 2 (ND2) instead of Nord 2.  There are other Nord models which also use that number...What Stoat said...except that I believe he is wrong about the lack of ability to mix 'n match onboard ND2 sounds with samples in the same program.  It should be possible to program an onboard ND2 sound to be silent so that when it's trigger note is struck it generates no audio output and only the sample is heard.  On other notes where you want only synth sound, load no sample (or don't program one for that note).  Of course, also possible to layer both together...Bless,Pablo

title: RE: Is it possible to import ddrum sound sample to Nord2??
post_content: Nice workaround Pablo! I'll try that out later today, also I normally call it ND2, must have been pre-morning coffee brain!

title: ND2 bank change from Max 7
post_content: Hello,I'm working with MAX/MSP and ND2 and trying to perform a bank change in ND2. I'm trying to work out the two values requested; LSB and MSB. I've tried several combinations to make the bank change but still have not response. I've tried these combination as put in the manual:CC 0, value 0 - LSB- (I'm just not sure which value to use in LSB, I read somewhere that the correct value is '0')CC 32, value 4 (bank 5, the one I want) -MSB-I read somewhere that program change trigger the bank also. So far I got no response from the machine. Any ideas?Another question:Are these values (LSB and MSB) to send one after the other on the same message, or one after the other in time?Thanks a lot!

title: RE: ND2 bank change from Max 7
post_content: Hi!Check a couple of things in the MIDI settings:First, check if the global ('GL') MIDI channel matches the one you send your CCs or PCs to,Second, make sure the ND2 receives CCs or PCs, check the following MIDI settings, (taken from the manual) :PC - Program Change can be set to Off, Send only, Receive only and both Send and Receive. Set this to receive if you want to change the programs on the Nord Drum 2 from a MIDI controller or a sequencer.Range: PC.Of, PC.S, PC.r, PC.Sr    (in your case choose one of the latter two options)CC - Control Change can be set to Off, Send only, Receive only and both Send and Receive. Set this to receive if you want to change parameters on the Nord Drum 2 from a MIDI controller or a sequencer.Range: CC.Of, CC.S, CC.r, CC.Sr.   (in your case choose one of the latter two options)CC Bank Select requires a pair of LSB and MSB values (Least Significant - and Most Significant Byte) to be acknowledged. Transmit the LSB value first, then the MSB value.Hope this helps,Albert

title: RE: Nord Drum 2 vs Maschine Mikro
post_content: Hi Orcoaffamato!Difficult to answer, depends on what you want to do and expect from the units,I don't know the Maschine Mikro at all, just had a brief look on the website, it looks like (a controller for?) a drum machine/sequencer with a lot of (sampled?) sounds.The Nord drum is a great sounding virtual analog drum synth, there's no sequencer on board.. It can be controlled with the Nord Pad, drum pads/triggers, or through MIDI (eg a sequencer).If the Maschine can be used as a (standalone?) MIDI sequencer or controller, it would be a great companion to the ND2.In fact, any hardware/software sequencer will. The Nord Drum2 is 'only' a sound module, but a very cool one!Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Nord Drum 2 vs Maschine Mikro
post_content: What @wartaler said. The ND2 is a stellar sounding drum synth which requires external hardware to trigger its sounds. If you have an iPad and an iOS device-compatible hub like the i ConnectMIDI ( imo both are essential tools in the world of today's electronic music-making) you can get pretty far with crafting beats. There are a number of fantastic apps (ie Patterning, Nord Beat...) out there that can control the Nord Drum and the results are excellent.So the ND2 is not an "all in one box" type of instrument, but an awesome one at that. Just my two cents.

title: Record with the Nord drum 2 & Nord Pad
post_content: Hello,I've had the Nord drum 2 and Nord Pad for quite some time now. But I am a drummer and am really not used to record with MIDI, this is a complete new world for me. I've been losing alot of time trying to figure out how to properly record my Nord Drum in Cubase 7 Elements. Even though I read through the manual of the Nord Drum2, it confuses me instead of clarifying the matter.I wish someone could help me and share how he/she records it and how I should proceed. Is it possible to record on 6 different channels? I have an audio interface which is the Audio Kontrol 1. I would like to record using the pad.If you can refer me to any tutorial which would help me that would also be really kind.Thanks.

title: RE: Record with the Nord drum 2 & Nord Pad
post_content: Hi Turbulz!Connect both MIDI in and out of your ND2 to the output and input of your interface respectivelyIn Cubase create a MIDI track with the correct ports of your MIDI interface selected..Make sure the MIDI channel of your track in Cubase matches the global channel set on the ND2*Select the track and arm recording (red circle) and engage monitoring (little speaker)some basic Cubase stuff in this video:*on the ND2 go to the MIDI menu, press [SHIFT]+[MIDI] once, or a couple of times, until you see GL.XX (where XX= the global MIDI channel the ND2 sends and receives on, a value between 1 and 16, which can be set with the knob)The MIDI channel here should match  with the channel set in Cubase in the track settingsThe notes you play on the Pad will be transmitted via MIDI to your computer, and Cubase should be able to record these notes. Cubase will also directly send the notes back to the ND2, so that you will hear what you're playing. To avoid double triggering problems, set 'local off' on your ND2 - this will internally disconnect the Pad from the ND2 sounds.press [SHIFT]+[MIDI] until you see 'Lo.On' - rotate the knob and set it to 'Lo.OF'You should be able to see incoming MIDI messages in Cubase whenever you hit a Pad, and also hear what you're doing.If so... just hit the record button and ... rock!Just remember to switch local back on after your session, and the ND2 is no longer connected to your computer and Cubase .. 'Lo.On'Hope this helps..Cheers,Albert

title: RE: CC changes not sent on individual MIDI channels
post_content: Hi!Yes, the ND2 only sends from the global channel, ...I think the indiv MIDI channels were introduced to control the parameters of each of the 6 channels of the ND2 from a controller or DAW, it's not much of a controller itself of course, with only one knob. You can only change one parameter of 1 of the 6 channels at the same time anyway. When you're recording CC changes on a sequencer, you just have to set the desired MIDI channel there to send it back to the ND2Why do you want it to send CC's from the indiv channel? What are you planning to do / what's your setup?Cheers,Albert

post_content: Ok! Yes I understand!Great you're making a Lemur controller!Yes, CC70 seems the only solution then, should work if you select a channel with the selection buttons. Making it more complexPerhaps making a unidirectional live editor/controller with its own library on board is easier,but then you should select 'local off' and only allow the ND2 to receive CCs, to avoid accidental changes, not very handy eithergood luck, keep us posted!Albert

title: RE: My "totally doable" ND2 OS update wishlist
post_content: Stoat wrote:I also have a few which could be done software:2) midi cc step sizes are more logical (like 1, 2, 3, 4, instead of 0, 3, 6, 8, 11)I do not have an ND2, but a similar situation happens in the NS2, for example, for the LFO frequency and other scales that are continuous but are addressed by a discrete encoder.Most likely this is the result of the number of encoding positions being smaller than the available values (a look up table).Renumbering so they look logical but not matching the value they address would be even more confusing...Let's say you see 21 but the output value is 37... it would be pretty difficult to set (or get close to) adesiredvalue, by looking at the display. At least now you have an idea of where you are in cc value and you know that not all values are possible due to the encoder resolution.Of course they could increase the encoder resolution to span all possible values if the scale is also discrete.

title: Hand Claps
post_content: Hello!Can the Nord Drum 2 simulate hand claps well?  I haven't heard many demos with the Nord and claps.  Thanks for any info.

title: RE: Hand Claps
post_content: Hi Ricoche,The ND2 can simulate claps quite well. In the noise envelope section there's Attack Mode which will allow you to choose between traditional AD, cyclic LFO's  or Clap mode.  There's 9 clap settings (or reverb phase lengths) that get combined after a sawtooth wave(s) (defined by attack/rate amount). The overall length of the clap sound can be adjusted with the noise decay. Additionally the noise decay can be dynamically controlled (with dec lo amount) although for a clap sound a single decay should do the trick. (See pages 16-18 in the manual)I dig the clap sounds, really easy to dial inCheers,Nate

title: RE: Unable to connect Nord Drum 2 Manager
post_content: Hi,Quite frustrating I can imagine!There are several things that can go wrong, from badly made MIDI interfaces, software, drivers, to cables. Perhaps above posters all have slightly different problems. Stoat, if I remember correctly, got it solved after he found out one of his cables was faulty. (Your cables are fine I bet, but it's always a good idea to test a couple)I'm currently on Win8, but it also worked fine on my Win7 (64) system with an e-mu xmidi 1x1, using windows' own usb-midi driver. Maybe the Nord software is buggy in some way, but it does  seem to work on some systems.I think it could be a specific combination of hardware, software & drivers, complex stuff to figure out what is going wrong.Some thoughts:As you say, sysex transfer is more sensitive for problems because of the larger amount of data/time. Although your setup works with other software sending sysex data, maybe Nord uses a slightly higher tranfer rate than your setup can handle. (there is no way to limit the rate is there?) (and: don't get me wrong, not saying you have a bad interface etc.!)And, Or, given the crashes, perhaps the ESI driver and the Nord software don't like each other much. (you can tell I'm not a computer expert). Have you tried updating the ESI driver?Best of luck, hope you get working soon, keep us posted!Albert

post_content: Hi ballener!I'm quite confident that it's possible,I don't own a SPD-SX, but I had a quick look in the manual, page 67You can set a global MIDI channel, and for each pad define a note number the SPD transmits from the MIDI OUT port. title: ND2 Program Change (Midi)
post_content: DearI am close to buy a Nord Drum 2 but not 100% sure if this little unit will meet my needs.As a ‘one-man’ acoustic guitar player/singer some songs needs a rhythm backing track. I plan to ‘sequence’ ND2 with the iPad (Dum Beat App) or Mac running Ableton LIVE.I was wondering it’s possible to force Ableton LIVE to send MIDI ‘Program Change’ to individual presets.Example:CHANNEL 1: Bank 1, Program 12, Sound from pad 4CHANNEL 2: Bank 2, Program 3, Sound from pad 2…. up to six…As far as I understand, I can can copy/paste sounds from other presets to the user banks (5-8) and send Program Change to load the preset, but my question is different from that.Thank you for your information.Best regardsRoman

title: RE: ND2 Program Change (Midi)
post_content: Hi Roman,The ND2 can store 400 programs (organised in 8 banks of 50 programs),A program consists of 6 sounds / channels, eg a drum kit with a kick, snare, hihat, and 3 tomsIf I understand your question correctly, you want to know if it's possible to swiftly replace the sound of one, or a couple of the 6 channels, with other sounds.It is possible to copy and paste a sound from one program to another, 'manually' - but not thru MIDIHowever, thru MIDI you can control all sound parameters of each of the 6 channels of the ND2, which might help to achieve what you want. Although I'm not sure how quick the ND2 will respond if you change a lot of parameters to completely reprogram sounds 'at once'Alternatively you could store several variations of one program. then you'll simply have to send program changes. Might work better..So I think there are a couple of ways to achieve what you want, how well it will actually work in practice, to quickly do program changes between 2 beats, depends on how quick the ND2 responds, and the tempo of your track, not sure -anyone else?Cheers,Albert

title: RE: ND2 Program Change (Midi)
post_content: Dear AlbertThank you very much for your detailed Information.This is exactly what I was asking for and the ND2 should work within my enviroment.Again, thank you Albert!Best regardsRoman

title: RE: Nord drum2 + Nord pad + kick pedal
post_content: Hello!You can connect the Nord Pad and a bass drum trigger* at the same time, however, note the following:The ND2 has 6 channels, on each you can program a different sound. The Nord Pad has 6 square pads that correspond with these 6 channels. Please note that if you connect a drum trigger next to the Nord Pad, you won't get a 7th bonus channel/ sound, unfortunately.With both the Nord Pad and a bassdrum trigger connected, you still play channels 1-6 as usual with the Nord Pad, and with the bassdrum trigger you control ...channel 1 (!)   So channel 1 of the ND2 can be played/triggered by both the bassdrum trigger, and with the Nord Pad, 'at the same time', - but not literally at the same time:Each of the 6 channels of the ND2 is monophonic, so you won't hear 2 bassdrum sounds (or whatever sound is programmed on channel 1) at the same time - in case you hit the corresponding pad on the Nord Pad, and your bassdrum trigger simultaneously.I usually only play the 5 other pads on the Nord Pad, and avoid the one that corresponds with channel 1, because I want to control channel 1 with my foot.*a bassdrum trigger, bass drum pad , 'silent pedal' , or a normal drum pad will all workhave a look at the video featuring Gavin Harrison here :http://www.nordkeyboards.com/products/nord-drum-2Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Nord drum2 + Nord pad + kick pedal
post_content: Thanks, exactly what I was wondering & plan to do.Thanks again!

title: RE: Nord drum2 + Nord pad + kick pedal
post_content: Thanks Albert for a more detailed explanation regarding Nord Pad + kick!Personally, I like to play all 6 Nord Pads in addition to playing an acoustic bass trigger. It allows me to play some quick "double bass" phrases without using a double pedal. It's usually in the form of a left stick hit(I play right-handed with the Nord Pad left of the hi-hats, like Gavin's set-up)on the "a" of 4 just before the downbeat then hitting the bass trigger on the 1. You can create some fat swings!

title: Max potential channels of ND2

Ideally, I would be setting up hi hat loops and playing along on the Nord Pad and kick trigger.Many thanks in advance.Sig.

title: RE: Max potential channels of ND2
post_content: Hi Sig,1.) The ND2 has 6 total channels. With the Nord Pad (uses ethernet cable) connected you can add a 7th(1/4") trigger to Ch.1 on the ND2. It will double whatever sound is assigned to Ch. 1.2.) When Nord Beat is playing the ND2 you can "jam" along with pads however Nord Beat isn't capable of recording/overdubbing midi. Also, the 6 ND2 channels are monophonic so it's possible to cancel out some sounds if you're playing the pads on the same channel & at the same time as the Nord Beat.Have fun!!Nate

title: RE: Max potential channels of ND2

title: Nord Drum 1 with Ableton

Would you please help me?P.S.: I'm not mother-tongue English, so sorry if it sounds weird sometimes.

title: RE: Nord Drum 1 with Ableton
post_content: Ableton (or any DAW) will never 'recognise' any MIDI device plugged into the Scarlett interface: by that I mean it will not appear in Ableton as a "Nord Drum" - the only thing Ableton will recognise is the Scarlett.  Instead, set the MIDI I/O in Ableton to send to the Scarlett on channel 10 (or any number of your choice - i use 10 for drums) and set the Drum to receive on channel 10.I don't fully understand which bit you are having the problem with, but given that your 2nd option appears to work, if you plug the Drum into the MIDI THRU of the keyboard, instead of MIDI OUT, then it should receive the same MIDI data sent to your keyboard.If this works for you, you can set the Drum to receive on a different channel number, then send the pattern to that MIDI channel in the Ableton Live I/O

title: RE: Sequencing with Nord Drum 2
post_content: You misunderstand what Nord Beat 2 app is -- it is not a "sequencer," it is a "step-sequencer."  These are two very different things.  Once you have spent some with the app you should begin to see how it works, what is going on.  You can do lots of fun things with it, but it will not record sequences in the manner you suggest.  This is not a mini-looper or Ableton Live clone.Bless,Pablo

I like the idea of positional sensing, like Roland's 'supernatural' units have, or the Mandala multi-zone pad. Some other aspects of Rolands technology I like as well; the way the units respond to repeated hits on a cymbal pad - making the cymbal sound build up /swell.. I'm not tempted to buy Roland gear because, well, it's grey, boring, sample based, and too expensive for me anyway..I don't think it's feasible for Nord to incorporate such technologies, even if they wanted to - probably heavily patented to start with, .But I do like to fantasize about the combination of such technologies and synthesized sounds..For the rest some minor things, perhaps in Noise section uncouple envelops for filter and amp - and perhaps adding more envelop parameters, or LFO in the Tone section, reinstate Click decay as in ND1I hope they won't go into multi-velocity-layered-samples, but perhaps being able to use samples a bit like it's done in the wave could be fun....just some .. fantasiesAlbert

title: RE: Wood Block Setting
post_content: Sorry for the late reply,I just remembered that on a ND2 with an older OS version installed, banks made on a later OS (my bank is made in OS3.00) will appear blank, (programs will sound as init) - the OS is displayed briefly when you power on your ND2...So:- If your ND2 has an older OS installed, download the latest from the Nord website:http://www.nordkeyboards.com/downloads/nord-drum-2- connect both MIDI in and out, and run the updater on your computer,- When/If you have the latest OS installed, and the bank still appears blank after uploading, perhaps delete it from your computer and download it again, also try some of the banks from the Nord website -- Maybe also try if a fresh copy of Nord Drum 2 Manager v1.00 helps:http://www.nordkeyboards.com/downloads/ ... -2-manager- If the OS update, or bank uploads fail, then perhaps your combination of computer OS, drivers, and MIDI interface can't handle the SysEx data stream to the ND2  - I think -- (in that case you need to retry by using a different computer system / other MIDI interface)Hope it helps,Cheers,Albert

title: Drum 2 and sampling

title: RE: Drum 2 and sampling
post_content: Welcome! Indeed the ND2 is capable of sampling and its pretty straight forward. As long as you can connect it via midi to the sample source like a macbook, put it in midi local mode off which is shift+lower parameter+midi then scroll through to Lo.On and turn the knob to Lo.off.  At this stage you can now set the sample source to midi notes for each pad. Midi notes for the pads are by default C5, D5, E5, F5, G5, A5 and they correspond with the 1-6 default layout.I hope that is simple enough, I could prob explain easier but I just finished work. The ND2 is real easy to trigger samples once you know what to do

title: RE: Drum 2 and sampling

title: RE: Drum 2 and sampling
post_content: Thats all good. Triggering from the ND2 sends a midi note so the type of sample (and its limitations) depend entirely on what your sample source is. For instance, in Ableton you can trigger drum samples via drum rack or configure it to trigger an entire song.The set-up you choose really depends on your needs but to trigger samples keep in mind the sample source is what is generating the sound not the ND2. So a usb-midi from ND2 into your macbook and then audio-out from the macbook would work - just make sure you buy a reputable midi-usb converter (cheap ones cause issues).I have used Ableton and FLstudio so far and both work great. If you want a detailed breakdown step by step Im happy to help, just need to know what your set-up is and software etc. (although I am only familiar with ableton and flstudio) Hope that helps - I recommend reading the manual time and time again, always finding new tricks in it

title: RE: Drum 2 and sampling
post_content: You can't play samples from the Nord sample library with the ND2,  it cannot record or play back recorded audio samples, unlike eg the SPD -S . but the ND2 can mimic timpani quite well!You can only connect one Nord Pad, or 6 single drum pads,To play marimba you can connect a MIDI keyboard, or a MIDI device with multiple pads, but it will be a monophonic marimba

title: RE: Drum 2 and sampling
post_content: Deja vu...general-synthesizers-keyboards-forum-f6 ... tml#p54819Some confusion seems to be around, so at risk of stating the obvious this may help:an instrument which supportsSampling:  is able to record, (and often edit) sounds and play them back.an instrument which is aSynth: generates sounds by combining, shaping and filtering simple electronically generated waveforms into more complex sounds.an instrument which supportsMIDI IN: is able to have its own sounds triggered/played by another external devicean instrument which supportsMIDI OUT: is able to trigger the sounds on another device (which might do sampling) - it may or may not be capable of making any sounds on its own (e.g. a drum pad, controller, sequencer etc.)The ND2 does only the last 3 things.There are devices which do less (or all) of the above, (and tbh there are plenty of MIDI devices that have MIDI IN but don't make a sound at all), but hopefully this clarifies the differences for those that were unsure, and is not meant to be patronising in any way.

title: RE: Drum 2 and sampling
post_content: Stoat wrote:Just following on from this: does anyone know of a compact sampler with midi in and audio out?Even though it's meant for dance/electro music production, the Korg Electribe ESX is a fun and versatile piece of gear. It has MIDI in out and thru, and some good sample tweaking abilities, and a basic sequencer fwiw.The onboard pads are not velocity sensitive, but it responds to velocity via midi. There is a new ESX 2 which was recently announced, not sure if it's actually available but retailers are listing it - it's pretty compact. The old ESX is built like a tank, so worth picking up on eBay. It comes in two flavours - the original one had a SmartMedia memory card slot, and they replace this with SD cards in later models. aside from that there is no difference between them, and you can pick up the older models and some SM cards on ebay at a good price... ( they also work with XD cards and an adapter)Anyway, maybe of interest.

title: RE: Nord Drum freezing while updating :o
post_content: I've had issues with updating synths via Sysex before (don't have a Nord Drum though).I was able to update my Blofeld with my Cakewalk UM-3G, but not via the built-in USB-to-MIDI function or via my M-Audio FastTrack Ultra. post_content: Hi,I'm waiting for the delivery of piezo transducers : 2 € each, and jack socket : 0.80 € each.The little wood box comes from a shop in France names "Cultura" :  2.99 €.The little white pad is 0.05 € (2 € for a set of 40).Add some double side adhesive to fix the piezzo inside the box.Add some wires ( from a dead electronic device )=> That makes a trigger for approximately 6 €.( and I do some paint with my daughter, which is unvaluable )Tools needed :A driller, 16 mm flat drill burr, a 10 mm normal drill burrA soldering ironIt's simple to make and requires no skill, and little money.Connected to a mic input it sounds like a kick drum stompbox, I'm looking for a second hand Nord Drum.I really encourage everyone playing with a stompbox and hope this can help someone into making one.collage_pad.JPG (450.23 KiB) Viewed 2299 timespercage.JPG (282.16 KiB) Viewed 2299 timesjack_socket.JPG (253.44 KiB) Viewed 2299 timessoldering.JPG (265.67 KiB) Viewed 2299 timesatelier.JPG (1.06 MiB) Viewed 2299 timesCheers,F.

title: Nord Drum : custom hardware kit ?
post_content: Can someone please confirm if one can plug a dynamic microphone into a ND, as a trigger ?Can it be calibrated in order to get full velocity range ?Has someone already done any custom triggers/kit for the ND ?

title: RE: Nord Drum : custom hardware kit ?
post_content: I doubt it... but I'm not 100% sure, why would you want to use a dynamic mic?A piezo will definitely work, drum triggers and pads are built around piezos - and you can buy them cheaplyfrom what I've read about them they differ greatly from dynamic mics, not only in how they work, output voltage & impedance are much higher,However, if you do want use a dynamic mic, you perhaps first need to amplify the signal with a pre-amp - e.g. on a mixing desk, then use the direct-outs(line of reasoning: audio outputs of drum machines can also be used to trigger the ND ) but I'm not an engineer so perhaps best if someone else answers your question before you fry anything (!!)And perhaps I'm wrong in assuming it won't work directly, -anyone?Piezos however will definitely work, check these links about DIY triggers and pads, see what piezos they're using and go from there:http://www.edrums.info/http://www.soundonsound.com/sos/apr11/a ... -happy.htmhttp://www.drummagazine.com/plugged-in/ ... -triggers/Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Nord Drum : custom hardware kit ?
post_content: Thanks very much AlbertThe edrum website is very informative.I'll post back pics of a kick pedal I made using a piezo.It's acoustic, I have it under my keyboard and plugged into mic channel on a mixer.I think I just have to plug it into a Nord Drum 2 to make a foot/kick trigger.Imho Nord should communicate more about compatible triggers.

title: RE: Nord Drum : custom hardware kit ?
post_content: ArfNtz wrote:I'll post back pics of a kick pedal I made using a piezo. It's acoustic, I have it under my keyboard and plugged into mic channel on a mixer.That would be great, - interested! so you are now using the audio from the piezo right? -just one remark on that: piezos require very high impedance inputs, (at least 1MOhms I read), otherwise they will sound thin, because impedance mismatch here causes high pass filtering,there are some very cool websites on how to build your own very high impedance piezo pre-amp for audio recordings - hiZ instrument inputs also work ok-ish - how does your bass drum sound thru the mic input?I think I just have to plug it into a Nord Drum 2 to make a foot/kick trigger.Yes, you can connect this piezo directly to your ND2, you'll just need to experiment with threshold and sensitivity settings to suppress spontaneous and double triggering etc. If you want more triggers and don't feel like soldering more piezos, Korg makes some piezo clips that might be fun with the ND2, they come with their 'cliphit' drum-blob - but are also sold separately - and are cheaper than the ddrum and roland drum triggersImho Nord should communicate more about compatible triggers.Here's what they mention on the website: "The 6 generic inputs can be connected to almost anything you like, electronic drum pads, acoustic drum triggers, a contact microphone, the outputs of an old drum machine and much more. Setting the Input and Threshold is easy and we’ve added a selection of presets for popular pads and triggers. " - I agree they don't give detailed technical data, but I tried many types of triggers and contact microphones, and they all worked fine with the ND2 after some tweaking...Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Nord Drum : custom hardware kit ?
post_content: Got rehearsal tonight, so I'll post pics tomorrow.Indeed I push down the the Hi-Z (guitar) button on the mixer (Mackie 402VLZ4).I chained 2 piezo.It's interesting to have it acoustic because you can tweak the sound with different material / hammer.In short, I made a custom hammer with a tennis ball and some neoprene (from a sea-surfing suite).Synth possibilities is nice, but if the ND2 had simple sample playback capabilites then I'd be less hesitant ...I could still use the midi out to trigger samples ...  but I'd like to keep things simple, a NE4D, a foot pedal, maybe one drum module.I was too newbie to understand the lines on Nord's website, I was missing examples or compatibility list, I feel that we're a bit left to trial & error method, but it's ok now.

title: RE: How often does your ND2 become hung/stuck?
post_content: Hi Ilya!I never had anything like that...You said it occurred at least once, how many times did it occur already?what is your setup, connected MIDI devices/computer software/app/MIDI clock setup/..? did it occur right after switching the ND2 on?/can you relate it to something you did; can you trigger it by (dis-)connecting something, sending something specific thru MIDI etc,if it seems so, maybe some of us can try to reproduce it....or is it just randomly occurring?Cheers,Albert

title: RE: How often does your ND2 become hung/stuck?
post_content: Thanks for your reply.It happened just once so far. I was using NI Maschine controller to send midi messages to ND2.The only thing unusual I guess is that it happened after the update to v.3 (not immediately though) and before the first restart. So hopefully it was a one-off glitch... Let see how it behaves from now on.Good to know that others do not have such problems.

title: RE: How often does your ND2 become hung/stuck?
post_content: Ok,So, after the ND2 rebooted itself as final step of the update sequence, it worked for a while, then crashed? - I can't remember exactly but mine didn't crash, most probably I unplugged it right after the update completedSo far, the only problem some people here reported with OS3.00 is this:http://www.norduserforum.com/nord-drum- ... t7166.html(when a MIDI clock signal is fed to the MIDI IN of the ND2 while booting, it will be deaf to any incoming MIDI messages - not the same at all, but perhaps good to be aware of when making connections...)well....hopefully it will just never happen again..Cheers,Albert

title: Nord Drum 2 Program Organization?
post_content: Just got the Nord Drum 2, and I love it! Except for one thing...Organizing my sounds is a real pain. I don't like how you can only copy and paste one sound at a time instead of a whole kit, I wish I could move programs easier from bank to bank. I wish I could visually see lists of my banks as well, like you can with all other Nord products. We live in 2015. Clavia hasn't thought of this? I understand the Nord Drum is fairly new, so maybe they're getting to making all of this better? Anyone know anything about this? I would love for the Nord Drum 2 to be easier to organize!

title: RE: Nord Drum 2 Program Organization?
post_content: Hi Phillip,To copy one program (kit) to another location press SHIFT+STORE (program number will start blinking) then dial in the desired program number, then press STORE again, the program is then copied to that location..One difference with Nord products like the Stage and Electro 5, is that the Nord Drum 2 programs/kits can't be given names, without program names I think it's difficult to make librarian software,The display of ND2 isn't really made for displaying program names I think, perhaps a nice idea for a ND3,EDIT: current Nord Lead, and older Electro models also can't display program names, but the names do appear in the Sound Manager -So, if ND2 still has some memory left for storing names, and can be made compatible with the Sound Manager - that would be nice indeed, perhaps we will see it in a future update - who knows!Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Nord Drum 2 Program Organization?
post_content: You could always use a sysex librarian and dump one program at a time from your nord drum 2 to your computer and name the files. This combined with a filemanaging system (for example Finder in OSX) would be sufficient for organizing your programs?

title: RE: Nord Drum 2 Program Organization?
post_content: Yes, I agree, although the Soundmanager is more efficient and user friendly, it's not much of a hassle to do it that way either..

title: Set up for ND2, Nord Pad, NB2, and iRig Pro for Dummies
post_content: Hi all! I just got a Nord Drum 2, a Nord Pad, iRig Pro, and downloaded Nord Beat 2 to my iPad. I need a super simple explanation of how I should set it up and if I need any cables that aren't included with the products.Based on what was included with the iRig, the only set up that made any sense to me at all was to connect the ND2's midi out to the midi in on the iRig. Then the iRig's out can plug to the iPad via Thunder. When I have it set like this, the iRig's light shows that when I hit the Nord Pad, it's receiving signals, but I don't get anything in the headphones from the iPad/Nord Beat (whether they are plugged into the ND2 or the iPad). I know I've got it set up wrong, but the only other configuration is midi in on both the ND2 and the iRig and that doesn't make sense either. Do I need additional cables so I can go from the iRig's midi out to the ND2's midi in? But then I also need another additional cable to go from the iPad (Thunder) into the iRig's input (midi, 1/4", or XLR). It surprises me that none of the cables that come with the iRig could be what I need.I'm completely confused by this thing. I thought it would be plug and play. If there's other set up, I'd appreciate the basic steps, too.Thanks in advance for any help!

title: RE: Set up for ND2, Nord Pad, NB2, and iRig Pro for Dummies
post_content: Hi! Welcome to the forum!I had to look up the specs of your iRig Pro, it seems it only has MIDI IN. So on your iPad, you can only receive notes coming from your Nord Drum2 when you hit the pads...In order to send notes to your ND2, e.g. playing with the Nord Beat app & have your ND2 produce sound, you'll need an interface that has a MIDI OUT port.The iRig MIDI 2 is a good option, -  you'll also need two regular MIDI cables, best to buy these at a proper music store (local or web)Alternatively, find yourself any simple but decent USB-MIDI interface that supports Core-MIDI, for example the E-MU Xmidi1x1 works well and isn't too expensive -In order to use such a USB-MIDI interface with your iPad, you'll also need the camera connection kit (30-pin-to-female-USB or Lightning-to-female-USB) -if you're tempted to look for cheaper USB-MIDI interfaces, check this thread to see which interfaces perhaps to avoid:http://www.norduserforum.com/nord-drum- ... 53-10.htmlCheers,Albert

title: RE: Set up for ND2, Nord Pad, NB2, and iRig Pro for Dummies
RE: Set up for ND2, Nord Pad, NB2, and iRig Pro for Dummies
post_content: Thanks for the replies! I think I'll get the iRig midi 2. Albert had said I'd need 2 midi/midi cables, but in the video in the 2nd reply, they only have the iRig connected to the iPad (using the cable that comes with the iRig) and a midi-midi from the iRig midi out to the ND2 midi in. So, if I buy the iRig midi 2, I only need to buy one extra midi-to-midi cable to complete this set up?I appreciate the clear answers! Great forum

title: RE: Set up for ND2, Nord Pad, NB2, and iRig Pro for Dummies
post_content: Hi!Well, I think the iRig MIDI 2 package doesn't include the MIDI cables you'll need, please double check that first -.. the above video shows the original iRig MIDI - which indeed comes with cables for MIDI in and out, that look similar to the cable you got with your iRig Pro...These cables however are different from the ones you'll need with the iRig MIDI 2...You'll need cables like this:http://www.thomann.de/gb/the_sssnake_sk ... e8fb8cd421And you'll at least need one, but I'd get 2 if I were you, - check your local dealer and find some of decent quality, and appropriate length..One note on the original iRig MIDI; it's still being sold, much smaller, and cheaper than the second version..However, if I understand correctly - you have an Apple device with the Lightning connector - and in all the images I can find of the smaller iRig MIDI, it has the 30-pin Apple connector - so you'd also need to buy the Lightning-to-30-pin converter to use it...The iRig MIDI 2 however, is more flexible and versatile than the original, comes with a Lightning cable and a USB cable - (30pin cable is sold separately) - but as far as I can tell -  MIDI cables are not included -seehttp://www.ikmultimedia.com/products/irigmidi2/Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Set up for ND2, Nord Pad, NB2, and iRig Pro for Dummies
post_content: wartaler wrote:The iRig MIDI 2 however, is more flexible and versatile than the original, comes with a Lightning cable and a USB cable - (30pin cable is sold separately) - but as far as I can tell -  MIDI cables are not included -I can confirm that, 'cause I own an iRig MIDI 2.

title: RE: Set up for ND2, Nord Pad, NB2, and iRig Pro for Dummies
post_content: Hi,I use ND2 and NB2 in Ableton with iRig midi 2.How could I make NB2 to control all the 6 ND2 channel sounds at the same time? Because now it controls only one...please help me

title: RE: Set up for ND2, Nord Pad, NB2, and iRig Pro for Dummies
post_content: Hi Kavinski!Nord beat 2 in Ableton?I'm not familiar with Ableton, I'll just go through the MIDI setup I use in combination with the NB2 app:1) On the ND2 match the global MIDI channel [GL.XX]* with the MIDI channel in the app (go to Menu > MIDI setup, check MIDI channel) -2) Whilst in the MIDI setup menu of the app: check if the note numbers listed (e.g. #1: 60,  #2: 62,  #3: 64, etc...) - match the MIDI note numbers set in the ND2 : in this example: [n. 60]* for channel 1, [n. 62]* for channel 2, etc...3) Set the individual MIDI channels in the ND2 to off:  [Ch.OF]*  (on each of the 6 channels) - because you don't need this option in combination with the app,...If it still doesn't work, there may be other issues, let me know...Cheers,Albert*press [SHIFT] + [MIDI] - once, or more times, then use the knob to set the value

title: RE: Set up for ND2, Nord Pad, NB2, and iRig Pro for Dummies
post_content: Thank you Albert,I think it works

title: NORD DRUM GOOD FOR INTHE AIR TONIGHT?
post_content: Hi,I'm not a drummer but I know how to program drum tracks on Cubase, usually I entered them manually in my stage II but is the Nord Drum will be a good choice to do this song, PHIL Collins, in the air tonight....Would I need to program drums track op into a second device (Ipad, computer) so is there a sequencer in Nord Drum?Or should I use the Nord lead 2 drums kits for it?Your advices?ThanksSincerely

title: RE: NORD DRUM GOOD FOR INTHE AIR TONIGHT?
post_content: Hi Quai!The drums in the song seem a blend of floor tom / bassdrum sounds and a synth drum sequence, near the end of the song a more aggressive sounding kit kicks in..Yes, I think you should be able to get similar synth drum sounds out of the Nord Drum 1 or 2 !I don't know much about the Nord Lead 2, if you happen to have one, please check that out as well, experiment, maybe check the Lead forum if someone posted something on drum soundsnone of the above synths will be able to really mimic the more aggressive acoustic drum sounds that you hear near the end of the song, maybe you'll need some drum samples + effects (or plugin) on top, in order to get that soundor a drumkit - and a drummer perhaps then..The Nord Drum 1 nor 2, has a sequencer on board, so you'll need a computer or tablet to program songs on.There are several sequencer apps, including the free step sequencer Nord Beat 2 for iOS - in which you can easily create songs from patterns -In Cubase it's just a matter of creating a track with the right MIDI channel and program the whole song as you're used toCheers,Albert

title: RE: NORD DRUM GOOD FOR INTHE AIR TONIGHT?
post_content: If you're not a drummer and you're using a computer, check out this VST:http://www.alyjameslab.com/alyjameslabvsdsx.htmlI own this and it's a very good Simmons SDS emulation for the price.The Nord Drum 2 is probably the best modern hardware emulator of that classic 80s synth drum sound but it's an e-drum brain, not a drum machine, it can be sequenced by other things like a computer but it's geared more towards playing live with e-drum triggers. It costs a lot of money so I wouldn't recommend it to people that intend to sequence it with a computer exclusively.

title: RE: NORD DRUM GOOD FOR INTHE AIR TONIGHT?
post_content: Yes, and after all, Collins was playing a Simmons kit at the time right?

title: question concerning midi
post_content: hello all,I've recently bought a nord drum2 to control it with a midi controller.Midi note #s are kept at the factory state; namely 60, 62, 64, 65, 67 and 69.But whenever I play notes other than #60, #60 is played along with that sound.For example, if I play note #62, the result sound that I get is #62 plus #60.Am I not setting something right?Could anybody please explain to me why this is happening, and what I can do to solve this problem?Thanks in advance.

title: RE: question concerning midi
post_content: Questions:) What's the MIDI controller make/model?) Do you have your MIDI controller plugged directly into the ND2?) Are you seeing two trigger lights on the ND2 light up instead of just one?) Are you sending MIDI only to the default global channel 10 on the ND2?) Do you have MIDI out from the ND2 plugged into your controller?My primary suggestion is to simplify the setup. Use a direct connection initially and only Controller->ND2, not in the opposite direction. That'll help you debug it more easily. Sorry in advance if this is something you've already tried, just not making any assumptions here.

title: RE: question concerning midi
post_content: Hello rhombus,Thanks for the reply.I changed the global midi channel to 1 and individual midi channel setting to any number other than 1, and it works fine now.Thanks for the tips!

title: RE: question concerning midi
post_content: Hi Norddrumuser!I changed the global midi channel to 1 and individual midi channel setting to any number other than 1, and it works fine now.Indeed that's the right way to set it up!(or switch indiv. MIDI channels OFF if you're not using the feature)Cheers,Albert

title: Synchronizing via Midi
post_content: Hi,Hi to everyone - as I am new to this forum.I got the ND2 recerntly and now wanted to increase using it. I have no computer in my studio..only hardware equipment - so I thought now about buying a ipad midi for using the ND app. But I can not find out if it is possible (and also what stuff I would need) to have the app synchronzed via Midi to an external signal (Clock -as slave) when working witht he app. Does the app accept being a slave the same time it triggerst the ND?Any help/suggestions would be highly welcome.

title: RE: Synchronizing via Midi
post_content: Sunlight,I have a ND2 and I use irig MIDI 2 interface ($100USD) along with a standard midi cable that plugs from midi out on irig to midi in on Nord Drum 2.  I've used it both master & salve modes. When in slave mode I have my laptop sending midi  via a USB to midi cable that connects to the midi in port on irig2 (and yes it will trigger the nord drum 2 while in slave mode) Nord Beat i2 s a great, free app for the iPad (or mini)!If your only hardware is an iPad (no laptop + USB to midi cable) and would like to  use nord beat 2 in slave mode, I think there are some iPad apps that will allow you set up a virtual midi port (I've never tried it though). Here's a video of nord beat 2 using virtual midi port to trigger another sound source within iPad (not in slave mode though).In order to trigger your Nord Drum 2 via Nord Beat 2 you will definitely need something like irig2 midi and a midi cable so that the iPad can send it midi.It's worth mentioning that the Nord Drum Manager (for software updates, downloading  custom kits, restoring factory patches, backing up your kits etc) would require a USB to midi connection  (irig midi 2 in includes the adapter but you would need 2 midi cables plugged in the in/out midi ports)  to a mac/pc.Good luck!Nate

title: RE: Synchronizing via Midi
post_content: Hi, I've got 2 questions;Is there any single MIDI interface that lets me both hook up the ND2 to Nord Beat AND my Mac OSX for os updates and the sound manager application. Not "irig midi 2", right?But not at the same time of course...Forgot the other question.Thanks.

title: RE: Synchronizing via Midi
post_content: Hi Tronque..The iRig 2 interface mentioned above comes with 2 different cables - to connect it to either a laptop (USB) or iPad (lightning) ..I think the original iRig model has a 30 pin connector, so won't connect to your Mac,Alternatively, find yourself any simple but decent USB-MIDI interface that supports Core-MIDI, for example an E-MU Xmidi 1x1 or the ESI M4U  -(have a look here which interfaces to avoid:http://www.norduserforum.com/nord-drum- ... t7453.html)to use a USB-MIDI interface with your iPad, you'll also need the Apple camera connection kit (30-pin-to-female-USB or Lightning-to-female-USB) - which isn't cheap -The iRig MIDI 2, I bet will work great, the other interfaces mentioned above I tested in combination with Mac, PC and iPads, and they work fine as well!Cheers,Albert

title: Audio trigger in_Midi out

title: RE: Audio trigger in_Midi out
post_content: Hi Harmen!Happy New Year to you too!Yes, of course, when you hit a pad/trigger connected to the Nord Drum, it will not only produce sound on your headphones/audio output, it can also send a MIDI note to another device,use a MIDI cable to connect your Nord Drum (MIDI OUT) to your other sound module/computer/software,and if this module/computer/software is properly set up*, it will (also) produce sound whenever you hit the pad/trigger, = exactly as you describe it...but the latency (time between you hit the pad, and when your other module/software will make a sound) will depend on a couple of factors, but I think it will work just fine,Groetjes,Albert*it should listen to the MIDI channel that the Nord Drum is sending on, can be set in the MIDI settings on the Nord Drum, check the manual of your other device as well,

(sorry I'm kind of a newbie regarding MIDI deep stuffs).Thank you !Cheers and merry christmas.

title: RE: ND v.1 w/ Hardware MIDI trigger
post_content: Hi, welcome to the forum!Sure you can use a standalone/hardware sequencer, drumcomputer, as well as MIDI controllers (e.g. with 4 pads) to control your ND, as long as it has a an 'old fashioned' (DIN) MIDI output. Like in your software, you'd then have to match the MIDI channel, the channel set with 'MIDI CH' on the ND should correspond with the channel the sequencer/controller sends on.To play the ND through MIDI, no SysEx is involved, just standard notes. A MIDI note is just some basic data; which note (Note number 60 ='central' C etc) how hard it is played. In software, or hardware sequencers you can program or record these notes in time, and they are outputted again whenever you want to and press play...Each of the 4 channels (sounds) of the ND only 'listens' to 1 MIDI note number, these are set per channel in the MIDI NOTE menu of your ND. By default these are set as 60, 62, 64, 65 (correponding to 'central' C, D, E, F). In your sequencer, program your drum pattern, or song, using these 4 notes only..I hope that answered your questions...Cheers,Albert

The 909 has a trigger output, and 2 MIDI output, but I see no way to control the sent notes via MIDI... (may be i'm missing something ?)But if you cannot in fact program the sent notes on your 909 how can you manage to trigger the ND ?Thank you !

title: RE: ND v.1 w/ Hardware MIDI trigger
post_content: Hi,If you want to trigger your ND through MIDI, your device needs to send MIDI notes, as far as I can tell from the TR-909 manual, it doesn't send MIDI notes, - [Correction: it does from the external track]You mentioned you are able to use some of your hardware to trigger the ND through the trigger inputs of the ND, does this include the 909? I once read -somewhere- that this is possible ..?If you have a device that sends MIDI notes, but you can't adjust which MIDI notes are sent, or which MIDI channel is used, - you will have to adjust these on the ND for it to work.. [Edit: you can use the MIDI learn function for this as Beardy Jack mentions below]As you said, it very much depends on the specific hardware you want to connect, just read everything you can find about MIDI in the manuals..Cheers,Albert

title: RE: ND v.1 w/ Hardware MIDI trigger
post_content: Hey!You can use individual outputs from the 909 to trigger the ND1, but you will lose the 909 sounds...Also, check the 909 manual because it can output notes to an external unit (external track) just use the midi learn function on the ND1 to set it up properly.The external track feature is often overlooked on the 9 and although probably originally intended for sending maybe a baseline to a synth it could be used to trigger the ND, obviously it is monophonic so that is a limitation...Not sure if I'm helping or not but good luck either way!

title: Considering buying, advice needed
post_content: Hey guys, I'm considering getting a ND2 to experiment with but I've never played one before and don't know what to expect from it. I will be heading off to university next year and so the ND2 would be a good compromise for an actual drum kit seeing as I'll have no room for it when living on residence. Is the nord drum 2 a good choice for someone who's never played anything other that acoustic drums before and what sorts of sounds and beats can be made with it? And Is it something which could be easily worked into songs within a band situation or is it more for solo electronic music styles?

title: RE: Considering buying, advice needed
post_content: Hi Elislater!Depends very much of what you expect...Sound:Have a listen here:http://www.nordkeyboards.com/products/nord-drum-2-  for some sound demos + 2 videos..Apart from some very nice sound banks that you can download from the Nord website, it's quite easy to create your own sounds, and there are a lot of sound parameters at your disposal.As expected from a drum synth It's very well suited for 'electronic' sounds & beats. However, though synthetic, the sounds can have a nice 'organic' touch to them, and the sound responds very dynamically, lifelike to your playing -It's also good at mimicking tuned percussion - and it can mimic acoustic drum soundsto some degree, but perhaps not as realistic as some sample based drum modules do...Playing & Expression:If you want to play like you do on a drum kit, you'll need pads, or triggers, the ND2 is compatible with all big brand pads, but in contrast to some of the big brand drum modules the ND2 will only register striking force (velocity). It is not compatible with dedicated hi-hat triggers, will only use one zone of 'multi-zone' pads, and will not register striking position on the head like with the Roland 'supernatural' V-Drums. - However I have to say that the ND2 does a lot with just striking force alone, as said the sounds respond very dynamically to your playing, a lot of sound parameters depend on velocity - in that way you can even mimic hi-hat open & close playing a bit -  for example -Size of your kit:With the ND2 you can build kits of 6 sounds, as it has 6 channels: e.g. bass drum + snare + hi-hat + 3 toms,  (- or 2 toms and a ride... ) (or a set of wind gusts and sea noises)Taken together,  it's great for making beats, it is truly an excellent addition to an acoustic drum kit, but whether it can replace one.. is up to you!Albert

title: RE: Considering buying, advice needed
post_content: Thanks heaps Albert! Lots of good stuff I've just learnt thanks to your replyI'm just a little shaky with all the pads and triggers as I don't really get how it' all works, would you suggest buying the nord pad to go with it or look elsewhere at other pads? And as far as triggers go how do you set them up and all of that? Is it difficult to learn how to do all of that?

title: RE: Considering buying, advice needed
post_content: Hi Eli,If you're looking for a compact dorm room solution, the Nord Pad will DEFINITELY be a good solution, though you will probably still want at least a kick trigger.  Of course, setting up a rig with pads arranged to simulate the acoustic experience you're used to will feel more natural to you, but it will hog lots of space.  You may benefit from having a completely different setup, like the Nord Pad or similar, so that you can broaden your skill development.  When dorm days are done the Pad can be integrated into your acoustic kit.Pablo
