title: Nord Drum 2 questions
post_content: Hello,Im totally new to this particular module,and was wondering if anyone could help.Is it possible to copy the sound of trigger channel 1 to trigger channel 2? I only managed to copy the whole kit and to another kit or program location.Does anyone have some idea for create a great metal kick drum sound? I mean how to set all the sound parameters to create one.Im going to trigger acustic bassdrums from this module,but would you say that the Nord Drum 1 is better aimed at that,and is the trigger response better on the ND2 than ND1?Thank you very much for your time-Jan

title: RE: Nord Drum 2 questions
post_content: Hi Jan, welcome!Copy and Paste functions let you copy the sound of one channel to another, either within the same program (kit) or to another, (page 17 of ND2 manual, or page 13 of ND1 manual) simply select a channel, press Shift+Copy, then go to the destination channel and press Shift+PastePerhaps someone else here has more experience with metal, when I hear metal kicks, I usually don't hear much more than loud clicks. You're going to use an acoustic trigger, your ND will have to blend in with the acoustic sound (unless your kick is completely muffled), just experiment a lot with tone, decay, frequency, and click parameters. With both ND1 and 2 you can make a nice deep kick sound with a good punch, or sharp attack if you want- and if that is the only thing you're looking for, ND1 is enough; you don't need stereo for a kick drum for example.I don't know if there is any difference between ND1, and 2 in terms of latency, I actually never noticed any lag so far with both of them.. did you with your ND2?Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Nord Drum 2 questions
post_content: Thank you very much Albert!!!I have allready today created some good ones,and actually it doesnt have to be a metal kick sound,but any punchy and prominent kick would be good. Just to get a great starting point. I just love how this module let you create own sounds from scratch!But of course I ran into another question,is it possible to route kicks to one of the outputs and say a snare,or all other channels to the other output? Just to get the FOH sound engineer total separation?In terms of trigger response,this must be the fastest and most acurate module Ive tried!!! Very impressive!Thank you very much again,and cheers from Norway!-Jan

title: RE: Nord Drum 2 questions
post_content: Great! Good to hear!Yes you can, with ND2 you can pan your bassdrum all the way to the left, (or right) and snare/other sounds all the way to the other side..Albert

title: Nord Drum MIDI triggering problem
post_content: I bought my Nord Drum last week and set it up for the first at the weekend with my M-Audio Trigger Finger. I followed the instructions on how to set-up MIDI note triggering and despite several attempts have failed to get this to work. Could anyone here help me solve this problem, please?ThanksLiamP.S. Also would appreciate advice on triggering the Nord Drum from my DAW (Sonar X2 Producer). Thanks again.

title: RE: Nord Drum MIDI triggering problem
post_content: Hi,Just to be sure:1) Match MIDI channel;the default channel of the Nord Drum is 10, so either set your M-Audio to transmit on that channel, or change the channel the Nord Drum listens to -to match the channel that the M-Audio transmits on2) Match MIDI notes;for each pad on your M-Audio you can probably set the MIDI note it will send, the Nord Drum 2 responds to incoming MIDI notes 60, 62, 64, 65, 67, 69,  =default setup, can be altered..make sure the notes match, - then perhaps this is useful:http://www.midimountain.com/midi/midi_note_numbers.htmlanother remark; you will only be using 4, or 6 of your 16 pads, depending whether you have the Nord Drum, or Nord Drum 2 resp.Perhaps you already know all above, and set it up correctly, then perhaps a faulty MIDI cable?Albert

title: Hi hat open/close with e drums?
post_content: I really would like to control the hi hat with the pedal from my Roland e drum kit. Any opinions on if this is going to be possible when the ND2 gets midi CC upgrade?

title: RE: Hi hat open/close with e drums?
post_content: Hi! Difficult to answer, I will give it a shot anyway..What MIDI messages does your Roland brain output when you play your hi-hat?1 note, (regardless if open/close) + CC depending on position?Or 2 notes depending on open/close, ..or something else..? Note on/off?With the ND2 you can define a mute group; channels* (sounds) within the mute group mute each other, each time you play another sound.. if your Roland outputs a different note depending on hh open/close then you can mimic hh open/close playing with the ND2 .. won't be a 'supernatural' response obviouslyWe don't know how they're going to implement the CC control feature; if a CC will change a parameter on all 6 channels at the same time, or whether we will be able to control some parameters per channel. ..If per channel, and your Roland sends a CC depending on hh open/close position, then you could perhaps partially mimic hh open/close by controlling tone/noise/click levels/ratio  .. I simply don't know- we will have to wait until CC control is there(and I am still waiting for my ND2 to arriveCheers,Albert*a channel on the ND is not to be confused with a MIDI channel, a channel on the ND is a sound (e.g. tom, snare hh open, hh closed, etc.) The ND only receives MIDI from one MIDI channel, you can set the MIDI note for each channel (sound) on the ND

post_content: andre99 wrote:Hi, I'm really confused as to whether my Nord drum is not working. When I switch between channels (using the channel select button obviously), the program is the same on each channel. So, all four channels can only have one program eg P15.I presume that each channel can have a different program. Am I horribly mistaken? Are there any settings that might be causing this problem?I think a single program contains four channels, so that would match with what you're seeing. title: RE: A really easy question........channels  & programs
post_content: Yes, a Program consists of and contains four channels, each of which can hold an independent voice.  These voices can be copied/pasted from channel to channel within a single program and also from program to program.Pablo

title: Your Setup with the Nord Drum
post_content: Just curious about how people use their Nord Drum 1/2,I'll start with my 'live' setup: I'm mixing acoustic drums and synthetic drum sounds, I really like the combination, and it works well, at least in the rehearsal studio,...Acoustic: I only use my cymbals and snaredrum - nothing beats a real snaredrum!Pads: Simple rubber Yamaha TP65 pads and KP65 kick padAcoustic triggers: I tried a ddrum pro kick trigger, it works fine with the ND1, no issues whatsoever! However, I think I prefer either acoustic (bass)drum, or pure synthetic sound, so I'm not using triggers nowBrains/sound units (other than ND): none, perhaps in future my SPD-S / MPC samplers with my own samplesI think I'm one of the few who prefers rubber pads, I find both rubber and mesh play 'unnatural', rubber are much cheaper. OK, the Roland 'supernatural' units with position sensing etc., give a very natural response, but ND isn't a TD30. Perhaps a downside of combining acoustic drums with (rubber) pads is the acoustic noise the pads make when you hit them. I find all types of pads noisy in one way or the other. In ambient 'live' band recordings I don't hear my pads, I wonder what overhead mics will pick up. Perhaps I'll have to do some clever mic positioning.. For the time being I'll stick with my synthetic rubber pads to make purely synthetic sounds, combined with 100% acoustic drumsAmplification:At home I'm fine with studio monitors, headphones, but in rehearsal studio I use whatever vocal amp/pa is there, which doesn't always sound ok. The next step for me is to invest in some proper amplification. I bet we could start a whole new thread about amplification, well there is a sub-forum here; 'accessories and amplification' I will check that..One thing I found out is that because I combine acoustic and electronic sounds, the speakers should be positioned near the kit, it feels totally weird when half of the drum sounds are coming from the other end of the room..So that is my 'live' setup covered I think, so what's yours?Cheers,Albert

title: Alesis perc pad........?
post_content: Hi, again I'm sure this has been covered in depth but does anyone use the alesis perc pad as a trigger for the drum machine and if so what do you think about it? title: RE: Alesis perc pad........?
post_content: Hi again,About the Nord Pad, I don't know of course, perhaps partly strategic, but perhaps also a way to keep things as simple and light-weight as possible;I think it is not much more than 6 regular pads (piezos in disguise?) sending their signal thru a relatively very compact RJ45 (?) common internet cable,when you want the Pad to send MIDI they'd have to put some electronics in I guess, and then users might want to change the MIDI notes sent by the pads, so you'll need a display..I don't know if it is possible but perhaps someday someone will make a little box that has the internet socket on one end and 6 jack outputs on the other, then you'd be able to connect it with ND1, or any other drum brain,(and in that way even convert the signals into MIDI if required)About the PercPad:I did find some critisism: according to this video it has the same problem as the ControlPad:(has to do with their way of trying to supress crosstalk between pads)Perhaps someone here can tell from his own experience how bad the problem really is?!I think 'Beardy Jack' has one:http://www.norduserforum.com/nord-drum- ... t4739.htmlCheers,Albert

title: RE: Alesis perc pad........?
post_content: Hey there!Haven't been here for a bit...The alesis Percpad is brilliant in my experience, flams rolls, velocity is spot on. I personally have never experienced accidental triggering or cross trigging from any of the pads. I'd recommend the alesis, very cheap and compact and can be played with fingers no problem.Setting it up takes literally seconds, just put the ND in midi channel learn mode, hit a pad, then go to midi note learn and match the pads up with whichever channel you wish. I timed it once but can't remember, it's under 40 seconds though I think! Easy peasy!Go for it, it's the cheapest option I think. It's inbuilt sounds are poor, the alesis sample pad is similar but I think it only holds 1 sample at a time (pfff) though it is a better colour!

title: External trigger pad and ipad app

title: RE: External trigger pad and ipad app
post_content: andre99 wrote:Also wondering about users thoughts on the ipad app as a sequencer. I have an iPad but would like to make sure it's decent before forking out for a midi conversion.I can't say anything sensible regarding the Nord Drum, but a cheap USB-to-iPad connector and a cheap USB MIDI interface work fine too if you don't know if you'll use it a lot.I have an E-mu XMIDI 1X1 (cost me about $30) and it works fine with both an iPad 1 and an iPad 4. With the iPad 1 I use the Apple Camera Connection Kit and with the iPad 4 I use a cheapy USB to Lightning adapter that cost me $2.90 including shipping. I think even those cheap USB MIDI interfaces from China work, but I can't say I have experience with those.Some genuine knock-off products:http://dx.com/p/usb-female-to-lightning ... 5cm-205760http://dx.com/p/usb-2-0-to-midi-convert ... gth-110980Of course, the products from companies like Yamaha, Alesis and IK Multimedia that provide MIDI for the iPad are much nicer, but for a cheap solution to test out MIDI on the iPad, $9 including shipping is not bad. I have that USB to Lightning convertor and it seems well made (especially for the price): at least is uses real rubber in the strain relief (I have cheapo Chinese cables where the 'strain relief' is just a bit of hard plastic). The USB MIDI adapter looks exactly like the ones I sometimes see for $15-20 in the shops, but of course it is still possible that it is a copy of a copy of a copy, etc.

title: RE: External trigger pad and ipad app
post_content: Hi!I agree with MJ, since the introduction of core MIDI with iOS4 it has become easier and cheaper as a lot of interfaces will work. I was surprised that even my -small, but big for iPad- ESI M4U (4 in 4 out) works without the iPad complaining that the device is using too much energy -Anyway, I like the App, it's very much 'what you see is what you get'; an uncluttered 6 track step sequencer, intended for drum units only (controls only one note per track!), perfect for the ND1/ND2!You can get an impression of how the app works; you can download it for free, but note that it won't produce any sound on its own. There are other sequencer apps out there that can do a lot more; 'Genome', 'Cubasis' - but they are not cheap, some apps discussed here:http://apps4idevices.com/categories/mid ... tml/page:1Then your question about pads...Indeed you'll need a ND2 to use the Nord Pad,I haven't seen too many small units with pads intended just for MIDI:- have read some negative stories about Alesis ControlPad, (can't play 2 pads at the same time!)- I don't know about their PercPad/SamplePad, it is really cheap though... here, and on other forums people seem to like them..- Of course there are the Yamaha DTX-multi12, and Roland SPD-Sx etc, which are good instruments with pads, -but much more expensive!I wonder how much latency is an issue with MIDI pads, I think that pads directly connected with the unit have lower latency theoretically,Good luck, have fun!Albert

title: nord drum connects with stage 2?
post_content: I am fairly new to recording, and I'm really looking for a great sounding drum machine that I can use to record / play live. I'm in the process of buying a nord stage 2, and would love to be able to use the nord drum with the stage 2.Unfortunately my audio interface only has 2 inputs. Is it possible to wire the nord drum to the stage 2? So that I don't take up those valuable inputs? My audio interface is an apogee duet 2. Any other suggestions for connecting a drum machine and nord stage 2 to play through monitors would be great! Perhaps a different interface?Thanks everyone!

title: RE: nord drum connects with stage 2?
post_content: You could use a direct box. The one I use, the JDI Duplex stereo DI has dual stereo inputs. This enables you to take two separate, unbalanced stereo or two channel signals like the ones output from all Nord devices and combine them into one pair of balanced signals output from the direct box. This you can use to run both instruments (now with a balanced signal) into your interface, a sound board/mixer or whatever you like.

title: RE: nord drum connects with stage 2?
post_content: The new Nord Drum 2 is two channel stereo. I think the previous Nord Drum was mono.

title: RE: nord drum connects with stage 2?
post_content: sawcreatives wrote:Unfortunately my audio interface only has 2 inputs. Is it possible to wire the nord drum to the stage 2?free: Not really... but you could connect the drum out into the nord monitor in and use the phones output of the NS2, but I do not think that this is very good as the impedance would be different than what the stereo input of your interface would expect.some cost: Poor-man's mixer or summing box. This would add and match the impedances of the outputs of both your instruments but you might get some attenuation. I haven't tried it. If you do, please report back:http://rane.com/note109.htmlsome more cost: get some small mixer.

post_content: If you want more inputs beyond what the summing DI box can provide, you are limited to a few options. A mixer like what was already previously mentioned. In retrospect, I wish I would have spent the extra several hundred up front for one with more analog inputs. Now I figure I'll just work with what I have somehow until I can afford the high cost of a new Universal Audio Apollo interface with Thunderbolt.

title: Using headphones in Audio Out.
post_content: Hi there!I have tried using a headphone in the audio out and everything seems to be good except that it only plays on one of the channels (can´t remember if it is left or right).I have actually tried to have the jack plug pulled a little bit out and then both channels are playing!! DOOHWhat kind of converter-cable (either a cable sold or homemade) would I need to make the mono-signal heard in both left and right channel of my headphones??Kind regardsPsypher

title: RE: Using headphones in Audio Out.
post_content: Psypher wrote:I have tried using a headphone in the audio out and everything seems to be good except that it only plays on one of the channels (can´t remember if it is left or right).Audio out isn't meant for directly connecting headphones too. Also, it is a mono output. If you can get the right volume with your particular headphone, I don't see a reason why you couldn't use it as a headphone output though (might not work well with all headphones due to volume issues)Psypher wrote:I have actually tried to have the jack plug pulled a little bit out and then both channels are playing!! DOOHWhat kind of converter-cable (either a cable sold or homemade) would I need to make the mono-signal heard in both left and right channel of my headphones??If you can solder you could easily create an adapter yourself. You'd need a male 6.35 mm mono jack and a female 6.35 mm (or 3.5 mm if that is more convenient for you) stereo connector (and some wire with two or more conductors/treads in it). The tip on the male mono jack should be connected to both the tip and the ring contacts on the female connector. I hope this makes sense.Anyway, it might be cheaper (and more convenient) to get something from eBay,DealExtreme.comor something like that. (DX doesn't seem to have anything suitable.)Maybe something like this:http://viewitem.eim.ebay.dk/35mm-STEREO-to-635mm-MONO-Jack-Audio-Cable-Adapter-Converter-63mm-14-Inch/251147614147/item(3.5 mm headphone socket)http://viewitem.eim.ebay.dk/635mm-STEREO-to-635mm-MONO-Jack-Audio-Cable-Adapter-Converter-63mm-14-Inch/280960780127/item(6.35 mm headphone socket)http://viewitem.eim.ebay.dk/35mm-STEREO-Jack-Female-Socket-635mm-14-MONO-Male-Plug-Nickel-Adapter-/350729367823/item(3.5 mm, metal version)http://viewitem.eim.ebay.dk/Metal-635mm-Stereo-Socket-to-635mm-Mono-Jack/380299989083/item(6.35 mm, metal version)And there's plenty more cheap Chinese stuff on eBay... I doubt you can make it yourself for that amount.

title: RE: Using headphones in Audio Out.
post_content: Hi,I'm interested too, -  quite puzzling indeed,I decided to go through everything step by step:if I'm correct the ND actually has a 3 connector socket, which is normally used for stereo, or balanced mono signals,but according to the specs the ND has unbalanced mono output, so:---------ND socket:---------stereo jack:tip:-----signal---------------leftring:----not connected-----rightsleeve: ground--------------groundConnecting your stereo headphones directly to ND will indeed result in a signal in theleftchannel only.If you pull your headphone jack a little bit back, you hear sound in both ears. I didn't understand why at first, but I think it is thanks to the fact they used a stereo socket:I think by pulling it back, the tip of the jack becomes connected with both tip and ring of the socket, while the ring of the jack is also (still) in contact with with the ring of the socket.In other words: the signal from the ND becomes connected with both left and right of your headphones.So, now your cable:  mono jack (that will go into the ND) to a female stereo jack (to plug your headphones in)I think you should indeed connect the tip of a mono jack - with both the tip + ring of a stereo female jack (see picture below, basically the same as your drawing..),(= shorting tip and ring of the female jack)  -You say the result is signal only on one side, - are you sure you didn't connect the tip (or sleeve) of the jack with both ring and sleeve of the female jack (= shorting the ring and sleeve of the female jack)?did you check your cable with a resistance meter, to check what is connected with what, and checking if there are no unwanted connections made...?I assume you did it right, - so why doesn't it work?!I ordered a dedicated mono-jack-to-stereo-female adapter - one as was suggested above .. (I hate soldering)I will let you know if it works!Albert

title: RE: Using headphones in Audio Out.
post_content: I GOT IT WORKING!!!!here are my findings:... I bought the "mono jack to stereo female jack converter" - although advertised as such - it doesn't work, because it is actually an 'unbalanced to balanced' 'converter',that is: they connected sleeve of the jack with the ring and sleeve of the female jack - which results in sound in your LEFT ear only!Then I bought some stuff to make the cable myself:-male mono jack-unbalanced 'microphone' wire-female stereo jackI connected the tip of the jack with both tip and ring of the female jack - and sleeve to sleeve, as in above posts -and it works!!!!So, my advice to all who want to use headphones on the ND:  - don't buy any 'mono to stereo jack converter' unless you are 100% sure it is wired as above, otherwise: DIY !!Cheers,Albert

title: RE: Using headphones in Audio Out.

title: RE: Using headphones in Audio Out.
post_content: yes, I don't know how to call it either, the ND is proper old fashioned mono, one channel,the 'converter' cable we made distributes this signal to both channels in a stereo setup, which one could still call mono..When I bought the wrong converter, it said 'mono to stereo' on the website; the confusion comes from the fact that a stereo jack is physically the same as a balanced jack; a TRS jack,when you want to connect 2 poles (TS) with 3 (TRS) you have a couple of options..However, now that is sorted, I started wondering if everything is ok impedance-wise - how healthy it is for the ND output circuit to connect headphones - it sounds quite ok..- anyone?Albert

title: RE: Using headphones in Audio Out.
post_content: One possibility with the cable you created is that if there were also a connection to the ring, the mono plug is now shorting it (the ring and the sleeve are the same piece of metal).It probably this does not matter (I have no idea what are the connections of the female connector). But to make sure that such shorting did not happen I would have used a stereo male plug, then connect its tip to both tip and ring of the female stereo connector and leave the ring of the male plug disconnected (and sleeve to sleeve too). That way there is no possible shorting and you still connect the left channel to both right and left of the headphones.Perhaps somebody has more information of what the contacts are in the ND connector ouput to clarify whether that is needed or not.

title: Connecting Nord Drum to Logic
post_content: So i bought a Alesis PercPad, hooked it up to the nord drum MIDI in, and on the nord drum MIDI out i put a midi to usb cable...how do I get logic to recognize the nord drum? Thanks

title: RE: Connecting Nord Drum to Logic
post_content: What do you want it to do in combination with Logic?You connected the PercPad to the Nord Drum's MIDI in, so you can play the Drum with the PercPad. However, with that setup you cannot send MIDI from Logic to the Nord Drum.If you want to record (via MIDI, not audio) your playing on the PercPad, this will only be possible if the Nord Drum 'echos' incoming MIDI messages to the MIDI out port (like a MIDI thru port). No idea if the Nord Drum does that, but I think that in your current setup Logic only receives MIDI messages when you turn a knob or press a button on the Nord Drum.The best setup might be to connect MIDI out on the PercPad to your computer; then also connect the MIDI in port on the Nord Drum (but preferably also the MIDI out port) to your computer. Logic can then see your drumming on the PercPad and it can control the Nord Drum, so it can send the MIDI messages you generate when playing on the PercPad to the Nord Drum, but it can also send (MIDI) recordings to the Nord Drum.I hope this makes sense. If you only connect MIDI out on the PercPad and MIDI in on the Nord Drum, you can do it with your existing MIDI-to-USB cable. Also connecting MIDI out on the Nord Drum to Logic has the advantage of being able to record knob twiddling on the Nord Drum, but loosing that may not really be an issue for you.

title: RE: Roland PD-8s to trigger Nord Drum?
post_content: hej_joe wrote:So, I got some Alesis pads, which I thought were thoroughly horrible, and then I decided to get two Roland PD-8s instead, since each one is dual zone.  The problem is, I can't figure out what would be the way you'd hook them up in order to get the capabilities out of both zones.  The pad itself has a single TRS output, so should I use a TRS in / 2x TRS out adapter or a TRS in / 2x TS adapter?  Either way, I can't get the rim zone to work properly, and striking directly on the pad triggers both channels that I have the drum hooked up to.Also, I jacked with all the Threshold/Sensitivity/Trigger settings and I don't see a way to reset the factory defaults - any ideas there?JoeHello Joe,Even though each of the 4 trigger inputs of the Nord Drum (ND) will function with either TRS or TS connectors, they are only single inputs.The TRS to 2 X TS adapter won't work unless wired correctly.The head piezo polarity is opposite that of the rim piezo.(this will cause triggering issues)V_Drum_TRS.JPG (10.08 KiB) Viewed 6507 timesPage 6 of themanualhas information on how to change the input(s) sensitivity.Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: Roland PD-8s to trigger Nord Drum?
post_content: This looks easy (ha!)Tip is the head piezo, ring is the rim piezo.  I know not much about the Nord Drum, but if it's anything like my ddrum4, all you'd need to do is break stereo out into mono and you'd be done.  So a simple TRS stereo female to two TS mono male connector would work.  Actually, if the Roland has a female TRS as it looks like in that diagram, you could use a simple insert cable like this:

title: Distortion & Overdrive
post_content: Hi all,Although the ND already has quite punchy sounds of its own, I wanted to experiment with some overdrive and distortion;Just to share my experience:I have a Line6 POD2.0 lying around and tried it out - also has a nice red colour, but other than that I found it is a very BAD match with the ND!In contrast to other drummachines, with the ND there was a constant crackling noise (as if playing a dusty LP record), even with volume of the ND down.No idea what is causing it, filtering out high frequencies from the ND output did help..However; I am quite happy with the results I got with the all analog Boss ROD-10  !!!!!!Unfortunately, it's a hard to come by piece of 80s technology, so my tip is probably not very useful for most...Cheers,Albert

title: Wishlist for the nord drum.
post_content: Wishlist for the nord drum:Edit all parameters via MIDI.Having a way to merge two channels to create a hi-hat open and closed (closed when the other stops). In a channel wouldbetter still.To output midi midi-thru be too.A few more waveforms in tone.

title: RE: Wishlist for the nord drum.
post_content: Individual balanced outputs!!!!!

title: RE: Wishlist for the nord drum.
post_content: Pianohenry:This involves changing the hardware.I do not think that is easily implementable.I'm thinking of improvements that can made ​​in software only.

title: RE: Wishlist for the nord drum.
post_content: The things you listed make sense, and were mentioned by others as well -but we don't know whether the current ND hardware can handle the software features we propose..- be able to control parameters thru MIDI CCslive- I agree, would be nice(  - an editor is perhaps already possible using midi dump option - requires some software to send the right sysEx)- option to stop one sound with triggering another (to mimic hi-hat open & close type of thing) - (=2 channels), yup,- you can also recreate this effect using only one channel; by controlling note length with a midi controller - which would require...just for the sake of it:- import your own waveforms into a few user slots- be able to set dynamics, sensitivity & threshold  per program, might be handy - in some cases - perhaps- trigger 2 or more channels with one trigger + using different thresholds: to completely change the sound dynamically- tremolo, vibratohardware future:- more inputs, so: more channels  - though I'm happy now- as mentioned; more outputs, at least stereo- headphones output I'd like- USB MIDI  &  OS/data transfer- accepts hi-hat triggers- accepts cymbal chokeCheers,Albert

title: RE: Wishlist for the nord drum.
post_content: Top of the wish list tree for me is an update allowing the 16 main buttons to become a rudimentary 16 step sequencer, could be very easy to use with combinations of shift to toggle steps on and off (I know velocity is key but can go without).It would be short I know but I can sit for hours with mine just programming and having a little sequencer would make me so happy. It's such a lovely machine but this for me would be the ultimate.Nord Drum Forever...

title: RE: Wishlist for the nord drum.
post_content: I've been holding off on this because I wanted to USE it first, ya dig?I've intentionally held off analyzing waveforms, or decoding SYSEX stream, because I wanted to move air first.After a couple of months, here's my wish list:1) control start time of each element... As it is, all three elements, Tone, Noise, and Attack, all start the moment the sound is triggered.- How about allowing me to change the start times in milliseconds? Tone and Attack start at 0, noise starts at 480ms?2) A couple of more oscillators per voice... A long tones decay will disappear when the sound is retriggered- While this can make for some interesting sounds, I'd like to have the option to turn this off or on at my discretion.3) Velocity Scaling... At this time strike velocity does modulate some parameters in the ND: sweep, punch, filter, depending on the element in question.- I'd like the ability to change how velocity affects the parameter. It seems as if more velocity = higher value sent to said parameter. Let me affect the Tone sweep in the last 30% of the velocity range while having it negatively affect the Noise filter while having the Tone Bend affected by the last 50% of velocity. Hopefully this makes sense, if not, I'll draw you a picture.I think the velocity scaling and element start time will open the ND to more possibilities.That's all for now.Ed

title: Nord Beat (app) wish
post_content: Hi ND users!Nord Beat app is similarlyverysimple as is the Nord Drum itself. Simplicity has two sides: First, it has great workflow - everything is in front of you and there's no need  to check any manuals or anything. But secondly, there are certainly limits too because of this simplicity.I could make list of features which could give Nord Beat much more power, but here I give just one wish which is the most important IMO:Ability to send midi clock (time signal) out.Simple as that, it's a quite common feature in many apps. I would assume that it isn't too difficult to program, right?Why this? Reason is obvious. Most of us using Nord Beat with ND, will not just play drum sequences. We wanna play other synths with it, and timing is important to make it go well. It's also the most natural way to give this time signal to drum machine.

title: Nord Drum = happiness or "Thanks, Clavia!"
post_content: I've had mine about 3 weeks. Thus far, totally happy with the purchase.Programming is a breeze, and it responds nicely to MIDI via Drum Kat and trigger pads from Roland, Simmons, and even some ancient Tama Techstar pads.I've been using it alongside my acoustic kit to bring synth drum sounds to the stage.Reception has been favorable from band mates and audiences alike.There are things I'd add to it, but all in all, I think it's perfect.I'll post some links to my youtube page as I post videos I make using Nord Drum.Cheers from TX,Ed

title: RE: Nord Drum = happiness or "Thanks, Clavia!"

I hope you can post your experiences with it and as you say before, i'll be waiting for your youtube videos!greetings from chile!

title: RE: Nord Drum = happiness or "Thanks, Clavia!"
post_content: Hi ND users and others,I was earlier quite critical about Nord Drum and especially its single output. Well, now when I finaly got mine - german Thomann is selling it for 199 euros! - I begin to really appreciate this little machine. Ok, still I feel it has its limitations (this single output and just four channels) but I also think that this simplicity is also its power. More features, bigger machine, bigger price. Workflow is just marvelous! In studio use you can of course take out those sounds individually and mix them afterwards.Why I have changed my mind? Well, It is much about value for price. Still I am not sure if it's worth 400 euros or more but for sure for 199 euros it's really winner! Three things matter most to me: 1. Sound quality: perfect. It fits greatly to my studio rig with some very professional synths. 2. Workflow: programming is just fast and simple. You'll get what you want much faster than messing around with sample libraries for example, 3. Playability: it has great dynamics and feel. In one word, it is an INSTRUMENT.

(a Musicmesse with a ND2 in near future?!)- the only thing that I am slightly dissappointed about is a small issue in current OS1.08 which I complained about to Clavia, didn't get fixed yet, so perhaps just not possible)Albert- hmmm when is the messeAlbert

title: Nord Beat feature request: MIDI-in navigation
post_content: First off, the new Nord Beat app is a gem: straightforward, easy to use, with a really crisp design.After working with it for a couple of days, I like it enough to use in a live performance, navigating patterns on the fly. But since I'm a bass player that's not practical -- my hands are fully occupied. However, I've got a Rolls MidiBuddy foot pedal board that sends out program change messages. It would be great if Nord Beat could map incoming program change numbers to Play on/off, along with shifting between the eight patterns (A-H). Tapping a foot pedal would trigger a jump to the corresponding pattern when the current pattern ends, so that a song could be used in an improvisation without ever messing up the beat.Sound do-able? Appealing?For now, Nord Beat is a great practice tool. Adding MIDI-in navigation would open a bunch of possibilities.

title: mono..
post_content: We were so happy, wow, Nord Drum! You can trigger a Kick sound and a hihat sound - LIVE!our guitar player likes to trigger a kick and hihat with his feet with triggers - and so far we used a Roland Hansonic for the samples, which I always thought sound crap. Pleased I was to find out about the Nord drum, it would sound a lot better!we were in madrid with the band (touring) and the shop owner of Nord gear was so cool to come with his first Nord drum unit to sound check - we were all seriously disappointed to find out the device is mono.seriously.. mono? no way to pan two different sounds? I sort of expect this to have 4 outs...how much is nord saving on leaving extra outputs off? I would gladly pay more, if it were at least stereo.

title: RE: mono..
post_content: I was there at the Musikmesse Frankfurt 2012 and I asked the Nord guy about this mono thing: why just mono? His guess was that first analog machines were mono and ND is kind of recreation of them... Come on, we don't need to go back in every aspect.But then they say this ND is targeted to performers with no need to special stereo pan. Again so wrong thinking. Of course stereo panning is good to have but also it's necessary to mix them separately. At least bass drum needs special mix.Then this four-channel thing. Our drummer might want to use his Roland SPD-S as a midi controller. So he can only use four pads of his 8. Forget it. I could tolerate this four-channel thing if it was just about four trigger inputs. But if I am right, this 4 is all you get via MIDI also, right? Amazingly stupid.Why I am so angry about this? Simply because it seems to be a great sounding little machine with these stupid limitations. Without them, we would already have it and basically ND is something that we were looking for to expand our live setup. Nord team has totally lost their minds when inventing it.

title: Love the little beastie!
post_content: I really like the sound palette that the various timbres offer!! It's exactly what I was looking for. The midi response is very good too. I have an issue with program change messages though. I hooked up the Nord Drum to the thru port of my Monomachine, which passes on the midi from my Octatrack (loving the micro timing with this lightning fast response time over here!) but, and there is a big but (no pun intended) the program number switches back to P 01 for two sixteenth notes just before going back to what I set it to on the "one" of the pattern.Anybody ?

title: RE: Love the little beastie!
post_content: Hi Darthen,If I understand you correctly you are sending a drum pattern (just notes) to a program of the ND, but then the ND changes/switches program during the pattern unwantedly?I don't know the Octatrack, or Monomachine, but I would first check what messages are actually sent to the ND,maybe you can hook your Octatrack/Monomachine combination up to a computer with MidiOx (to monitor MIDI signals) to see if there are unintended prog changes being sent by your Octatrack/Monomachine combination,if you are sure that only notes are sent, (so no prog changesor anything else), perhaps you should contact Clavia,Albert

title: RE: Love the little beastie!
post_content: Hi Albert,I stored the program I want to use on this particular track on number 99 so I effectively send out a program change message to the ND from the Octatrack. But the message I send is for it to switch to P 99, every time the pattern on the Octatrack ends (4 bars) the ND switches back to P 01 for two sixteenth notes and back to P 99 on the start of the pattern so it's not a show-stopper but for a short period the drums sound off.Hope that is clearer than my original statement... thanks for the idea I will check what messages are sent and get back to you.

title: RE: Love the little beastie!
post_content: Hi Darthen,Thanks, that's clear, you included a program change to P99, makes sense,indeed strange that it switches briefly to P01, then back again!Yes, I think that's the best way to find out, let me know what your findings are..Albert

title: Any info available about Nord Drum's Waveforms?
post_content: Any info available about the Nord Drum's Waveforms?

title: RE: Any info available about Nord Drum's Waveforms?
post_content: mitkroy wrote:Any info available about the Nord Drum's Waveforms?Themanualhassomeinformation.Each sound of the Nord Drum (ND) is comprised of three components:ToneNoiseClickTone Wave can have the following range of settings:An 1-3 (Analog synth-like waves)b 1-9 (more traditional drum-like waves)c 1-5 (percussive waves)Noise Color can have the following range of settings:-10 to +10 (Pink noise to White noise)Click Typen1 - n9 (noise waveforms with different characters)c1 - c9 (noise body with added attack)t1 - t9 (pitched sound)Hopefully one of the ND owners can fill in with some additional information here.Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: Nord drum (machine)
post_content: ok, hear me out, i think this thing could be cool..  i have an old ddrum4 and i've played around with it on a real kit with a real drummer using the old ddrum red shot acoustic triggers and the result can be pretty interesting.. for a $600 investment (nord drum + triggers) you basically add electronic drum sounds to a kit..  and then MIDI out to your synth and your drummer can help re-enact ELP's version of Ginastera's 1st Piano Concerto..ok, I'm reaching there, but I think it's pretty neat..  4 more channels would have made it actually very neat, though..

title: RE: Nord drum (machine)
post_content: While I can see adding the Nord Drum to an existing drum set for synthesized drum sounds I was really hoping that the Nord Drum would be the next evolution in electronic drumming. I would have LOVED to see a Nord sample library section dedicated to various real sounding drum kits and cymbals that have been meticulously sampled by the Nord team. Maybe even add the existing synthesized section that is the Nord Drum mixed with sample library type drum sounds...something like a Nord Wave drum where you can mix synthesized drums with authentic sounding samples creating something altogether new. Maybe even add an effects and amp section.Also I really feel as though the Nord Drum should have atleast 8 sound inputs instead of 4...Nord Drum EX?I can practically already achieve what the Nord Drum is by hooking up my existing Yamaha electronic drums via midi to my Nord Lead 2x rack drum presets.If they could make a Nord Drum module that could do all of the above I think it would be game over for Roland and Yamaha electronic drums. I do like what the former Ddrum team is doing over at 2Box,but their hardware is flimsy and it is not available in the USA. If Nord just put out a great drum module that was compatible with all rubber,mesh type drum triggers then they wouldn't even need to make a drum rack and pads thus keeping cost down.Sorry if this post is long winded,but I would just really like to see a great next generation Nord drum module with sample library type sounds somewhere in the near future.

title: RE: Nord drum (machine)
post_content: I now own one and I like it!it's very tiny, yet the build quality that we are used to from Nord, rugged, easy to operate, & it sounds good!I'm fine with the limited amount of channels, but I do agree it would have been nicer to have stereo,I think with stereo it would have become more of an instrument of it's own, now it's more a unit that you add to your kit, -which I will-Albert

title: RE: Nord drum (machine)
post_content: Yeah, more and more I think about it I really get amazed (or almost angry) why the h**l did they make it mono?!? I could tolerate just 4 channels if it was at least stereo. Having stereo + 4 indvidual outputs would of course the professional way to do it. If you wanna record it, you would probably want to put those 4 on individual tracks. Or, on stage you might want to have some EQ boost on bass drum etc. etc.Now when everything is forced to one output it REALLY limits its use. So IMO this a clear example when sparing money and space (maybe they tried to make it as small as possible...?) can be a mistake. Less isn't more in this case obviously.Sent from my HTC Vision using Tapatalk

title: RE: Nord drum (machine)
post_content: Well, ...now that I've been playing with it for a while I have to say that I don't miss stereo in case of beat making with 'vintage' drum synth sounds, but I do miss stereo when playing percussion sounds ..so, in my opinion:pros:1) I very much like the way it sounds!! dynamic response of some parameters gives a very 'natural' feel to it, even with very weird synthetic sounds2) connects to different types of pads and triggers and has midi in and out3) small, built like a tankcons:1) it's mono, which is fine in case of beat making etc, but it would have been nicer to have stereo,2) doesn't have the option to stop one sound by triggering another (can't do hi-hat open/close stuff) - as far as I can tell..3) doesn't allow to change sound parameters through midi CCs - would have been nice to connect it to a midi controller or DAW to change sounds4) doesn't have headphones out, always need a mixer or pre-amp to play(apart from the outputs) - perhaps in future OS updates?Although I listed more cons than pros, all in all, I AM quite happy with my Nord drum, simply because I like the way it sounds!Albert(Edit: in my 'cons' list I previously reported some weird behavior when playing rolls, has to do with pitch bending notes behaving differently at low velocity = small bug - already reported to Clavia)

title: Updating OS to v1.08?
post_content: Has anyone been able to successfully update their machine to 1.08?  I'm trying to get it to upgrade using a Mac, connecting with a Midisport 2x2 and CANNOT get it to work, for the life of me.  After I select which MIDI interface I want to use (the A or B channel on the Midisport), the updater just displays a message saying "Please select the Nord Drum MIDI ports" before eventually timing out.  I've scoured the manual and can't find the error of my ways...?
